PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, representing the Prime Minister. No doubt the minister heard this morning the comments of the highly respected business leader, John Prescott, Managing Director of BHP, when he said that real interest rates in Australia are `unrealistically high'; that `they're out of line with the fundamentals'; that, despite low inflation, `we have amongst the highest money interest rates in the world'; and that interest rates in Australia have gone up three times the rate of those in the United States, without explanation from this government. I ask the minister: does this not further demonstrate how out of touch his government is with business reality when he describes, as he did a little while ago, the decision to push up interest rates as `sensible and prudential'? Does it not further demonstrate that the minister simply does not understand that what he is contributing to is a repeat of the boom-bust record which led to such devastation in the early 1990s?

—Senator Hill is making clear his inability to understand what Mr Prescott was talking about this morning. He said that we were seeing a broadly based recovery and that the government's projection of 14 per cent to 15 per cent growth in investment was realistic, and generally speaking his remarks were extremely supportive of the government's position and economic strategy.

PARA.TAB: What he said about real interest rates was clearly directed to the long end of the interest rate market; he was talking about movements in longer term interest rates, such as our 10-year bonds, because of the reference in the same sentence to increases two or three times greater than those in the US.
Senator Short interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —He could not have been talking about the short end of the market, Senator Short, because at the short end of the market—I will give Senator Short the figures—US rates have risen by 1 3/4 percentage points, while Australia's have risen by only three-quarters of a percentage point. We have had substantially less than half the increase in the United States at the short end of the market. The situation is that real short term interest rates are currently around 4.3 per cent, which is historically very low indeed.

PARA.TAB: It is the case that the longer term rates have been increasing. US 10-year bond yields have increased by around 1.6 percentage points from their February average, while Australia's long yields have increased by around 3 1/2 percentage points. Increase in Australian yields have not been treble but in fact double those in the US. They are running at about 8.2 per cent, and that is historically high.

The whole point about the longer term rates is that they are determined by the markets, and the government shares Mr Prescott's difficulty in understanding why in the hell the markets have reacted as they have done so far at the long end of the market, because the truth is that the Australian economy is currently enjoying the best set of economic fundamentals for three decades, with inflation at extremely low levels, accompanied by very positive economic growth and particularly, of course, employment growth.

We have a situation where the Australian economy is universally acknowledged to be in just about the best shape it has been for the last three decades. Under those circumstances, it is manifestly irrational for the bond markets to have been as spooked as they apparently have been by some of those overseas developments which have led them to react in that way.

But the short term rates, which are the immediate representative of the government's position and the response to the government's position, are at the levels which I have described. Senator Hill has once again demonstrated that he could not make an impression on a soft cushion in this place or any other place he might choose to go to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The government continues to blame the markets rather than accept responsibility, and the minister continues to confuse the long end of the market with money rates. Mr Prescott was talking about money rates. Look at bank prime interest rates. Is it not in fact the case that Australian prime interest rates are higher than those of Austria, Belgium, Britain, Canada, Denmark, France, Germany, Holland, and three times that of Japan and the United States? Is that not in fact what Mr Prescott was talking about? How does the government expect Australian business to compete under its policies when business has to accept real interest rates higher than those of the rest of the world?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let Mr Prescott speak for himself:

ANSWER.PARA: I think interest rates in Australia in real terms are unrealistically high. They are out of line with the fundamentals. We still have very low inflation but we have amongst the highest money interest rates in the world. Our interest rates have gone up three times the increases in the US for reasons that have not been explained.
He is obviously talking about that, otherwise his reference to the United States would have made no sense at all. The question was:
And the Reserve Bank is about to put them up again?
And Mr Prescott went on to say this:
Well, I know there is speculation about that but we would see that as being at loggerheads with the fundamentals.

The reference to the `fundamentals' is one of total confidence in the fundamentals of the Australian economy as they exist at the moment, and of total confidence in what the government has done to produce those fundamentals being as effectively in place as they are.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Today the Prime Minister released the government's cultural policy statement Creative Nation, in which he announced a significant number of very important initiatives across Australia's cultural landscape. Can the minister, particularly in his capacity as Minister for Trade, explain how these initiatives will create the opportunities to enhance Australia's export performance and project a new, vibrant image abroad?

—I thank the honourable senator for her very creative question. It is in fact a privilege to have had the chance to be even slightly involved in the development of this very important statement. I think Australians will immediately and over time come to recognise and appreciate the significance of this statement in Australian cultural history. It seeks to enhance our capacity as Australians and as a nation to access, preserve and protect our cultural heritage; to encourage and facilitate new artistic works; and to maximise community participation in our cultural life. This comprehensive and important statement builds on a sound record that was reflected particularly in the 1993 budget.

PARA.TAB: I wish to make particular reference, in direct response to Senator West's question, to the economic aspect of the statement. One part of this very important cultural statement is the overdue proper recognition of the importance of arts and culture as an industry in Australia, an industry which is providing more than 300,000 jobs. It is also an industry with a significant export potential. In fact, it is an industry that adds value to many other areas of activity through design, innovation and marketing. The sincere commitment of the opposition to it was reflected at the last election and appreciated by the people in question.

Culture is also a valuable export in itself, and there is great potential for that to be added to. The international market for cultural industries is large and growing, and we can share in that increase. In this statement there are many initiatives which build on those things which we did in the 1993 budget in respect of plugging the arts industries into our industry support programs and providing explicit export assistance.

We are building on that with new technology initiatives to give Australian industry the capacity to participate in the new international opportunities on the superhighway. Of course, with the film and television fund we are building on the recent tremendous success of our film industry and our television industry. There is a growing capacity for these industries to sell in our region and around the world. As the number and diversity of television channels in our region grow, so the demand for television products will expand. The capacity of Australians to meet that demand is strong and will be substantially reinforced by the strength of the TV production fund and the SBS fund, which have been developed in this statement.

It is also important to note that we have provided additional funding for the Australia Council to develop an international marketing strategy to increase export potential. It is doing well already. This morning I had the opportunity to open the performing arts market. The market is being developed by the Performing Arts Board of the Australia Council and is being conducted in conjunction with the National Festival of Australian Theatre here in Canberra.

That has been very successful and is a basis on which we can build. That is why there is extra funding for an international market strategy for the Australia Council, and that will coincide with a market development and international cultural projection strategy within the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

There is no doubt that the recent promotion in Indonesia, and others previously in Korea and Japan, have shown the export potential as well as the cultural benefit of major promotions integrating our business and trade development with the best of Australian culture. There is more funding in this program to develop the opportunity for the best that Australian arts have to offer to project themselves internationally and to reinforce our export performance.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Will the minister confirm that Mr Keating wants to upgrade his RAAF 707 aircraft at a cost of $10 million? Will he also confirm that Mr Keating wants the defence budget to carry the cost of the upgrade despite the protest of the RAAF? What improvement to our defence capability will be achieved by this renovation of the emperor's flying home?

—Mr President, it has obviously taken Senator Newman six or eight months to catch up with the news because it was in the newspapers six or eight months ago. The government was faced with the choice of a purchase of a new, second-hand or leased aircraft, or the much cheaper option of bringing the 707 up to a capability in which it could continue in service in the particular role that that plane has played for many years in the past and could play for many years in the future.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that these days the 707, as an international aircraft, is not capable of landing at many international airports because of the noise problem for a start, and that has been true for many years. I was only just reading in Senator Button's recently released book about his `voyage' to the funeral of Chernenko in 1984, where he had to fly into a US base in Japan because no commercial airport would take the 707. So we made a decision that, rather than go for the option of a modified 747—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I asked the minister a very specific question about whether the defence budget would be asked to meet this and whether the RAAF was protesting. I also asked about the defence capability that would be achieved by this particular upgrade, not by using it as a troop transport.

—Mr President, I did not realise that standing orders had been amended so that one had to give the full answer in a minute. I was going to take the four minutes and put the background to the decision.
—The minister was answering the question.

—Mr President, I was explaining the background to the decision to upgrade one 707. The ignoramuses over there decided to interrupt me but I will continue with my answer to Senator Newman's questions. The decision was made that the cheapest possible option in those circumstances was to upgrade one of the 707s, obviously the one that was not an air-to-air refueller. That decision was carried in the newspapers six or eight months ago.

PARA.TAB: The shadow defence spokesman at the time, Senator Hill, did not ask a question. Mind you, in his whole time as shadow minister, he never asked one question in the Senate—not one question in the Senate!
Senator Newman interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable senator for reminding me for the eighth time. It will be carried out of the defence budget as part of the expenditure. It is also a plane that is used for defence purposes and defence roles on occasions. What I am arguing, quite clearly, Mr President, is that this was by far the cheapest option available.

PARA.TAB: I do not know what Senator Newman expects. It is not the done thing for Prime Ministers and others to travel on commercial airlines. Let me tell Senator Newman that that is not enjoyed by commercial airlines because of the security problems it creates for them. As a country, we should provide a reasonable standard of transport for the Governor-General or the Prime Minister when they travel overseas. When I meet many of the visiting dignitaries, I look at some of the planes in which they arrive in this country and I find it quite clear that those planes are far more expensive to purchase and maintain than our well over 20-year-old 707s.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his attempt at an answer. However, I remind the minister that the purpose of these 707s is primarily as a troop transport and they must be readily convertible to such for an emergency. So I asked the minister just what this would do to our defence capability—and he failed to answer that. How many flying hours for training purposes will have to be cut by the RAAF unless the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet meets the $10 million bill instead of the Department of Defence?

—With respect to the first question, even this particular plane will remain available for transporting our troops when required—as will the other four planes that we have in service. All five planes will serve that purpose. The other four, of course, are also fitted with air-to-air refuelling, which is a great force multiplier. We have five planes. If necessary, we can use all five planes, even with a luxury fit, for transporting troops.

—Following on from the earlier question on the cultural statement, my question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. As part of the Prime Minister's cultural statement issued today, major initiatives were announced to boost Australia's interactive multimedia industry. Could the minister provide details and inform the Senate as to how these industry development initiatives relate to the government's cultural objectives?

—I endorse the sentiments expressed by my colleague Senator McMullan in his answer on the question of the cultural statement—a very important statement for all Australians—brought down by the government today. In that statement, the government set aside an amount of $84 million in a package of five specific measures to speed the growth of the Australian multimedia industry. Multimedia products and services are possible because of advances in technology, particularly the development of digital technology, and they are forming the basis of a new era of international service industries that are knowledge intensive. Australia, therefore, is ideally placed to capture part of this market—the government is determined to see that we do so—and seize the opportunities presented by this technology, both in cultural and in industry terms.

PARA.TAB: A key initiative announced by the Prime Minister today is the establishment of Australia Multimedia Enterprise, a $45 million fund to develop and commercialise multimedia products and services. The objectives of the enterprise will be to help finance the development of a multimedia industry in Australia and accelerate the production of Australian content multimedia titles. The enterprise will provide finance on a project basis to develop and commercialise multimedia titles in combination with private sector capital. Australia Multimedia Enterprise will increase direct investment into this area and also encourage private sector investment in the area as well. The fund will be driven by industry and will encourage the forming of consortia to produce and distribute high quality, interactive multimedia products and services. The fund will be supported by developers and is committed to adopting world's best practice as its standard.

In addition, the government has also committed $20.3 million over four years to see the development of up to six cooperative multimedia development centres to increase the skills base for this industry. The centres will be collaborative enterprises between the education and training sectors and other public and private sector organisations. An additional $7.6 million will be provided over the next two years to fund the production of Australia on CD, a program and showcase setting out the wide range of Australia's cultural endeavour.

The government will also provide specific assistance to the Australian Film Commission, the Australian Film Television and Radio School and the Australian Children's Television Foundation to encourage the development of their abilities in the multimedia field and to help capture for them and for Australia a large part of the work that will go on the information superhighway.

Finally, the government will fund a series of multimedia forums to bring interested developers together to address critical issues for the industry. Two million dollars will be provided over four years to allow forums to convene in a range of Australian venues with both local and international speakers.

The funding will also allow scope to market Australian conferences overseas and provide two-way video link-ups with international demonstration sites. The forums will facilitate joint ventures, marketing and distribution arrangements, and accelerate the integration of the industry, the cultural community and the government.

The initiatives taken in the cultural statement will not only lay the framework for ensuring that Australian content is not missing from new multimedia products but will also facilitate the development of a world-class innovative industry which can bring its products to the world market.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Justice. I refer to the minister's statement yesterday that the Director of Public Prosecutions wrongly advised the Australian Federal Police that they could not execute a search warrant against Telecom in their investigation of alleged phone monitoring and taping. Does the minister agree that the police have no way of knowing what information they were denied access to—for example, the rooms full of tapes reportedly held by Telecom—and that this must have had a significant effect on their investigation? Were representations made by Telecom to the DPP or to the police about Telecom's supposed shield of the crown immunity in the course of the police investigation? If so, what were they? Finally, has the minister requested an explanation of the DPP about how such a fundamental error was made, given that the Telstra Corporation Act makes it absolutely clear that Telecom enjoys no crown immunity? If so, what was the DPP's response?

—I can say in response to some of the points that Senator Bourne has made publicly and also Senator Spindler made in the Senate yesterday that I do have some more information to incorporate into Hansard after question time today. But that information does not go to the specific points that Senator Bourne has raised at this moment. What I intend to do with those is take them on notice and give Senator Bourne an assurance that we will come back with an answer to them tomorrow.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The minister would be aware of media reports today of a summit of farm and government leaders held in Canberra to discuss strategies for dealing with the impact of the drought on the future of grain supplies. Can the minister advise the Senate of the outcome of the meeting?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I can. I did meet with a group of representatives from the major primary producer organisations in Australia at the NFF meeting which was convened this morning and, indeed, is still in progress now. I had to tear myself away from it to come back to the delights of question time in the Senate, without which my life would not be complete.

PARA.TAB: All major primary producer organisations were represented at this extremely important meeting, and I emphasised at the beginning of the meeting this morning that, while the impending grain situation is serious, there is no reason for panic. I tabled an information paper at the outset of the meeting, and I was pleased that there was broad agreement at the meeting from all of the representatives there with the advice contained in the paper.

Current indications are that existing stocks of wheat, barley and sorghum are sufficient, with a 660,000 tonne safety margin to meet domestic demand until early December, when they will be supplemented by the new season's harvest and importation of grain. The amount of imports necessary will depend critically on the size of the winter crop harvest and the success of the summer sorghum crop.

At this stage, AQIS has received applications for the importation of just over half a million tonnes of grain. All of these figures are contained in the information paper. There will be a need, depending on the winter crop harvest and the summer sorghum crop, to import between half a million and up to two million tonnes of grain. That latter figure of two million tonnes, I might say, is based on a zero sorghum harvest, which, I stress, is highly unlikely to happen.

We will have a much better idea of the expected harvest when ABARE releases its accelerated crop report, which is now going to be released on 25 October. AQIS has so far received, as I have said, applications for the importation of over half a million tonnes of grain. There was broad agreement at the meeting with the information in the paper that our transport system, particularly our ports, will be able to handle transhipments or imports at this level if it is required.

The other major issue which is being discussed now is the AQIS protocols required for the importation of grain. Protocols have already been developed and approval given for the importation of 120,000 tonnes of sorghum, 50,000 tonnes of processed meals for stock feed and 10,000 tonnes of maize for pet food. I informed the meeting this morning that I have established an imported grain task force within the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service to speed up the AQIS approval process. It will consist of technical staff and plant scientists who will work full time on assessing applications to import grain.

If necessary, technical experts will be provided overseas to obtain the latest scientific information to assist in the decision making process. The task force will work to protect Australia's rural industries through the development of safe importing procedures, and the integrity of the assessment process will not be jeopardised. Because of the agreement, certainly in terms of supply and demand that was reached this morning on the basic information contained in the paper I presented this morning and because there are a number of senators who I think would find the detailed information useful, I seek leave of the Senate to have the document incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: SENATOR COLLINS, MINISTER FOR PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY NFF GRAINS MEETING ON 18 OCTOBER 1994
Thank you for the opportunity to address this most important meeting. I welcome the initiative of the NFF in drawing together Australia's principal grain users and suppliers.
I would like to address in turn each of the issues raised in Mr McGauchie's letter of invitation of 11 October.
At the outset, let me say I am dismayed by reports that there is "panic" in the grains market.
The crop shortages anticipated from this drought are serious but there is no reason for panic.

The preliminary advice from my Department is that there are sufficient wheat, barley and sorghum stocks already in Australia to meet expected demand until supplies become available from the new grain harvest or from imports.
Best Estimate of Available Feed Stocks and Likely Demand
Current stocks of grain in Australia held by the Australian Wheat Board, the Australian Barley Board, the NSW Grains Board and Queensland Grainco amount to 4.6 million tonnes.
This is a conservative estimate.
Importantly, it excludes on-farm stocks and those held by livestock feeders
exports of 2 m/t of wheat and up to 600,000 tonnes of barley are expected.
This leaves a balance of 2 m/t of wheat, barley and sorghum available for domestic use through to mid December.
Expected domestic demand over this period is for 1.33 million tonnes, providing an indicative national surplus of some 660,000 tonnes.
These estimates are based on advice from the Australian Wheat Board and the Australian Barley Board on their export intentions to my department on October 7.
There will be shortages of sorghum which users will need to make up with wheat, barley and other substitutes.

ANSWER.PARA: Transport of Grain from WA to the Eastern States and Physical
Capacity to Unload Grain Imports

The ports of Newcastle and Brisbane (Pinkenba and Fisherman Islands) are best located to service the drought-affected areas of NSW and Queensland. Port Kembla's unloading capability is set to come on-stream in mid-November

PARA.TAB: these ports are already equipped to handle grain shipments from other Australian States and can also handle imports of grain.

ANSWER.PARA: The vast bulk of WA and SA grain is being transported to NSW and Queensland on 30,000 to 50,000 tonne foreign-flagged vessels using single voyage permits.
The grain is unloaded by "grabs" into hoppers at dockside and transported by truck or rail.

Unloading capacities are 150,000 tonnes per month in Queensland (Pinkenba and Fisherman Islands) and 120,000 tonnes per month in NSW (Newcastle and Port Kembla). NSW capacity is soon to be upgraded to 160,000 tonnes per month.
Development of Protocols for Grain Imports
Protocols have already been developed and approval given for the importation of 120,000 tonnes of sorghum, 50,000 tonnes of processed meals for stock feed and 10,000 tonnes of maize for pet food.
Each application for importing grain is assessed on its merits.
The time taken to approve applications for processing grain imports in metropolitan areas where a similar protocol has already been developed is relatively short.
I have established an "Imported Grain Task Force" within the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service to speed up the AQIS approval process.
It will consist of technical staff and plant scientists, who will work full-time on assessing applications to import grain.
If necessary a technical expert will be temporarily based in North America to obtain the latest scientific information to assist in the decision making process.
This Task Force will work to protect Australia's rural industries through the development of safe importing procedures. The integrity of the assessment process will not be jeopardised.
The Task Force will be able to provide advice and to answer industry questions on importing grain and can be contacted:
by telephone on 06 272 4177, or by facsimile on 06 272 3682
These measures will streamline the quarantine risk assessment process.
Cost and Capacity of Domestic Grain Transport
From my Department's investigations, the import capacity of the relevant bulk grain export terminals in Queensland and NSW is around 300,000 tonnes per month.

Australia has a well developed domestic grain transport system. I welcome comments from the experts here today on whether any problems are expected in transporting grain into the drought-affected areas of Queensland and NSW.
Impediments to the Efficient Operation of Grain Markets
Grain imports are a sensible option as part of a national strategy to ensure regional grain shortages are met in the most efficient and cost effective way possible.

It makes sense to sell high quality milling wheat and malting barley into hard-fought and established export markets rather than using it as stockfeed in Australia when feed grain can be imported at a lower price.
Recent calls for unnecessarily restricting grain imports would have the unwelcome effect of further increasing domestic feed grain prices.

This would disadvantage livestock producers resulting in a large increase in prices of poultry and pig meat for consumers. Such price increases would also make it difficult for domestic food processors to compete with cheaper processed food imports.
Summary
I am aware of some press reports that Australia could have to import some $500 million of grain this year.
At current prices, that translates to between 1.5 m/t to 2 m/t of grain. I would make the following points:

current indications are that existing stocks are sufficient, with a 660,000 tonne safety margin, to meet domestic demand until early December when they will be supplemented by the new season's harvest and imports of grain
the amount of imports necessary will depend critically on the size of the winter crop harvest and the success of the summer sorghum crop
at this stage AQIS has received applications for the importation of just over half a million tonnes of feed grain.

the "DPIE audit of grain supplies" is in fact a joint effort commissioned by the SCARM which is being undertaken by ABARE in conjunction with the states. It will look at stocks and expected production and is to be released on 25 October as an ABARE Crop Report
18th October, 1994.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Given that the Prime Minister solemnly promised prior to the last election that the cultural statement was substantially completed and that it has only now surfaced, 18 months later after four deferrals, with the eighth arts minister in seven years comprehensively sidelined, why is it that the document still cannot identify the members of the major organisations board; has no idea what copyright protection is appropriate for the new communications environment; declines to specify how it would protect Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cultural materials under the Copyright Act; and absolutely refuses to give any details of its commitment to the protection of the moral rights of all copyright creators?
—That is a second-rate performance.

—Well, second-rate is a positive compliment. Indeed, it is a third or fourth rate contribution from Senator Alston. But it is what we would expect from an opposition that has never had anything useful or constructive or positive to say about arts in this country. As to the specific points on copyright that Senator Alston raises, I will refer those to the Prime Minister or the relevant minister for a detailed reply.

PARA.TAB: As for the point Senator Alston made about the major organisations board, he comprehensively misses the point. The point is that the government is not in the business of itself determining who is getting what amount of funding from what particular pools. It is a matter for arms-length determination and recommendation and advice by the Australia Council. It has not been determined who is in it yet. That is a matter for determination in the first instance by the Australia Council, as I understand it. The government does not want to be put in the position of varying from the arms-length policy that we have adopted towards all grants to relevant organisations.

We have not adopted an arms-length policy so far as some of the major organisations are concerned. That is a matter of history and the specific circumstances. But when it comes to possibly bringing within the scope of this new funding package organisations that have previously been outside it, it is a matter that the government would prefer to distance itself from rather than expose itself to suggestions of the kind that those opposite would no doubt be the first to make.

More generally, Mr President, the opposition's mean-spirited approach to this whole arts and culture policy does it no credit and does the intelligence of the Australian public and electorate no credit. I think that ordinary Australians are proud of the culture that this country has generated, the standing that we enjoy internationally in all the major arts, and the way in which these—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. The minister is now clearly debating this issue, and he is entitled to debate it after question time. But he was asked a number of specific questions relating to deficiencies in the government statement and that is what he ought to be answering.
—He has.

—When there is provocation on both sides, it is very difficult to judge whether the answers are specifically relevant to the question or not or answering interjections. I would ask you to keep your answer to the point.

—If I am asked questions about the inadequacy in the content and the approach adopted by the government towards its arts funding policy, it is entirely reasonable, in my judgment, to be able to make some general points in reply. The only point I was making is that the opposition has utterly failed to appreciate, and by its nature it is congenitally incapable of understanding, the basic point that Mr Keating was making when he first foreshadowed this particular policy. He then said that the arts are a measure of our guiding spirit and a measure of our identity as a nation and as a people.

PARA.TAB: That is what this particular policy is designed to touch, to stimulate and to respond to so far as the feelings and the pride of ordinary Australian people are concerned. That is the essential core and substance of this policy. All the nitpicking and miserable, mean-spirited response to it by those opposite will not undermine that basic reality—that this is a policy that has an enormous appeal to the Australian people, who are much prouder of their country than is Senator Alston.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I will ignore the allegation of treason. I notice the minister's constant reference to `ordinary Australians'. Perhaps he would like to tell us why ordinary Australians should not be outraged at the way in which he has gone about ratting on pre-election promises, particularly the cultural foundation which, he solemnly promised, would be set up quite separate and apart from the Australia Council and would be located in Melbourne. Now we are told it is going to be subsumed within the Australia Council. The government was committed to spend $27 million to locate the National Museum at Yarramundi Reach. Once again it has comprehensively ratted on the Australian people. It is now proposing a pale imitation. It will retain Aboriginal cultural artefacts only, and even then only because Langmore shamed the minister into it in caucus. Why should ordinary Australians believe a word the minister says?

—The difficulty, as always, is that Senator Alston's offensiveness is matched only by his ignorance. The truth of the matter is that the cultural foundation that was promised by the Prime Minister is to be established—with a base in Melbourne. It is the case that the National Museum will have a continuing role and status, not only through the proposed new Gallery of Aboriginal Art, which is to be established with a home of its own on the Acton Peninsula here in Canberra. The museum concept is to stay alive. It is to be responsive to the new reality about access to collections.

PARA.TAB: If those opposite read the terms of the statement they will see that the whole concept is to develop a new system whereby audiovisual access to the contents of this collection as it stands at the moment will be attainable and, hopefully, over time, under the umbrella of the National Museum, access of this kind will be attainable to every other significant collection in the country. For the first time there will be an integrated concept of a national museum which will not just mean the building of bricks and mortar on a particular location, but will genuinely represent the collection and heritage of the nation. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is the minister in a position to inform the Senate of the events related to the attempted peace negotiations on Bougainville? Is it true that the peace conference broke down on Friday of last week and has not reconvened since? Is this irretrievable? What is to happen now with the South Pacific peacekeeping forces on Bougainville? What is an appropriate Australian role?

—Unhappily, it is the case that the Bougainville peace conference adjourned last Friday, 14 October, at Arawa without any progress being made. It did, in that sense, break down. The chairman, Sir George Lepping, has now returned to the Solomon Islands. I understand that the delegates, who gathered in their hundreds from all parts of Bougainville for the talks, have for the most part gone home. So the hope that the peace conference would mark a decisive step towards a peaceful settlement of the Bougainville conflict has clearly not been realised. That is a matter of profound disappointment to all those, not least Prime Minister Sir Julius Chan, who devoted enormous personal energy, time and commitment to the process.

PARA.TAB: The refusal of the BRA leadership to participate in the conference and their reassertion of hardline demands, including their reported statement that, if total independence is not granted, blood will continue to be shed, suggests that they at least are unprepared to make the compromises that are obviously necessary for a peaceful settlement. We in Australia again appeal to all parties to pursue the process of negotiation and reconciliation. The need for peace on Bougainville is as pressing as ever. The genuine efforts of the majority of parties on Bougainville, supported by regional countries through the regional peacekeeping force, deserved a better outcome than this.

Although the conference has concluded, I understand that large numbers of people from the surrounding areas who met at Arawa yesterday expressed opposition to the hardline stand of BRA leaders Ona, Kabui and Kauona, and that efforts to continue a dialogue between the government and more moderate elements of the BRA may be continuing. Expression of such sentiments in what is effectively the BRA heartland is of some significance. If such a dialogue can be maintained, it may yet offer some progress towards peace, even if the main chance has for the moment been missed.

The South Pacific peacekeeping force has performed outstandingly and won the respect and trust of all parties. It did everything expected of it in securing the conference site, establishing neutral zones and providing security for those wishing to attend the conference. With the effective conclusion of the conference and of its task, the SPPKF is now making preparations for its withdrawal from Bougainville and expects to be off the island by Wednesday.

That force represents an unprecedented exercise in South Pacific regional cooperation. I believe we should be proud of the part that our personnel, along with of course those from Fiji, Tonga, Vanuatu and New Zealand, have played in it. While the command on the ground was exercised by Fiji and Tonga and personnel from those two countries and Vanuatu made up the force itself, the force could not have done the job asked of it without Australia's overall coordination and logistic capabilities, which no other contributor was in a position to provide.

The immediate outlook on Bougainville is very clouded, but the desire of the overwhelming majority of Bougainvilleans for an end to the fighting has, I think, already been forcefully demonstrated at the conference. We appeal to all parties to respect this through maintenance of the cease-fire. We in Australia remain ready to consider any further requests that might be made for assistance in the search for peace on Bougainville. But again I make the point that I have made over and over again from the outset, and that is that the process can be carried forward only through decisions taken by the various groups on Bougainville itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. The arts paper released today by the government says that many problems of centralised control are identified in the Tribe report of the 1980s and that the world's finest orchestras all operate under local control. Why then does the paper go on to provide that existing funding for the Sydney Symphony Orchestra will be transferred from the ABC to the Australia Council, with a five-year funding guarantee and a commitment that this `flagship orchestra will tour throughout Australia, become a major cultural export and strengthen its program of international recording' when, at the same time, it gives no comfort or funding commitment to any other of the state orchestras?

—It is made clear in the statement that other orchestras, apart from the Sydney Symphony Orchestra, will continue to receive their same level of funding for the foreseeable future through the ABC. Moreover, they will have the opportunity to seek, if they so desire it, the same separate status as the Sydney Symphony Orchestra is proposed to be given.

PARA.TAB: The point that lies behind this particular initiative is to try to create circumstances where the Sydney Symphony Orchestra can become an orchestra of genuine international stature, to perhaps an even greater extent than it has at the moment, in the same way as the Berlin, New York or London Philharmonic Orchestras have become. That is the kind of concept that the Prime Minister and the cabinet have had in mind in breaking the links in this way and creating the potential for the Sydney Symphony Orchestra to really take off. It is already at reasonably exalted heights in terms of orchestral standing, but this is an opportunity for it to become an orchestra of really great heights.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Melbourne Symphony Orchestra? Why have you sold out to Sydney?

—The judgment has been made—maybe it is a tough one for the MSO—that it probably is the case that, internationally, to reach these kinds of international standards with the kind of funding support that is necessary, a country of our size can sustain only one orchestra on that fully, elaborately developed basis. But that is not to say it might not prove possible for the others to join the ranks. That particular possibility has not been excluded. In order to make life a little easier for Melburnians to bear in this respect—

PARA.TAB: Senator Robert Ray interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Ray will allow me to get a word in, it is also the case that Melbourne has been specifically recognised in this policy for its contributions to fine music by becoming the new home of the proposed new National Academy of Music, which will become—
—What about Queensland?
—Queensland is being very nicely looked after through an institute for indigenous performing arts which will be—
—Oh, ha ha!

—I can understand the chuckling and chortling because you, Senator Macdonald, and the red-necked troglodytes around you, do not give any credit to the reality of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander culture in this country. We not only recognise—

—Mr President, I raise a point of order on two grounds. Firstly, the minister is now debating the question. Secondly, he is directing his comments straight to Senator Ian Macdonald. He ought to direct his comments through you, and he ought to answer the question that I asked him.
—Senator Evans, you should direct your answer through the chair.

—Mr President, I have made the point. There is no attempt in any way to be discriminatory, other than in order to encourage the development of an even finer standard of performance and achievement so far as these performing arts in Australia are concerned. It is never going to be possible to make everyone happy in this respect, but an attempt has certainly been made to respond to the real capacity that exists in different parts of the country to do a specially important job in terms of the contribution that particular cities can make to particular areas of the performing arts. That recognition has been made in the ways that I have suggested.

PARA.TAB: Again, I do not think that this is the occasion for carping and nitpicking, let alone troglodyte redneck interjections of the kind that we had from Senator Ian Macdonald. This is a statement that addresses—in a way that is simply beyond Senator Macdonald's imagination, quite apart from being beyond his grasp—the needs of this country moving into the 21st century. It is a policy statement that represents the aspirations of this country and brings those aspirations a lot closer to realisation than is within Senator Macdonald's capacity to grasp.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. I refer the minister to the announcement in this year's budget of an additional $25 million in funding for primary health care to be spent over five years under the national Aboriginal health strategy. I ask: firstly, how many applications were received for that $25 million allocation and what was the total amount of funding requested; secondly, has the joint planning committee recommended that none of the $25 million be directed into primary health care but be directed instead towards capital works programs; thirdly, if this is the recommendation from the joint planning committee, can the minister assure the Senate that neither Minister Tickner nor Minister Lawrence will accept this recommendation and that they will, in fact, direct that the additional funding into primary health care services be as promised in the 1994 federal budget?

—Mr President, my advice is that the joint planning committee of the national Aboriginal health strategy is being held today. I am further advised that the meeting is going on as we speak and that it has not yet concluded. So it is not realistic to provide any information on the outcome of a meeting which has not concluded. I am told that the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs will not be briefed on the results of the meeting until it is finished. For that reason, I would ask Senator Lees to place the question on notice and I will ensure that she gets a response as soon as the meeting has finished its deliberations.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction. The minister will recall that last week I asked him a question regarding small business perceptions of government. In his response the minister stated that small business had responded very well to a range of programs available through his department and, in particular, that small business had welcomed the initiatives announced as part of the Working Nation statement. Last week the Tasmanian section of the Australian export awards were presented to various firms in that state. Can the minister inform the Senate whether any of the winning firms have had any involvement with any of the federal government's small business assistance programs or the initiatives announced in the Working Nation statement?

—Last week, as part of international business week in Tasmania, a number of awards were given to various firms, acknowledging the export success of those firms. The major award, the Premier of Tasmania's award for export success, went to the catamaran builder Incat Australia Pty Ltd. The agricultural products award went to Blue Ribbon Holdings. The large manufacture award went to United Milk Tasmania Ltd. The small to medium manufacture award went to Global Lightning Technologies. The new exporter award went to Aquatas Pty Ltd. The services award went to Mercury Walch Pty Ltd. All these firms have been very successful in the export market and will now progress to the national export awards.

PARA.TAB: These winners, from a range of activities in one form or another, have received assistance from various industry portfolio programs. For example, five of the companies have benefited from the 150 per cent research and development tax incentive; four have utilised the services of the national industry extension service, known as NIES; one has been assisted through EFIC, the Export Finance Insurance Corporation; another through the national teaching company scheme; and one through the ship bounty scheme. In summary, five out of the six winners have utilised one or more of the industry assistance programs.

Honourable senators would be aware that in the Working Nation statement earlier this year, the eligibility, for example, of the 150 per cent tax concession for R&D expenditure was made easier. So it is reasonable to expect that even more SMEs in particular will take advantage of the concession in this financial year. Similar improvements were made to the operation of EFIC to allow the corporation to provide greater assistance to exporters.

The simple point is that the government has a range of well-targeted industry assistance measures to assist Australian business particularly to become world best, more competitive and export orientated. I certainly urge all Australian business to have a look at the range of programs available. To assist in this, as part of the industry statement the government has established AusIndustry to be a one-stop shop approach to getting information about the assistance available. We now have a national telephone number that can be rung from anywhere in Australia. Any people from small or medium sized businesses, or from even larger ones, who are listening today can ring 008 026121. That number right around Australia will give them information about the range of programs.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is it again?
—For Senator Cook, the industry minister, I will repeat the number. It is 008 026121. That is the number people can ring to get that one-stop approach to these excellent programs.

PARA.TAB: Senator Murphy interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Murphy has said, they are available in Tasmania. This is an example of the assistance given by federal government programs to small and larger businesses in Australia.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction. I refer the minister to the Queensland and New South Wales governments' small business drought assistance scheme, which contains an annual interest subsidy of $5,000 for up to two years. I ask: as the small businesses of drought affected Queensland and New South Wales are being devastated by the drought, along with their farming customers, is the government prepared to match the Queensland and New South Wales governments' small business scheme dollar for dollar in the same way that the Queensland and New South Wales governments have matched the federal government's drought package?

—I must acknowledge the point that, in my 18 months as minister for small business, Senator Boswell is still the only member of the opposition who has asked me a question about small business. In 18 months, Senator Boswell is the only one opposite from either the National Party or the Liberal Party who has asked a question about small business. I have not had even one question from the Liberal Party about small business.
—Order! The minister will get on with answering the question.
—You can't even get the dorothy dixers right.
—The shadow minister for red hats over there ought to be very quiet. He is still trying to find the man with the red hat in Torres Strait.

PARA.TAB: I appreciate Senator Boswell's interest. I have to say to the honourable senator that the federal government will not match that particular program. I point out to him, though, that in the announcement made by the Prime Minister and my colleague Senator Collins, as Minister for Primary Industries amd Energy, about the drought assistance package, we have provided $164 million of assistance. We have provided income support of $73 million. On the business side, an additional $66 million over the next two years will be paid as an interest subsidy under the exceptional circumstances provisions of the rural adjustment scheme. We have also provided additional business advice in rural areas under the BARA scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —How about the high taxes?
—The point of all of these, as Senator Boswell would understand—even if blockhead Kemp over there cannot understand—is that all of this money—
—Senator Kemp!
—Mr President, would you tell Downer's fop to shut up for a while.
—Senator Schacht, have you completed your answer? I have already asked Senator Kemp to be quiet.

—No. Mr President, the real issue for small business is cash flow. I acknowledge that small businesses in country towns are suffering as a result of farmers not being able to purchase the same amount of goods and services because of the downturn caused by the drought. This $164 million in drought assistance will assist members of the farming community to buy services and goods from small businesses in country towns. This will help in a significant way small businesses in country towns to deal with their cash flow problems. We believe that that is the most effective way to provide the assistance.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. At estimates committee I asked whether Professor Healy had sought approval of the Monash University institutional ethics committee for trialling of the drug RU486. I now realise that I should have used the words `Monash Medical Centre'. I now ask: prior to the new CTN arrangements, did Professor Healy seek approval from the Monash Medical Centre's IEC, which failed to grant approval on the grounds of the toxic effect of the regimen on the women subjects of the trial? Is it a fact that, since the new CTN program has been in effect, Professor Healy has sought and obtained approval from the Family Planning Victoria ethics committee? As this CTN scheme has hit—(Time expired)

—Mr President, I will give Senator Harradine a general response to his question. I might have to follow through on some of those specifics of which I have not had notice, with Dr Lawrence. In relation to the legality of the Victorian trials, in terms of both their approval and conduct, that has been reviewed by the Attorney-General's Department. The advice is that the trials are legally correct in both respects. In relation to the approval of the importation of the drug and the clearance of the trials to proceed, the Attorney-General's Department has found that all legal requirements have been met.

PARA.TAB: Can I also say, Mr President, that the approval by the department in March 1994 for the importation of RU486 for use in the trials was made expressly conditional upon the use of the drug being fully compliant with the law. I am advised that Victorian and New South Wales laws make abortion generally illegal but provide for it to be carried out legally under specified circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. That is not particularly relevant. I would be interested in the opinions but, with respect, the response is not particularly relevant to the specific questions relating to the institutional ethics committee and the clinical trial notification scheme and the fact that Minister Lawrence has suspended those until a review takes place.
—I have no power to determine how the minister answers the question, but I ask him to take Senator Harradine's comments into account.

—I will indeed do that, Mr President. As Senator Harradine seems a bit dissatisfied with what I thought was a rather full answer, I will take Senator Harradine's question on notice and reply to him in due course.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I understand the problem. Whilst the minister does that, could he take into consideration the fact that a senior member of the team appointed to review the Family Planning Victoria trial of RU486 has now been found to have been the author of an article strongly supporting RU486 and is a colleague closely associated with Professor Healy? That person is Professor John Funder. Is it appropriate for that person to be part of the conduct of an independent inquiry?

QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacGibbon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. The minister will recall the Auditor-General's report into the Collins class submarine contractor of 1992 and the principal finding of that report, that is:

QUESTION.PARA: The protection provided by the contract is insufficient relative to the losses that may be sustained by the Commonwealth in the event of failure or default by the contractor.

In the two years since that report was written we have seen considerable slippage with the program. What steps has the Commonwealth taken to reduce its exposure in relation to the findings of the Auditor-General?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator MacGibbon would have listened with interest to my response at the time, which was a 20-minute response, in which I contested much of what the Auditor-General had to say at the time. This was not on the basis of the Auditor-General looking at questions of probity or otherwise, but his general summing up of what should be the proper business approach. I think I pointed out on that occasion that the major criticism of the Auditor-General was the amount of money paid up-front. Of course, the alternate bidder required a further $300 million up-front. To get a project of this particular size and sophistication up and running—probably the most advanced industrial project that this country has ever tackled—did require a fair amount of money up-front.

PARA.TAB: We were absolutely confident that the shareholders—that is, James Hardie, five per cent; Kockums, about 47 per cent, and the AIDC, about 47 per cent—would be able to provide financial security throughout the life of the project, and we remain so.

The only substantial slippage in the program, which we have gone over at estimates committee, was the delivery of the combat system, which relied on the development of software. There has been a variety of meetings with Rockwells and CSC to get that back on target. It appears now that much of the slippage will be contained over the next two years and that the project will right itself in terms of timely delivery with the third and fourth submarines. We know with the first submarine that the software for the combat system is being delivered in separate tranches and therefore the submarine trials can continue. So it remains our view in Defence that the financial situation in terms of guarantees is still in a very solid position.

I refer Senator MacGibbon back to my comments of December 1992, I believe, when the report came down about that particular audit report. I was not satisfied with it. It is the only time I have substantially criticised an audit report. I believe the Auditor-General went well beyond the normal audit process and did not necessarily have the resources or the staff to do that competently.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I well recall the minister's response to the Auditor-General's report, but I point out that that was some years ago. That was before the delays and the difficulties became as apparent as they are now with the software program, and probably some of the technical elements of the platform itself. I reiterate the point made by the Auditor-General, that we are dealing here with the equivalent of a $2 company. We have a company that has an equity capital according to the Auditor-General of only $10 million discharging a $5,000 million contract. I assume then from the minister's answer that he has taken no steps at all as a consequence of the Auditor-General's report.

—Kockums is part of the Celsius group of companies, which is one of the largest defence companies in the world. I think it is inconceivable, even if the worst occurred in terms of overrun and increase in costs—and there is no evidence of increase in costs—that it would not stand by its obligations under the contract. I have no doubt whatsoever about that. It would totally besmirch its worldwide reputation if it were to try to use some technicality to say that it did not have to finish this particular submarine. It is marketing submarines around the globe, and I am absolutely convinced there will be no difficulty in this regard. I should stress that the submarine is still on budget.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I refer the minister to the press reports that the application by the Russian-born boxer Kostya Tszyu to become an Australian citizen has been rejected because of trips overseas during his residency period. I ask the minister whether Mr Tszyu is eligible to become an Australian citizen and whether the press reports are correct in the details put forward.
—I am aware of the reports to which Senator Jones refers. I also welcome the opportunity to correct some of the factual errors.

—I am sure that, if Senator Kemp takes his time, he will not get as excited as he seems to be getting now. There have been some factual errors in the reporting. At the outset, let me say that I have had a look at this matter exhaustively over a period of a few months. I did so initially at the request of Mr Gary Punch, the member for Barton, and have done so with an endeavour to see whether there was any way we could assist this particular person.

PARA.TAB: To qualify for Australian citizenship an applicant must meet the residential requirements prescribed in subsections 13(1)(d) and (e) of the Australian Citizenship Act. Basically, these are that a person has to be here as a permanent resident for some one year during the two years prior to the application; and, secondly, has to be a permanent resident for not less than two years during the five years preceding the date of the application. It is obvious, therefore, that this particular person did not qualify, having applied for Australian citizenship on 17 May 1994 but having entered Australia as a temporary resident on 8 November 1991 but becoming a permanent resident on 7 April 1993.

I also exhaustively pursued whether any areas of discretion could be applied here. The media, in fact, has got it wrong in respect of the capacity to exercise discretion in this area. There are two avenues of discretion which might have been available: one was section 13(4)(b) of the act. That allows discretion to count periods of temporary residence as permanent residence if the applicant would suffer significant hardship or disadvantage if the application were denied. Mr Tszyu submitted a statement in support of his application, but he was not able to demonstrate that significant hardship or disadvantage would flow from being denied Australian citizenship in accordance with the legislation.

There is also a discretionary power in the act for periods spent outside Australia after becoming a permanent resident to be considered as qualifying periods if the time is spent, in accordance with the legislation, engaged in activities beneficial to the interests of Australia. Even if the time Mr Tszyu has spent outside Australia at sporting events is counted as permanent residence in accordance with this discretion, he would still not be able to meet the resident qualifications until 7 April 1995 at the very earliest.

These provisions have been fully explained to him and he understands he is not yet eligible for citizenship. I can say, however, that I am looking forward to welcoming him and his wife to the family of Australian citizens as soon as they are eligible to be considered under the legislation. In the meantime, I wish him the best at the world championships in December.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—On 12 October last, Senator Coulter asked Senator McMullan, then acting as Minister representing the Minister for Finance, a question concerning the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories. Senator McMullan took part of that question on notice, and I now can provide the reply.

PARA.TAB: Under an indemnity agreement the Commonwealth has indemnified CSL for certain existing and potential claims made for personal injury, loss or damage suffered through therapeutic use of certain products manufactured by the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories. This agreement includes cover for products and claims relating to products derived from plasma collected from blood donated by people in New Zealand and Papua New Guinea and which have been manufactured by CSL and supplied for use in New Zealand and Papua New Guinea prior to the CSL share offer settlement date.

This indemnity applies to claims by persons who contract or have contracted hepatitis because of the use of those products and products derived from plasma collected from blood donated by people in Australia and which have been manufactured by CSL before the plasma fractionation contract between CSL and the Commonwealth commenced. This contract became effective on 1 January 1994. This indemnity applies to claims by persons who contract or have contracted hepatitis because of the use of those products. Details of this indemnity agreement were disclosed on pages 91 and 92 of the CSL Ltd prospectus dated 15 April 1994.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —After question time yesterday, Senator Spindler raised some questions on the applicability of legislation and the effect of the shield of crown immunity with respect to Telecom or Telstra. During question time today, I indicated that I had some more information to provide to the Senate. I seek leave to incorporate not just the answer from the relevant minister, but also the advice that Senator Spindler sought for tabling yesterday, with excisions to ensure that no operational activities are compromised by the publication of that advice.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: Answer:

I wish to respond to matters raised by Senator Spindler, on 17 October, in relation to the AFP investigation into alleged illegal telephone monitoring by Telecom and advice provided by the DPP that search warrants would not issue against Telecom as it was protected by shield of the Crown immunity.

I can inform the Senate that the Attorney-General's Department advises the Minister for Justice that it does not agree with the conclusion, reached by the DPP on 4 March 1994, that a search warrant under section 10 of the Crimes Act 1914 cannot issue against `Telecom' premises.
The DPP opinion referred to the ruling by the full Federal Court in Rogers-v-Moore (1993) 115ALR 347, which held that section 10 was not expressed to bind the Crown.
I am informed that on the 22 September 1994 the DPP advised the AFP that, "There is an argument that a search warrant will lie against the premises of Telstra".

Section 26 of the Telstra Corporation Act 1991 provides that Telstra, more commonly known as `Telecom', is taken for the purpose of Commonwealth, State and Territory laws, not to be an "instrumentality or agency of the Crown" and "not to be entitled to any immunity or privilege of the Commonwealth" unless a law expressly provides otherwise.
The Attorney-General's Department advised that there is no provision in the Crimes Act which provides that Telstra is to be treated as if it were the Crown for the purposes of section 10.
The remainder of the matters raised by Senator Spindler query the adequacy of the AFP investigation in light of the original advice.
I am informed that an interim brief is presently under consideration by the DPP. As I understand the situation the director, Mr Michael Rozenes QC, will personally consider the matter.

The DPP is an independent statutory office, I remind the Senate that if the DPP forms an opinion that further enquiries need to be made into any of the matters disclosed by the AFP investigation, or that further investigation needs to be made, then he can request for that to be done.
For obvious reasons I am reluctant at this time to discuss the AFP investigation.
However, I am assured by the AFP that, as indicated in the Senate on Monday 17 October, that the DPP advice had little or no effect on the final outcome of the AFP investigation.
I wish to make it clear that this government has not applied `external pressure' on the AFP or the DPP over this investigation.

The advice the DPP provided on 4 March was simply wrong. The AFP, having sought legal advice naturally complied with it and sought the information required by other means. That is all there is to this matter.

In relation to Senator Spindler's request for tabling of the DPP's advisings this government is generally reluctant to table advice, particularly when it relates to current operational matters. However, as the matter relates specifically to a point of law I am prepared to table that part of the DPP's original advice relating to that matter. I am informed that the second advice, offered on 22 September, was verbal.

As for the advice from the Attorney-General's Department that was tendered to the Minister for Justice as a result of the matters raised by Senator Spindler. I have provided full details of that advice earlier in this answer.
Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions Head Office
4 March 1994
Australian Federal Police
GPO Box 401
CANBERRA ACT 2601
Attention: Commander Brown
RE AFP INVESTIGATIONS INTO ALLEGED ACTIVITIES OF TELSTRA
I refer to your request of 28 February 1994 for clarification of three points in relation to your investigation into the above matter and provide the following by way of answer.

You ask whether a search warrant can be obtained for premises occupied by "Telecom". The answer is, no. As you recall the decision in Rogers v Moore and Others (1993) 41FCR301, a decision of the Full Federal Court, was to the effect that Section 10 of the Crimes Act 1914 does not authorise the issue of a warrant to enter and search the premises of the Crown in right of a State. It is further authority for the proposition that the Crown in right of the Commonwealth can not be the subject of such a warrant.

AOTC was created through the merger of the Australian Telecommunications Corporation (Telecom) and OTC Limited. Like its predecessors the new body AOTC is owned by the Commonwealth which has the sole right to shares and to vote and is not able, by statutory prohibition, to divest itself of shares or voting rights. Further, the Minister has the right to give the Company directions concerning any matter. In 1993 AOTC adopted `Telstra' as the trading name for use outside Australia and as the Company name in lieu of AOTC. I am in no doubt from the legislation that Telstra is in fact an instrumentality of the Commonwealth and as such a warrant may not be directed towards it.

As you are aware, leave to appeal to the High Court from the decision of the Full Federal Court has been granted and the matter is listed for hearing in mid March. It would not be proper to approach a Magistrate or Justice to seek to have a warrant issue contrary to the Rogers v Moore decision.
If there is anything further you require, please contact the writer on 2705670.
Grant Lalor

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan) and the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans), to questions without notice asked by Senators West and Alston this day, relating to the government's cultural policy.

SPEECH.PARA: This document is a very substantial let-down for all those people who, after at least 18 months, were expecting a fair bit of coherence in terms of strategy and some fairly precise indications of who would be receiving specific funding and, of course, it is a let-down for a number of people who thought they were entitled to rely on solemn pre-election promises. The National Museum is probably the high-water mark of perfidiousness because, quite clearly, the government's promise on the museum was given with very great intent. It was the centrepiece of the government's arts policy prior to the last election. Those of us who have inspected the collection, as I have several times, would know that it has one of the most extensive collections of Aboriginal art, particularly Arnhem Land bark paintings, which long ago ought to have been on public display. Prior to the last election, the government never contemplated that it should be somehow put to one side and treated as a virtual museum. It ought to be seen in context. It ought to be regarded as part of our cultural heritage, as a unique aspect but, nonetheless, as part of an integrated whole.

PARA.TAB: Instead, we have had a pure exercise in political self-indulgence—a megalomaniac Prime Minister (Mr Keating) who has his own views and versions of what constitutes culture. He is sure into culture, but not Australian culture. If it is all about trawling through art galleries and antique shops, if it takes him to the other side of the world, it is fine. He is very keen on it and loves to do the rounds of the galleries in Europe. But if it comes to looking at Australian architecture and Australian culture, all we get is a Prime Minister bagging those with a Hill's hoist and those who cannot afford more than a quarter-acre block.

It is very disappointing to find that we cannot at least have a national museum, like every other country in the OECD, that will bring together all of those items in a central repository. It is a matter of concern to me that some solemn assurances were given not just prior to the last election, but subsequent to the last election. I will indicate the concern that I have in that area in a moment.

I would also like to draw the Senate's attention to the total failure of the government to take seriously the notion of cultural exports. If one seriously acknowledged that we have a trade imbalance of about 5:1 and that there is a lot more we can do to coordinate art exports, one would set up a specific cultural exports board that would bring together those with expertise in the areas of importance, such as marketing; instead, that vital area is handed over to the Australia Council.

In other words, bureaucrats are once again running the show. We already have bureaucrats in foreign affairs, trade and other departments with this so-called responsibility, but none of it is being brought together in any coordinated manner. As a result, there is now no prospect of any further progress. I will show the minister three statutory declarations and ask him if he has any objection to the incorporation of those documents in Hansard.

It is a matter of great concern that the Minister representing the Prime Minister, Senator Gareth Evans, admitted during question time that we are now to have a de facto national orchestra. Only one orchestra can be sustained on the basis that he outlined and if it is the flagship, if it gets the international assistance, we can rest assured that all the other orchestras will be gutted—they will be cut adrift from the ABC or left to raise their own funds and rely upon the generosity of state governments. Not only is the government going against the Tribe report but also it is being consistent with its whole notion of culture residing on the eastern seaboard of Australia, otherwise the government does not want to know about it.

The only way that this government's Prime Minister wants to see Australia is from 35,000 feet above sea level on his way to Paris. Quite clearly, that is not what Australians want. They desperately expected that there would have been some spreading around of the goodies with the creative fellowships granted yesterday. But what did we get? We got simply a very one-sided view of what constitutes excellence. I seek leave to incorporate these documents in Hansard.
Leave granted.
