TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say a few things on this subject, particularly in the context of the National Museum, because Senator Alston really is gilding the lily in his usual fashion on this particular subject. As the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said last week in parliament, the government does not intend to disband the National Museum; on the contrary. We said at the last election that we would provide $26 million for the construction of the National Museum if the museum could raise the equivalent amount from the private sector, which to date has not occurred. It remains the case that to establish the museum on the basis that was originally contemplated remains a very big ask indeed when that support is not coming from other than strictly governmental sources.

PARA.TAB: The trouble was that, while other aspects of the museum's outreach activities were being addressed through travelling exhibitions and exhibitions at Old Parliament House and Yarramundi, under those circumstances in particular we would not be able to see any progress, at least not quickly, on the development of the Gallery of Aboriginal Australia, which everyone has acknowledged to be at the core, at the heart and the centrepiece of the museum's collection and the material that exists for that particular purpose.

So we have decided to treat as a priority the establishment of the Gallery of Aboriginal Art, to establish it as a major physical centre on the Acton site, which is the old Canberra Hospital site—a magnificent site effectively in the centre of Canberra. It will be a stand-alone institution involving ATSIC and the Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, with the Gallery of Aboriginal Australia built as part of that. It will be a magnificent facility and it will be at the core and the heart of the clear original concept of the National Museum.

It is not intended that the National Museum disband its existing collection of non-Aboriginal material. That will continue to be exposed at the Yarramundi site, which will not be disbanded, notwithstanding the fulminations that Senator Alston is going on with about doubts to that effect, statutory declarations and so on. The Yarramundi site, as I understand it, will be maintained. Moreover, National Museum displays will continue at other window outlets of the Sydney Customs House and the Old Parliament House and, in that direct physical way, that aspect of Australia's social history will be brought to the people.

Moreover, it is proposed, as I said in the course of question time, that a new concept be developed for outreach in terms of not only this particular collection but also, hopefully, the collections over time of all the major national collecting institutions in Australia. Through the development of CD-based multimedia broadband services of one kind or another there will be access to these collections by many more Australians than would be the case if it were established as a single, stand-alone facility in Canberra.

What might evolve in the future so far as another physical facility for the remainder of that collection is concerned is a matter for the future, but for the moment far and away the most important and largest component of the National Museum collection will be housed, and housed in a way that will do us all proud.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have abandoned the museum and you know it!
—I am a bit surprised to hear an interjection from Senator Reid about that. I thought she would be very pleased indeed to have the Gallery of Aboriginal Australia established in this particular way.

PARA.TAB: On the question of cultural exports, to which Senator Alston also made another unhelpful contribution—and he is leaving the chamber now, of course, having said his little piece—it is the case that the government considered whether or not to establish a separate stand-alone organisation to advance the cause of cultural exports. But we took the view that on balance, rather than devoting scarce resources to establishing yet another separate bureaucracy, it was more important to get the appropriate linkages working between Austrade, which has an existing responsibility for cultural export promotion, and the expertise that resides in the Australia Council. A significant amount of money will be allocated to enable those exports to be stimulated and developed in that way, but in a way that is more cost effective than through creating, as I said, yet another bureaucracy.

On the subject of the orchestras, I think that question has been answered in question time. It is not in any sense the government's intention to sever the capacity of or to set adrift the non-Sydney ABC symphony orchestras. They perform a tremendously significant role in their respective states. Indeed, it is to be hoped that they will continue to play that role and have an enhanced role in that respect in the future. But it is possible, we believe, if we establish some new less restrictive funding arrangements, to enable at least one—maybe more than that over time, but at least one—orchestra to acquire the level of standing, performance skills and performance capacity that will make it a genuinely, absolutely unequivocally, international class orchestra.

I can understand those on the other side who do not share that aspiration for Australia to have such an orchestra, but that once again, I am afraid, simply demonstrates the narrow-mindedness which is endemic on the other side of politics.

TALK.START.PARA: —The most significant thing about this cultural statement is its acknowledgment, admittedly hidden away, that so much of the enormous advances in government support for the arts took place under coalition governments.
—Ha, ha!

—The minister laughs. He obviously has not read the statement, and I recommend him to do so before we get that kind of smart alec response. In fact, the statement specifically points to the significant steps forward under the Gorton government. I must admit it does fudge a few things: it claims that the taxation benefits arrangements to the arts came in in 1991—in other words, under this government—when in fact they were simply the reallocation of the arrangements under the Australian Elizabethan Theatre Trust, which had been introduced by a coalition government. In fact, almost all the major developments in arts funding in Australia were introduced by coalition governments.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Elizabethan Theatre Trust, which I have already mentioned, was the vehicle through which the first ever taxation concessions for the arts were made available. The Australia Council for the arts was established by whom? Naturally, a coalition government. The coalition has an enormous history of support for and encouragement of the arts. While the minister at the table sneers at that, his own statement recognises it. That is why I say that is the most important part of the statement, because it removes the capacity for people like Senator Evans to carry on in that childish way. It removes the dishonesty presented by the government that, until Whitlam, there was no recognition that the arts existed in Australia.

The rewriting of history that has gone on by people like Senator Evans becoming some kind of incompetent Manning Clark of the arts for the Labor Party is just extraordinary. I must say that there are some elements of this cultural statement which I am glad to see. I have to say that. It includes, for example, some things that were in my arts policy, and I commend the government for picking up those things.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have no shame.

—I am interested that a senator who has not heard a word of this matter has come into the chamber once again maintaining the Senator Evans sneer. This is just nonsense. It is a pity she was not here to hear the facts. The one thing I would say about this cultural statement is that it does mirror the government's policy. It is a mirror all right because the government is looking into everything. There are very few positive statements of what it is going to do. As I said, I commend a great many of those statements, but all through this statement the government says that it will `examine' such and such—in one case it says `endeavour to examine'. That is perhaps not quite getting up to the barrier of actually examining something.

PARA.TAB: The government says it will `investigate' and `review'. It is a sort of tax summit or economic summit for the arts. When those opposite do not know what they really want to do, they go to the people and say, `We do not know what we really want to do but we will have a summit about it.' They have been in government for 11 years, but they do not know what to do yet. That is what this statement reveals. That is why I find it disappointing that in so many areas, after 11 years in government, this government still does not know. Yet it has made a virtue of its alleged enormous and overwhelming commitment to the arts.

Everyone in this chamber knows how disappointed I was that many of my ideas were not accepted by my side at the last election. I do not resile from that, but that is what makes this statement even more disgraceful. Those opposite got such political capital from claiming to be total supporters of the arts, but now put out a statement that says, `We do not know what to do after 11 years but we will look into it.' That is the looking glass approach to government from the mirror party opposite. They are `looking into it'. Surely they can do better than that.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Loosley this day, relating to the peace conference in Bougainville.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a matter of profound regret that this long war, which has now gone on for over five years, cost at least 3,000 lives, and disrupted and dislocated the lives of tens of thousands of other people, has not been brought to a peaceful conclusion by the negotiations which began in Arawa approximately 10 days ago.

PARA.TAB: It was a very hopeful beginning, there was reason for optimism, and the negotiations seemed full of promise. A cease-fire agreement was in place between the government of Papua New Guinea and the Bougainville revolutionary forces. There had been direct face-to-face contact at the highest level in Honiara between Prime Minister Sir Julius Chan and Commander Sam Kauona. There was every reason to believe that there was a real chance of finding a successful end to the war, a solution which would be both just and enduring.

It was hoped by a lot of us in this place that a solution could be discovered through the process of negotiation. This has proved to be an opportunity squandered. It is a real tragedy in the making. It is not an opportunity that is likely to arise easily or readily again. I hope the opportunities present themselves again, but a solution will not be easily accomplished. In that respect, the Arawa talks, which, as the foreign minister said, broke down last Friday, must be placed with the earlier Honiara endeavour accord, which also failed to bring an end to the island troubles. Those agreements, too, were obviously negotiated with a degree of good faith. They offered much promise, but the promise went unrealised. Perhaps a delay might have proved better in terms of bringing the parties together at Arawa. Perhaps the PNGDF could have exercised greater discipline and understood more reasonably and comprehensively that its role had changed.

Certainly the Bougainville Revolutionary Army should have come in to talk. Safe conduct was guaranteed; safe passage was organised. Even a helicopter was suggested at one stage to guarantee the BRA's leadership safe passage to and from the talks. These are all issues which, doubtless, historians will canvass in the future. I place on record this afternoon that I am very troubled by the allegations of incidents over the past week or so. I am very disturbed by the killings and claims of killings on both Bougainville and Buka that are understood to have occurred over the past few days.

Sir Julius Chan has demonstrated that he is dedicated to the process of peace. In my view, Sir Julius is an outstanding Prime Minister of Papua New Guinea. He is committed to finding a solution, and he is prepared to go the distance.

Despite the failure of the last several days, the cease-fire on Bougainville must be maintained. Senator Gareth Evans was absolutely correct in focusing on that. The island cannot be permitted by either side to slide back into turmoil, conflict and killing. That would simply compound the tragedy and turn the tragedy into an absolute catastrophe.

A few days ago I was visited in this place by Ms Ruby Mirenka, courtesy of Community Aid Abroad. Ms Mirenka had come from behind the blockade maintained by PNGDF in part on Bougainville to talk with people in public life here in government and the parliament about the cost in human terms of the civil war; the cost to ordinary Bougainvilleans, particularly the children. Just as our parliamentary delegation in April saw directly the costs in terms of the areas that we visited across the island, Ms Mirenka was able to describe in very graphic terms what had happened behind the blockade and to show through photographic evidence just what the cost had been to ordinary Bougainvilleans and their families. The photographs of children in pain because they were lacking in the most basic medical support were just heart rending.

There is no doubt from the conversation which I had with Ms Mirenka that behind the blockade the desire is for peace and a return to harmony and normalcy. It may be that on both sides of the blockade people can push the leaders to a resumption of the talks.

The ADF role under Brigadier Peter Abigail has been outstanding. Our participation, along with that of our colleagues from the neighbouring countries of Fiji, Vanuatu, Tonga and New Zealand, has been very purposeful. I compliment the foreign minister for staying the distance. Australia must stay the distance for the future. I call upon everyone involved in this dispute to maintain the contact, to endeavour to maintain the momentum for discussions, to maintain the cease-fire and to look to a neutral place for a resumption of talks—perhaps on our shores.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to support the remarks made by Senator Loosley. I know how strongly he feels about the matter. I can say that I share his views and I know the coalition does, too. In fact, our shadow minister for foreign affairs, Peter Reith, has already issued a statement on this matter.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Loosley said, we are naturally very disappointed that the talks have broken down. I wonder just how committed Sam Kauona and Francis Ona are. Obviously they are very brave men. They have proved that by leading a guerilla army. They have used the excuse that they were too frightened to come in and sit down to talks. Perhaps they should have thought about the people that Senator Loosley talked about—the women and children on the island.

The fact that the women were the ones who went back to the villages and tried to get these rebels to come in and sit down to talk reinforces what we saw on the ground. It is the women and children who are suffering. The women are the ones who want this war to finish. They can see what the long-term effects of the destruction will be for them and their children.

What impressed me the most when the delegation visited Bougainville was that the women were the most concerned. The women demonstrated quite openly to us that they were the ones who wanted to go back to their villages. They wanted peace. Sure, the men felt the same way but, as we all know from Bougainville's culture, the women are the

SPEECH.PARA: ones who set the scene. It was brought home to us very strongly when we went through the refugee camps and saw the conditions that people were living under that it is the women and children who are suffering. The longer this civil war continues, the longer it will take to get some normalcy back into the system.

PARA.TAB: I, too, would like to say how impressed I am with Sir Julius Chan. Meeting the man, listening and talking to him, as the delegation did, left no doubt in my mind that he is committed wholeheartedly to peace. It is just a pity that the years of fighting and division on Bougainville seem to have placed the Bougainville rebels in a position where they are either too frightened or too suspicious to come forward to sit down and talk.

I think all Australians would urge the Australian government to intensify its efforts, if possible, to get them back to the conference table and, by whatever means, to try and impress upon the BRA that they should sit down and that the cease-fire must hold. I know that our ambassador in PNG, Bill Farmer, would be expressing our concern to Sir Julius.

Australian politicians used to have a very strong relationship with PNG, probably because of the travel arrangements that existed at that time. I am being very open about this. We could fly to PNG on our normal parliamentary allowance. The fact that it is now classed as an overseas trip perhaps encourages people to go further. I believe that in those days there was a much closer relationship between the PNG government and the Australian parliament. I hope that we can return to something like that position.

The catalyst might be the building of our new chancery, to which the government, through the Public Works Committee, has committed $22 million. It may provide the opportunity for some politicians to travel to PNG again and re-open discussions and continue those friendships from the past. Like Senator Loosley, I hope that people will get back to the table very quickly and continue the peace efforts.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht), to a question without notice asked by the Leader of the National Party in the Senate (Senator BosweIl) this day, relating to drought assistance to small business.

SPEECH.PARA: I regret that Senator Schacht has again shown no compassion for or understanding whatsoever of the way that small businessmen are being affected by the drought. I have been raising this matter for a couple of months, asking this government to seriously consider the impact of the effects of drought upon small business. Senator Schacht mused as to why no-one, apart from Senator Boswell, would ask him a question. I am surprised that Senator Boswell even asked him a question because one always gets a complete non-answer from Senator Schacht.

PARA.TAB: The other day Senator Schacht was completely caught out when he could not even answer a dorothy dixer question that he wrote for himself. It is no wonder that Senator Schacht is not asked any questions about small business.

I regret that he is not in the chamber, because I do not like doing this in his absence. But he is a minister of the Crown and he should put in an appearance in the chamber every now and again to do what he is paid to do and make a contribution to this house. As with most things, Senator Schacht simply does not have the understanding or the competence to realise what small business needs and what affects it.

Senator Schacht's only experience in small business was in turning the Labor Party in South Australia from a big business into a very small one. It is again no surprise to me or to anyone in this chamber why he is struggling to maintain his preselection.

There are a number of issues in relation to small business in drought affected areas that the chamber should be aware of. The president of the Queensland Retailers Association has confirmed that many small businesses in rural Australia are suffering. He quotes the instance of five businesses that have gone out of operation because of the drought, and they are, in many instances, carrying debts of up to $150,000 because they extended credit to farmers when the banks would not and when this government was too lousy to look at the question of drought relief when it should have.

It has not been a question of whether the drought started on 1 July or any other date; it has been creeping up. The government has been warned, but chose to ignore it completely until very recent times. As a result of that, these small businessmen are having great difficulty in continuing to operate. The tragedy of that for regional Australia is that many of these businesses will not reopen when the drought breaks. They have been forced out of small communities, they will not reopen, and it simply means that another one of the small communities in Australia's regional areas fades into history. Senator Schacht has no interest in that. He does not understand in any way what small business needs to do. I know that Senator Robert Ray thinks this is all a bit of a joke.

TALK.START.PARA: —No; I think you are a joke.

—There he goes again—just mouthing off. He is not at all interested in the real effects of the drought on small business. It is typical of the Labor Party. All Senator Ray can do is shout abuse across the table. He is not at all interested in the plight of small businessmen and it is typical of the Labor government.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan), to a question without notice asked by Senator Coulter on 12 October week, relating to blood supply products distributed by the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cook said today that an indemnity had indeed been given with respect to the documents covering the sale of CSL and that that indemnity covered plasma which had been mixed from sources from Australia and, in this case, from Papua New Guinea. The background to the question is that, while the incidence of hepatitis infection in Australia in the general community is about one in 500, the incidence of hepatitis infection among those who have received CSL products and are suffering from haemophilia is over 80 per cent. Over 80 per cent of the 1,600 haemophilia sufferers are so infected.

PARA.TAB: The relevance of this to CSL lies in two observations. One is that there is on the record—and I have already drawn attention to this—a letter from CSL dated 1986 in which CSL admits that it was mixing plasma not only from Australia and New Zealand but also from Papua New Guinea, from Pacific islands and from South-East Asia. So concerned was the Australian Red Cross about this practice that the Australian Red Cross wrote to CSL asking it to desist from this practice. The Red Cross had had legal advice that it could not therefore guarantee the safety of CSL products, which the Red Cross itself was then using to treat patients with a variety of diseases, including haemophilia.

CSL refused to comply with the request from the Red Cross and continued with the practice—as far as we are aware—until December 1992. There is a letter in existence—to which I have also drawn attention—in which the Red Cross said that it would therefore, on legal advice, refuse to continue with the use of CSL products.

The minister has replied that the government gave an indemnity to the purchasers of CSL, when CSL was privatised, with respect to plasma from Papua New Guinea but not from these other countries. Also, the prospectus did not, when CSL was sold, give any information to prospective buyers of CSL shares that CSL had been mixing plasma from these other sources.

The other bit of information relevant here is that there is considerable evidence that plasma from Hong Kong was heavily contaminated with hepatitis C and that the pooled plasma from Hong Kong was not tested for it. As CSL said, hepatitis C infection was endemic in Hong Kong, so it assumed that all the blood plasma would be contaminated. But donors of blood in Hong Kong were not tested before the samples were taken. Here we have a clear link between the mixing of these plasmas by CSL and the real possibility that the infection rate is so high in haemophilia sufferers in Australia because they have been treated with a contaminated CSL product.

I conclude by pointing out that, although this information is in the record as a result of the two questions I have asked and the two short speeches I have made taking note of answers, the media seem rather uninterested in taking up this matter. It seems that either the government or CSL or both are attempting to disparage the status of Catherine Beauchamp, the author of Red Alert, by spreading stories that she is against blood transfusions, which she is not, or that she has fabricated the letters to which I have drawn attention, which I believe she has not. It seems that the government or CSL or both are very worried about the effect of these revelations on the possible value of CSL.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for the debate has expired.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Women: Pension Age
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned strongly opposes attempts by the government to raise the pension age for women from 60 to 65 years.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate take action to reject this proposed change.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Kernot (from 104 citizens) and Senator Lees (from 154 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate the need for changes to the Family Law Act of Australia and to the child support scheme.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate support the following changes.

PETITION.PARA: (1)That the existing Family Law Act be scrapped and replaced by a more simplified version together with the minimum of rules and regulations necessary.

(2)That the Family Court be replaced by a Tribunal and that all matters resulting from divorce and family breakdown be heard before, and determined by a panel; the panel to be made up of persons qualified in matters arising from family breakdown.
(3)That legal professionals be barred from appearing before the Tribunal resulting in vast savings to the disputing parties.
(4)That a modified fault clause be re-introduced to Family Law primarily designed to discourage adultery and to stop rewarding adulterers at the expense of deserted and innocent parties.
(5)That the Child Support Agency be scrapped and replaced by an appropriate administrative procedure within the Tribunal.
(6)That apart from cases of exceptional circumstances parental-child access become the inalienable right of all parents.

(7)That alternative counselling, (Government funded) be made available through the Churches and that much more emphasis be placed on mediation in resolving disputes prior to the commencement of legal proceedings.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Kernot (from 172 citizens) and Senator MacGibbon (from 2,105 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Woodchip Licences
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:

PARA.TAB: Australia's old growth forest and wilderness areas are being diminished as a result of continued logging. The Federal Government has granted new woodchip export licences despite its agreement for a moratorium on logging in high conservation areas.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should:

PETITION.PARA: apply conditions retrospectively to woodchip licences in order to meet Commonwealth obligations, and
exclude from licences, woodchip derived from old growth forests and wilderness areas.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia asks that the Childcare Rebate Act 1993 and the Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Act 1993 be amended with the application of common principles. To ensure that all parents with dependent children are treated equally, allowing maximum freedom of choice in child rearing.
These Acts need to be amended to take account of:

PETITION.PARA: 1.the fact that 60% of married women in the workforce who have children, would prefer to stay at home and mind their children, but for economic reasons can't afford to (Institute of Family Studies Survey).
2.the failure to provide for equitable choice for women and families in allowing parents the maximum right to choose the most appropriate form of care for their children.
3.that there be recognition of a parent at home as a formal occupation reflecting its economic value and worth to society.

Dear Senator Colston
Thank you for your letter of 25 August 1994 concerning the Training Guarantee (Administration) Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1994 No 176.

The Regulations remove the application of the Training Guarantee from Zone A of the Timor Gap. The Australia-Indonesia Zone of Co-operation Treaty deals with the development of petroleum resources in the disputed waters between Australia and Indonesia. The Zone of Co-operation is divided into three areas. The area in question, Zone A, is under joint Australian/Indonesian control. Zone B is under Australian control and Zone C under Indonesian control.

The Treaty requires agreement between Australia and Indonesia over the introduction of any new taxes in Zone A. The regulations in question became necessary in July 1993 when the Indonesian Government advised that it did not agree to the application of the Training Guarantee in that Zone. Because the Training Guarantee should not have been introduced in the Zone without Indonesian agreement, it was necessary to make the regulations retrospective to remove its application right back to the Training Guarantee's introduction on 1 July 1990.

At this stage, there are a few exploration companies operating in the area. Some are small companies while others are part of much larger oil companies. Enquiries made before the discussions with the Indonesians indicate that both types employ skilled personnel and provide much more training than is required under the Training Guarantee. Therefore, it is extremely unlikely that any of them would have lodged training guarantee shortfall statements or that there will be any requests for repayment.
I hope the above satisfies the Committee's concerns.
Yours sincerely
Ross Free

The Hon Michael Lavarch MP

Dear Minister
I refer to the Classification of Publications (Amendment) Ordinance, ACT Ordinance No 5 of 1994, considered by the Committee at its meeting of 25 August 1994.

Section 28AB of the principal Ordinance is amended to impose a nine years retrospective liability to pay an application fee of $50, with any such payments made since that date taken to discharge that liability. The Explanatory Statement gives the background and reasons for the amendments. Also, the retrospectivity appears to be valid under the parent Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910. The Committee would appreciate your advice, however, on the legislative and administrative considerations which dictated the retrospectivity liability and the apparent simultaneous discharge of that liability. In particular, in the absence of this retrospectivity would any fees paid between 1 April 1985 and 22 June 1994 have to be refunded? If so, could you advise the Committee of the amounts involved?
Yours sincerely

Chairman
20 September 1994
Senator Mal Colston
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
Canberra ACT 2600
Dear Senator Colston
I refer to your letter of 25 August 1994 concerning the Classification of Publications (Amendment) Ordinance (No. 3) 1994 (the amending Ordinance).

As you note, the amending Ordinance provides, in part, for the retrospective liability to pay a fee for an application to review a decision approving or refusing to approve the classification of a film or advertising matter in relation to a film. It also provides that any payment made during the relevant period (1 April 1985 to 22 June 1994) is to be taken to have been made in discharge of that liability.
The Committee has sought my advice on the legislative and administrative considerations which dictated the retrospective liability and the apparent simultaneous discharge of that liability.

An application to review a decision of the kind referred to above is made under State and Territory legislation. As noted in the Explanatory Statement for the amending Ordinance, the Commonwealth, States and Territories agreed that an application fee of $400 to review a decision would be charged from 1985. This was to be comprised of a fee of $50 levied under the legislation of each of the 8 States and Territories involved.

The fee is a fee for service. Further, the fees collected represent only a nominal contribution to the cost of providing the service. It is an `up-front' fee, that is, the fee is payable before an application for review can be dealt with.

On being made aware of the failure to make a fee determination in 1985 to give effect to the Ministers' decision in respect of the ACT component, the Government was clearly required to take action to redress the problem. It was considered that the most appropriate course of action in the circumstances was to adopt a direct approach and to legislate to rectify the problem. This course was not taken lightly in view of the undesirability, as a general rule, of retrospective legislation—which is reflected in the strict approach that the Committee adopts in relation to such provisions.

This decision was taken in the context that the fee retrospectively levied was the fee agreed upon by the Commonwealth, States and Territories when the fee was introduced in 1985, that it had been collected in good faith and that the services to which the fee relates have been delivered.

There was, of course, never any intention to levy, retrospectively, a higher fee than that previously agreed upon and collected. This is reflected in the amendment itself which immediately after levying the fee retrospectively, then discharges that liability on the basis of payment of the fee having already been made.

The Committee also asks whether in the absence of the retrospectivity any fees paid during the relevant period would have had to be refunded. The short answer to this is that a person who had paid the fee would generally have been able to bring an action to recover it, but that in the absence of any claim the Commonwealth was not under any legal obligation to repay the fee.

In relation to the Committee's question about the amounts involved, the Office of Film and Literature Classification have informed me that, according to its records, 23 applications were involved during the relevant period. The Principal Ordinance, of course, only relates to films (usually video tapes) for sale or hire. The ACT component of the total fee applicable would thus have been $1350.
Please let me know if I can be of any further assistance to the Committee in this matter.
Yours sincerely
Michael Lavarch

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General:

PARA.TAB: Australian National Audit Office—Annual Report for 1993-94.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The parliament is the body to which the Auditor-General is responsible, not the government. As a result, any damage done to the capacity of the Auditor-General to fulfil his tasks on behalf of the parliament is naturally a major cause for concern. That is why, of course, the scandalous diversion of the scarce resources of the Auditor-General into the Centenary House fiasco is obviously a matter of major significance. It is welcome to see that that matter should be resolved towards the end of this month. The Auditor-General notes in this report:
As a result of sustained criticism of the circumstances surrounding the ANAO's accommodation in Centenary House, Canberra—
which, of course, is owned by the Australian Labor Party, although that was not known at the time the Auditor-General became the tenant—

TALK.START.PARA: —Read that as `inquiry'.
—I do not think it is a matter of dissension in the inquiry, as I understand it. The Auditor-General went on:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I endeavoured to establish an independent inquiry into the matter.

In the event, a Judicial Inquiry was established by the Government to examine all aspects of the leasing arrangements. Mr Trevor Morling, QC, was appointed in May 1994 to conduct the Inquiry under the Royal Commissions Act. Mr Morling's report is expected to be finalised towards the end of October 1994, and I am looking forward to this putting an end to the controversy surrounding the issue. I also look forward to the Government's review of the level of ANAO's resources following the outcome of the Inquiry.

That is the central issue. The rental arrangement—and this is not a matter of dispute before the inquiry—would have been such as to severely damage the viability of the Auditor-General's office because of the huge rent rise of something like nine per cent per annum that would have flowed from the Auditor-General to the Australian Labor Party.

PARA.TAB: It is in that context that the Auditor-General is saying in this report that the next few months represent a crucial period for the Audit Office, not only because of the Centenary House matter and whether or not the government will make good the extraordinary loss of funds that would flow from payment of that lease if that lease survives, but also because of the expected passage of the legislation to replace the Audit Act 1901, along with the conclusion of the Audit Office's restructuring. That is still, the Auditor-General says, inhibited by an order of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission relating to that restructuring and, as I said, the finalisation of the Centenary House inquiry.

The Auditor-General goes on to say that he is greatly encouraged by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts support for providing the Auditor-General with the authority to set his own terms and conditions of staff of the Audit Office and for the establishment of an audit committee of the parliament. I might say in passing that I regret that the JCPA has backed down a little from the position that it had taken on the issue. But the Auditor-General says:

SPEECH.PARA: With these important building blocks, the prospect of a long-term improvement in the ANAO's funding position, and the continuing commitment and professionalism of all the staff of the ANAO, I am cautiously optimistic that the ANAO will continue to provide the Parliament, the Executive and the community with a valued service well into the future.
The important part of his report was contained in the following passage:
It is now up to the Parliament to decide what it, rather than the Government or its agencies, wants from the Auditor-General and the ANAO.

That is the central issue. As a member of parliament, I have found the Auditor-General's reports to be an essential element in the proper performance of my functions as someone who is keen to ensure that there is detailed and effective scrutiny of the activities of this government. Heaven knows, this government needs that kind of detailed and effective scrutiny.

PARA.TAB: The Auditor-General has been fearless in his criticisms. The government finds some of those criticisms unacceptable. As the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) mentioned today, some of those criticisms generate some disagreement on quite reasonable grounds. There is no doubt, however, that the Auditor-General and his office have shown themselves to be a diligent servant of this parliament.

As he notes in his own report, the quality of the audits has improved markedly—and I endorse this view—in the area of the two core products of financial audits and performance audits. The Auditor-General gives credit for that to the enormous commitment, dedication and goodwill of staff which has enabled the Audit Office to come through the challenging period of recent times very well. He says, as I accept:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . and our performance audits have become more focused and better targeted as a result of improved liaison with both the Parliament and auditees.

I want to deal briefly with that question about his reporting to the parliament. The highlights of this report are to the effect that, of the 430 audit opinions on the financial statements processed for 1993-94, 393 were unqualified, leaving 37 qualified. The ANOA report goes on to say:

More than 1,000 recommendations were made to Ministers, boards and/or senior management for better collection and payment of public moneys, the protection of assets and improvements in financial management.
Technical standards have been further enhanced and relations with auditees have been strengthened despite a period of staff shortages and budgetary constraints.
Contracting has continued to be used to provide specialised skills and to assist the Audit Office with peak workloads.
On the other aspect of the Auditor-General's activities, which is in performance audits, as the Auditor-General says:
The year has produced a number of highlights, marked by an increased awareness and use by the Parliament of the Auditor-General's audit reports.

Audit reports tabled during the year covered a wide range of public administrative issues. Resulting recommendations have focused on improving the administration of public sector entities and encouraging the ongoing development of good management and public accountability.

In 1993-94, 66 performance audits were tabled. If recommendations in these reports are implemented, the ANAO estimates there will be potential savings of $16m initially plus ongoing savings of up to $59m per year.
As a member of this Senate, I commend the Auditor-General for his efforts and I welcome his annual report for 1993-94.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would like to comment briefly on the Auditor-General's annual report, or the annual report of the Australian National Audit Office for 1993-94. At the outset I wish to congratulate the Auditor-General, Mr Taylor, and his staff on what I think has been an extraordinarily good and productive year under very difficult circumstances which, as he says in the opening line, has been a year of marked contrasts.

PARA.TAB: I put on the record my appreciation—and I am sure I speak for the whole of the coalition—of the work of John Taylor as Auditor-General. I think I am right in saying that he retires early next year. So I understand that this annual report will be the last annual report produced by the Audit Office with John Taylor as the Auditor-General. He has been a remarkable Auditor-General. He has shown an independence of spirit, initiative and courage that are very rare in public office, particularly when one is as exposed to criticisms as an Auditor-General is in public office. We owe John Taylor and his very supportive staff a great debt of gratitude.

As my friend Senator Michael Baume said, we on this side of the parliament—and I hope all members of parliament—find the reports of the Auditor-General and the Audit Office of enormous help. Indeed, as an opposition it would be very difficult to do our work effectively without those reports. That is an essential part of the role of the Audit Office and the Auditor-General. As he says at page 3 of his annual report at paragraph 1.7:

The Auditor-General has a central place in the process of public accountability. The Executive is accountable to the Parliament, and through the Parliament to the community, for the stewardship of the resources the Parliament has provided to it. Ministers are accountable to the Parliament, although the extent of that accountability varies in the case of statutory authorities and government-owned or controlled companies.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me interpose there that far too often in our system of government, and particularly under the Hawke and Keating governments of the past 11 years, there has been far too little recognition by ministers of the fact that they are accountable to the parliament and to the public and that they are not a law unto themselves, as we have seen far too often apparently to be the case. We are seeing that at the moment with the performance of Minister Brereton in his roles in industrial relations and also in transport.

PARA.TAB: In his report, the Auditor-General draws attention to the fact that some of the recommendations of audit reports that were made in 1993-94, which were aimed at improving public administration, have largely been accepted by the agencies that were subject to review. It is commendable that in 1993-94 those reports included recommendations for savings in budget outlays totalling no less than $75 million, including ongoing savings of $59 million per annum. That is a notable achievement and one which I am sure the Audit Office will continue to build on in the future.
In his annual report, the Auditor-General states:

SPEECH.PARA: The existing inflexible and insufficient funding arrangements do not allow the ANAO to operate on an appropriate basis, let alone identify potential savings which may be shared with the staff.

I believe that is an enormous indictment of the government. For the government to have to starve such an essential body of funds and to have such inflexibility in terms of the funding arrangements, when the Audit Office is the watchdog of the public purse, I find extraordinary and very much regrettable. It should be welcomed that the government has announced that it will review the funding for the ANAO, following the outcome of the inquiry into Centenary House—one can only hope. I urge the government to look very carefully at providing greater flexibility and adequacy of funding to the Audit Office in the course of and as a result of that review.

PARA.TAB: It is regrettable that the government has to wait until the completion of the inquiry into the Audit Office's accommodation in Centenary House. I think that is one of the less respectable events of recent times. So far as accommodation of government departments and agencies is concerned, the fact that the Audit Office took the accommodation in Centenary House without its being revealed that the owner of the building was the Australian Labor Party is, I believe, a disgraceful omission on the part of the government departments concerned. It is there that the criticism lies, rather than with the Audit Office.

I guess the inquiry will look at all of those matters, and I would not pretend to pre-empt that inquiry. But the fact of the Audit Office being accommodated in the building owned by a political party is something that everyone hopefully—certainly on this side of politics, and I am sure the Audit Office itself—regards as unsatisfactory. It is worth noting that the Auditor-General himself endeavoured to establish an independent inquiry into this matter. In the event, of course, a judicial inquiry was established by the government to examine all aspects of the leasing arrangements, but I think it should be on the record that the Auditor-General himself endeavoured to establish an independent inquiry into the matter.

I wish to draw attention to the fact that we have had an incredible five-year delay on the part of this government in the introduction of the promised legislation to replace the Audit Act 1901. There has been the Joint Statutory Committee on Public Accounts report on the necessary and desirable changes to the Audit Act and the whole of the legislative basis for the Audit Office. It has been there for five years. The government promised three or four years ago, at least—I remember I was involved in estimates committees on it at the time—to introduce that legislation. I think the earliest commitment on the government's part was something like three years ago. The date kept slipping and slipping, not just by weeks or by months, but by years. Fortunately, at last we have had legislation introduced, and I hope that it will be the basis of and the underpinning for the stability and the future development in desirable ways of the Audit Office.

The role of the Audit Office is particularly important. It has some very important tasks at hand at the moment, not the least of which is the inquiry it is undertaking at the behest and request of this chamber to enable the parliament and the public to make an informed assessment of the Australian National Line's financial position. It is a financial situation which we have seen under this government, particularly the handling by it of the present minister, go into an absolutely disgraceful state over recent months.

The government and Minister Brereton, the Minister for Industrial Relations, have acted in a way which has greatly damaged the ANL. It has greatly damaged the value of the ANL at a time when the government itself was trying to privatise the shipping line with the coalition's support. The government has bowed to the muscle of the maritime union in a way which has caused great damage to the line and the shipping industry in Australia. The financial implications of that are very grave indeed, and I and the coalition look forward very much to the Auditor-General's report into some of those matters. I believe and hope that it will provide a basis for this parliament to have an assessment of the activities of ANL and of this government, particularly this current minister in relation to ANL. That is essential in the public interest.

I am pleased to welcome the report for 1993-94 of the Australian National Audit Office. I commend the office and the Auditor-General on the work that they have done. I look forward to seeing a continuation of that on behalf of not just the parliament but the Australian people in the years ahead.

SPEECH.PARA: SOCIAL SECURITY (1994 BUDGET AND WHITE PAPER) AMENDMENT BILL 1994
This bill introduces a range of important reforms in the social security portfolio, stemming primarily from the 1994 budget and the government's 1994 white paper on employment and growth.

The white paper has provided a valuable opportunity for a fundamental review of the income support system for unemployed people. The current system has been outpaced by social and labour market changes and the changing structure of employment—changes such as a higher incidence of long term unemployment, greater participation by women in the workforce, increasing part-time and casual work and a decreasing gap between low wages and income support. The income support changes made in this bill are among those that will make the unemployment system responsive to the realities of the labour market of the 1990s. Further measures contained in the white paper will be included in social security legislation to be introduced later in these Sittings.

Changes to commence in March 1995 will broaden the range of work-related options that the long term unemployed, and those at risk of becoming long term unemployed, can pursue while continuing to receive income support. These options will include developing and participating in group or co-operative enterprises, more courses of study and training approved by the Commonwealth Employment Service, and a wider range of voluntary unpaid work such as on environmental projects or community and cultural activities. Also, eligible clients will be able to continue to receive income support for up to 12 months while developing self-employment opportunities.

A further important reform is the introduction of two advance payment options for eligible job search and newstart allowance clients. After 3 months on payment, clients will have access to an up-front lump sum payment of up to $500 to assist in job search and other activities related to finding paid employment. For the long term unemployed, and those at risk of becoming long term unemployed, there is an option to take an advance of their income support of up to $1,000 for activities approved by their case manager as assisting their return to work and included in the client's Job Search or Newstart Activity Agreement. In either case, the proportion of payments to be advanced will be limited to 14 per cent of the rate of allowance (not including remote area allowance). The period over which future payments may be advanced will be up to 6 months for the $500 option and 12 months for the $1,000 option. The remaining fortnightly payment will be paid in the usual way. There will be no interest charged and advances will be available only to clients who can show that they have the ability to manage their finances while taking up this option.

To qualify for job search or newstart allowance, a client must satisfy the secretary that he or she is taking reasonable steps to comply with the terms of a Job Search or Newstart Activity Agreement. It is also generally necessary to satisfy the activity test either by actively seeking and being willing to undertake paid work that is, in the secretary's opinion, suitable for the person, or by taking reasonable steps to comply with a requirement to undertake certain activity. There have been broadly varying decisions made about what constitutes suitable work and what steps are reasonable. As a result, the application of the legislation has lacked uniformity and has caused confusion for clients.

This bill rectifies this inconsistency by codifying the suitable work and reasonable steps issues. In future, the emphasis will be altered to create a presumption that any paid work is suitable unless the secretary forms the opinion that it is unsuitable for the person. A range of circumstances will be prescribed to establish that the work is unsuitable such as the client lacking the requisite skills, experience or qualifications for the job, the existence of a pre-existing illness or injury that would be aggravated by the conditions of work and the wages of a job not covered by an existing award being below the minimum rate for comparable work.

The reasonable steps issue will be addressed by a new provision that deems a client not to have taken reasonable steps to comply with the activity test or the terms of a Job Search or Newstart Activity Agreement. This will apply if the main reason for failing to comply involves a matter that is within the control of the client or if the circumstances which prevented the client from complying were reasonably foreseeable by the client.

This bill makes the job search, newstart and sickness allowance liquid assets test more equitable. This test is essentially a deferral of payment to a client whose "liquid assets" (that is, cash and readily realisable assets) exceed established thresholds. First, the liquid assets waiting period will apply to clients only once in any 12 month period instead of each time a claim is made. Secondly, allowance will be made for a client's liquid assets to be reduced by any one-off lump sum payment of non-housing related debts such as clearance of a car loan. Also, the proceeds of the sale of the client's home may be deducted as long as settlement occurred in the last 12 months and the money is to be used to buy another home. Lastly, avoidance of the liquid assets test will be prevented by having it apply to both the client and their partner.

This bill relaxes the residence requirements for refugees applying for certain social security pensions. The qualification criteria for most pensions require a period of qualifying residence or a continuous period of being an Australian resident. As a result, refugees cannot qualify for most pension payments. It will now be possible for refugees to satisfy the residence requirements as long as they reside in Australia and hold a class of visa approved by the Minister for Social Security. Provided that other qualification criteria are satisfied, refugees will have access to Australian pensions.

More equity is being introduced into the payment of additional family payment outside Australia. At present, additional family payment can continue to be paid for up to 13 weeks if the qualified person is absent from Australia as long as the child remains in Australia with the other parent. The unintended effect of this on sole parents is that they lose additional family payment as soon as they leave Australia because they have no partner in Australia to care for the child. In the case of a couple, it also precludes payment of additional family payment if both parents leave Australia. This restriction is being relaxed to allow for additional family payment to continue to be paid for up to 13 weeks to a qualified person who is outside Australia, whether or not the person has a partner who remains in Australia with the child. It will still be a requirement that the child remain in Australia.

This bill closes a loophole in the provisions that allow the value of certain employer provided fringe benefits to be taken into account under the family payment income test and the parental income test for job search and sickness allowance recipients aged under 18. Some employees may be paid rental or mortgage subsidy payments that are not captured by the fringe benefit provisions in the Social Security Act because they are cash payments. Amendments are now being made that will result in these payments being treated as income for the relevant income tests if the payments made by an employer to an employee are to assist the employee to meet costs associated with a housing loan or rental payments. However, this bill also includes special measures for Defence Force members so that low cost housing or a housing rental payment are given a lower fringe benefits value.
The Social Security Act contains definitions that refer to certain sections in the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 relating to the calculation of an undeducted purchase price (UPP).

Amendments to these social security definitions are necessary in the light of recent amendments made to the calculation of UPPs under the Tax Act. They will ensure that there is not an unintended tightening of the income test treatment of pensions and annuities taken out on or after 1 July 1994. That is, the status quo will remain for social security purposes. This will be achieved by applying the pre-1 July 1994 income tax definition of UPP for social security purposes so that social security clients with superannuation investment products purchased with eligible termination payments will be treated the same irrespective of when they purchased these products.
I commend the bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum.
SOCIAL SECURITY (NEW ZEALAND AGREEMENT) AMENDMENT BILL 1994

The Social Security (New Zealand Agreement) Amendment Bill 1994 provides for the incorporation into the Social Security Act 1991 of the new social security agreement that was signed by Australia and New Zealand on 19 July 1994.

In 1943, Australia and New Zealand signed a `host country' Social Security Agreement under which each country agreed to pay pensions to residents who had come from the other country. Reimbursement arrangements have gradually been introduced to ensure that the arrangement can withstand imbalances in migration patterns between the countries. During the latter part of the 1980s there was a significant net intake of New Zealanders into Australia.

The new Agreement takes account of the ease with which people may travel between Australia and New Zealand. It means that neither country will suddenly face an excessive burden in paying pensions to people who have spent most or all of their working lives in the other country.

Under the new agreement, New Zealand will reimburse Australia for pensions paid to people from New Zealand with less than 10 years residence in Australia during their working life. Australia will similarly reimburse New Zealand for the pensions it pays to people from Australia. The level of reimbursement in these cases will be based broadly on the percentage of a person's working life spent in each country.

The new Agreement provides a far more equitable sharing of the cost of pensions paid to people who move between Australia and New Zealand. These new cost sharing arrangements are to begin from 1 January 1995, the date the new Agreement comes into effect and will cover all new arrivals from that date. The arrangements will be phased in over five years for people who arrived after 1 January 1983.
Reimbursements by New Zealand to Australia are likely to triple over the next three years and then rise to around $90 million a year as arrangements are phased in under the new agreement.
The Agreement does not cover reimbursement for benefits to the unemployed or family allowances. These benefits are not normally included in the scope of cost-sharing agreements.
I commend the bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1994 is to ensure that asylum seekers who have had access to the refugee determination processes in another country should not have access to Australia's system other than in exceptional circumstances. The bill covers two groups of asylum seekers. The first are those covered by the comprehensive plan of action, the CPA, which the Australian government signed in July 1989. The second are those in relation to which there is a safe third country, which I will refer to as STC. This STC concept is new to our onshore refugee screening procedures, and I will come back to it in more detail later in my remarks.

PARA.TAB: The coalition, after very wide consultation, has decided to support the bill. However, we believe there are some amendments which should be made to remove some areas of concern. Most of the concerns were raised over the application of the safe third country concept. After careful consideration of the bill, we consider that further improvements and safeguards can be made which, rather than changing the nature or spirit of the legislation, with which the coalition agrees, would enhance its operation and better ensure its fairness, equity and transparency. I will also be moving an amendment to the second reading motion which addresses other legitimate concerns that have been expressed.

It cannot be denied that the asylum seekers covered by this bill are effectively attempting to jump the queue. In most of their cases they have failed to accept the decision of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees-supervised screening processes in another country and have come to Australia seeking a second try. This has been called `forum shopping'. To allow such asylum seekers access to our protection would be to discriminate against other legitimate asylum seekers who are following the normal processes of application and assessment. We believe this is unfair and should not be permitted.

If this bill were defeated there is every likelihood that it would encourage more boat people who have had their applications for asylum rejected, in accordance with the proper procedures of the comprehensive plan of action, to make their way to Australia's shores as unauthorised boat arrivals—or, in the parlance of the new Migration Act, as illegal non-citizens—to seek another opportunity to apply for asylum. This would not only undermine the comprehensive plan of action but also put additional pressures on Australia's refugee program and its processing. With many tens of thousands of people in refugee camps throughout Asia alone, let alone in other troubled areas of the world, this would be of major concern.

The measures contained in this bill have their roots in the refugee situation in the late 1970s and 1980s, when thousands of people fled their home countries, in particular Vietnam and Laos. Many finished up in camps in Thailand, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Malaysia and the Philippines. Until the late 1980s, countries of first asylum accepted the arrivals and other countries, including in particular Australia, accepted substantial numbers for permanent resettlement without any great formality or problems.

I might say that I take very great pleasure and pride in being a member of the political party and government—the Liberal Party and the Fraser Liberal-National Party coalition government of the second half of the 1970s—that were responsible, despite strong opposition from various quarters, including, I must say, the Labor Party at that time, for the initial welcoming to Australia of the Vietnamese refugees and the other Indochinese refugees who were desperately seeking new homes for resettlement at that time.

However, pressures built up in the late 1980s, particularly with respect to the huge number of boat people who fled to Hong Kong. In July 1989 an international conference on Indochinese refugees was held in Geneva. The major result of the conference was a comprehensive plan of action to apply to Vietnamese and Lao people who arrived in first asylum countries after the cut-off date, which ranged from June 1988 through to March 1989, depending on the country concerned.

Under the CPA, the first step in the procedure is to determine whether the person is a refugee or not. In other words, the previous virtually automatic assumption of refugee status was revoked. This is determined in accordance with the United Nations 1951 convention relating to the status of refugees and its 1967 protocol. The CPA provides that the UNHCR, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, is to be involved in the determination process and that the UN handbook on procedures and criteria for determining refugee status is to be the authoritative guide to determining a person's status. The CPA also provides for consistent region-wide refugee status decision making. One of the principles of the CPA was that, in accordance with article 33 of the United Nations 1951 convention:

SPEECH.PARA: No Contracting State shall expel or return—
the international word being `refouler'—

a refugee in any manner whatsoever to the frontiers of territories where his life or freedom would be threatened on account of his race, religion, nationality, membership of a particular social group or political opinion.
Article 33 basically ensures that applicants for asylum will not be returned to their country of origin without having their claim for refugee status assessed.

PARA.TAB: The CPA was adopted in 1989 by the UNHCR, by the governments of countries from where the refugees originated, namely, Vietnam and Laos, by the countries or territories which offered first asylum to the boat people, namely, Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia, Hong Kong and the Philippines, and by countries offering resettlement, including in particular Australia, whose record in this respect is admirable on a world basis.

The CPA ensured that Vietnamese and Laotian asylum seekers were given first asylum and were screened for refugee status. Those determined to be refugees were eligible for resettlement. Those determined not to be refugees had to return to their country of origin.

Some allegations have been raised about the UNHCR's processing of refugees in accordance with the CPA at the Galang camp in Indonesia by members of the Vietnamese Australian community. They allege that the screening procedures in Galang have been corrupted and that many non-refugees were either buying refugee status or gaining it through sexual favours and the like.

This bill has been subject to inquiry by the Senate's legal and constitutional affairs committee, which recommended that the bill be enacted. In the course of the inquiry, the UNHCR regional representative assured the committee that, to the UNHCR's knowledge, no applicant for refugee status had been wrongly screened out due to his or her failure to pay a bribe in some form or other. If this is the case, then although these allegations are of a very serious nature and must be examined further—I will come to that later—they do not impact directly upon this bill. If anything, those allegations draw attention to those people who may have been granted refugee status in Galang, who may not have been genuine refugees but whom Australia has accepted in good faith.

Although there is no evidence of wrongful screening out of refugee applicants in Galang for corrupt reasons, such allegations nevertheless require further investigation. I have therefore circulated a second reading amendment which I will formally move on behalf of the coalition and which calls on the government to strongly request the UNHCR to re-examine and evaluate its mechanisms for reviewing claims of boat people seeking asylum, to better identify those who may have been erroneously processed. The amendment also calls on the minister to table in the Senate such proof of this representation as his written request to the UNHCR, the UNHCR response and the minister's response to the high commissioner's examination and evaluation.

This second reading amendment is very much more than a mere pious amendment. It requires the minister to take action in respect of these matters. If the minister fails to comply with the request, then he will be in serious contempt of the Senate. The coalition moves this amendment following detailed discussions with the Vietnamese Australian community and following representations from other concerned organisations. I would like to pay particular credit to the Vietnamese community in Australia and its national president, Mr Cuong Vo; to the Vietnamese-Australian Welfare Association of New South Wales and its secretary, Duc Nguyen; and to the Vietnamese Refugee Supporting Committee of Victoria and its secretary, Trung Doan, and his other members. There were many other people and organisations who made very important recommendations and representations to us along these lines.

Several of these organisations presented the coalition with an amendment to the bill, the principle of which we agree with completely. The wording of the second reading amendment that I will move is based, importantly, on the amendment suggested to the coalition by these Vietnamese Australian community organisations.

I urge the Senate to support this amendment. It is essential that this matter be cleared up and that genuine asylum seekers feel confident of getting a fair hearing of their claims and that a fair decision will be made. To ensure that the government does not simply ignore the Senate's wishes in respect of this matter, assuming the amendment is passed, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs will be required to table in the Senate by no later than 1 February 1995 a report setting out the details that I mentioned earlier.

The effect of this amendment is to create a parliamentary obligation on the minister to perform the tasks outlined in the return to order, to use the technical term, and to report back to this chamber on those matters. It is a binding obligation which failure to comply with would leave the minister in serious contempt of this Senate, as I said earlier. The legal advice that the coalition has received is that this approach, through an amendment at the second reading stage, carries more weight than would an appropriate equivalent type of amendment to the bill. It is for this reason that the coalition has adopted this method of approach.

This bill effectively implements the safe third country concept in Australia. It will require that asylum seekers who have arrived in Australia from safe third countries or who have access to safe third countries will be barred from making applications for protection visas. They will be removed to a safe third country.

In general, the safe third country concept states that someone who has had access to the system of protection in a safe third country will be denied access to Australia's onshore refugee determination processes and will be returned to that safe third country. Countries such as Austria, Canada, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Italy, the Netherlands, Sweden and the UK have adopted the safe third country concept in one form or another.

The system which most closely resembles the one proposed in this bill is that of Canada. Canadian legislation states that a person who claims to be a refugee under the 1951 convention and 1967 protocol is not eligible to have the claim determined in Canada if that person came from a prescribed country. As with the system proposed in this current bill, the Canadian system stipulates that a safe third country must be prescribed in regulations. Canada requires an STC to be party to the 1951 convention and, in particular, article 33 of the convention on non-refoulement. It also considers its record on human rights. Prescription lasts for two years, but is renewable. It may be revoked at any time. Canada also recognises refugee sharing arrangements with other countries such as the CPA countries.

The British define an STC as one in which the life or freedom of an asylum applicant would not be threatened within the meaning of article 33 of the UN convention, and the government of which would not send the applicant elsewhere in a manner contrary to the principles of the 1951 convention and 1967 protocol. The provisions under which a country will be a designated safe third country in relation to a non-citizen in the Australian context are set out in the bill.

The status of a country prescribed as a safe third country is to be subject in the bill to a sunset clause. Unless the status is renewed by regulation, a country is to cease to be a safe third country three years after the commencement of the regulation which initially conferred that status.

Some concerns have been expressed, particularly by the UNHCR representative in Australia, about the safe third country concept and how it is to work. The first concern is the bill's failure to specifically mention the non-refoulement or article 33 of the 1951 convention. The second relates to the need for STC agreements to include assurances on the country's willingness to accept such asylum seekers and the willingness to permit such a person to remain there until final determination of that person's situation. The UNHCR representative's third concern, which was shared by others, related to the three-year period for renewing STC agreements.

A final concern relates to the definition of `the public interest' contained in the bill. Much of the workability of this bill relies heavily on the fact that it must be firm but also fair. Recently, when a boatload of potential asylum seekers landed on our shores, three already assessed cases were granted access to our system of assessment in Galang. It is vital that, if such cases are going to continue to arise, there is flexibility under the act to allow for their reassessment. There is significant scope within this legislation, in the form of ministerial discretion, for flexibility, we believe.

The coalition recognises that all people who arrive by boat, without authorisation, will still be interviewed by officers of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in the way that they have been to date. On the basis of that interview, it will be decided as to whether they come within the scope of this legislation. The department has stated that at this interview, if it is discovered that a potential applicant has new information in support of that person's previously assessed case, that person will be allowed to apply again. However, the only area for such flexibility lies in the minister's non-compellable discretionary powers, which may be exercised only in the public interest.

I will be pursuing some of these matters further in the committee stage of the bill, and I have already circulated proposed amendments relating to some of those concerns. I conclude my second reading comments by reiterating that the coalition supports the intent and the spirit of the bill and we look forward to the government looking seriously at, and hopefully accepting, in particular, the second reading amendment and the other amendments that we are putting forward. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the motion, add:
"but the Senate:

PARA.TAB: (a)calls on the Government to strongly request the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees to re-examine and evaluate its mechanism for reviewing claims of boatpeople seeking asylum, to better identify those who may have been erroneously processed; and

SPEECH.PARA: (b)resolves that there be laid on the Table of the Senate, by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic affairs, by not later than 1 February 1995, a report setting out details of:

TAB.TAB: (i)the Minister's written, diplomatic and other approaches to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees requesting the Commissioner to re-examine and evaluate its mechanism for reviewing claims of boatpeople seeking asylum, to better identify those who may have been erroneously processed;

SPEECH.PARA: (ii)the Commissioner's responses to those approaches;

TAB.TAB: (iii)the Commissioner's examination and evaluation of the mechanism for reviewing such claims; and
(iv)the Minister's response to the Commissioner's examination and evaluation.".

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1994. The purpose of the bill is to insert a new subdivision relating to `certain non-citizens unable to apply for certain visas' into division 3 of part 2 of the Migration Act 1958. If passed, these provisions would enable immigration authorities to refuse to even consider visa applications of certain asylum seekers. In other words, they would be turned back without having their claim for refugee status even assessed by Australian authorities.

PARA.TAB: This would be possible in two main situations: where asylum seekers are covered by the comprehensive plan of action, the CPA, which applies to all refugees from Vietnam and Laos, or where the asylum seeker has a prescribed connection with a safe third country. The connection may be that the person was present in that country at a particular time, even for a day, or that the person has a right to enter or reside in that country.

One could accept that where a person has a right to enter or reside, that was a reasonable connection with that country. It is a little more difficult to accept that the prescribed connection could include a situation where somebody has simply travelled through that country and stayed for a day, a half day or an hour. The Australian Democrats will be moving an amendment to this clause of the bill to substitute `and' for `or'. This is a request made by the representative of the UNHCR. I think there is a very compelling argument for combining the presence, however brief, with the right to reside, to make the connection more substantive.
