The government has acknowledged that the purpose of this bill is to prevent people coming to Australia to seek asylum when, firstly, they have been rejected as refugees by a safe third country; secondly, if they have passed through such a country without applying; or, thirdly, if they have a legal right to stay in such a country.

I submit to the Senate that this bill should be opposed. It is an obnoxious bill. It places Australia in breach of its international obligations. Under the refugee convention, Australia has an obligation to determine the legal status of an asylum seeker and not to expel such a person or return that person to wherever he or she could be under threat on the grounds of race, religion, nationality, political opinion or membership of a particular social group.

Where the asylum seeker has been refused refugee status, or even where he or she runs the risk of being refused such status—we have no control over what happens in the so-called safe third countries—Australia could be causing a forced return from the safe third country as a result of the operation of another country's legal system, a legal system that may on paper be very close to ours but which in practice we do not control and, in many cases, probably do not agree with. In essence, it means that we would be prepared to adopt as our own the decisions of another legal system.

One can assume that Indonesia, in the future, may be one of the countries to be declared a safe third country. I should mention that, according to the bill, countries can be declared safe third countries by regulation. One need only recall the way in which Indonesia's legal system has dealt with offences against East Timorese citizens to realise how unacceptable these provisions could turn out to be in practice.

In addition, as has been mentioned in the chamber before, there are sufficient allegations of bribery as an element in the refugee determination process at the Indonesian reception centre on Galang to reinforce profound unease about the process. Senator Short said that the UNHCR representative was not prepared at the committee hearing of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs to confirm or offer evidence that these alleged briberies have actually taken place.

TALK.START.PARA: —For those who might have been screened out.

—Yes, I know. What I am addressing, though, is the reliability and integrity of the process which the government—and I understand the coalition parties will be supporting it—is prepared to use to deal with people who come to our shores seeking asylum. The government says, `No, if they have travelled through Indonesia, Thailand or Malaysia, we will turn them back.' That is the effect of the bill.
—The bill relates only to those who have been processed properly and screened out.

—That is the point I am raising. Can we rely on the process that has taken place in those countries and has screened them out? I refer Senator Short to three people who arrived in Australia by boat. Although we decided that these three people were properly refugees, they had not been accepted as refugees by the Indonesian process and authorities. Surely, that shows up very clearly the different approach and the different levels of integrity and efficiency. It also shows a different attitude and approach to determining the legal rights that exist in our legal system in Australia and the system in Indonesia where all of the 17 asylum seekers who arrived here on the Vagabond were screened out and rejected.

PARA.TAB: The assessment of the people who arrived here on the Vagabond took place before this bill could take effect. Therefore, as Senator Short has said, those three could be found to have been wrongly screened out in Indonesia. Yet our system, properly, has accepted them as being refugees. If nothing else, this event shows the difficulties that this bill poses. I know it has been said that the three were accepted as refugees on the basis of additional advice. However, that is very strenuously and strongly denied by people who have worked with those three and who have legally represented them.

No cogent new evidence was offered by the government at the committee hearing or at any other stage. On the contrary, the facts are that on the same basic evidence, the Indonesian authorities said, `These people are not refugees,' and on the same basic evidence the Australian authorities and the Australian process said, `These are refugees.'

There are a number of other points about this bill which I would like to advert to. A safe third country can be so declared for a period of three years. This, very obviously, ignores the possibility of very significant political and constitutional changes in the government of such a country—changes in the way the legal system operates and the way in which power is exercised in that country. Three years is by far too long a period. I will be moving an amendment to reduce that to two years. I will be moving another amendment to place the obligation on the government to act immediately to put a stop to the status of safe third country if significant changes occur in a country.

Another concern needs to be put on the table. It is less a legal concern than a political one, because the fact is that this bill shifts the determination process of asylum seekers into the area of foreign affairs, of relations with other countries. There may indeed at any stage be very sound reasons for not declaring a country, yet the Australian government may find it compellingly expedient to do so on foreign relations grounds because not to do so would be seen as an insult. We only have to look at the recent history of our region to accept that relations with our neighbours can, at times, be extremely sensitive and their reactions to what we say and do can be extremely prickly.

A situation where we would not declare a country—in other words, where we say in substance, `No, we won't declare you because we don't really trust you'—would be viewed as an insult by that country. Yet we in Australia would be concerned to foster trade with that country, and I suspect that the principle and the fate of individuals who are asylum seekers would be sacrificed to the economic interests of the country.

The next point that needs to be addressed in this debate is the matter of ministerial discretion. The bill provides this safeguard to the asylum seeker, and the minister has the discretion in the public interest to admit that particular person to the determination process in Australia. However, it is a non-compellable discretion. In other words, the non-exercise of ministerial discretion would not be subject to judicial or administrative challenge, except by prerogative writ under the constitution. It is therefore a fairly illusory safeguard.

Another point to be made in this context is that the representative of UNHCR has suggested that public interest need not necessarily include compelling humanitarian reasons. He has suggested that the bill be amended to ensure that the minister should exercise his discretion where compelling humanitarian reasons are present. I have suggested to the minister that this matter should be addressed in the chamber. I am looking forward to his response to that and to his assurance that the definition of public interest does include compelling humanitarian reasons.

Finally, the bill has a retrospective element. The bill applies to cases which have been commenced in the Australian determination process since 1 September of this year. In summary, I suggest again to honourable senators that we should reject this bill because it puts us in breach of our international obligations.

Unfortunately, the amendments foreshadowed by the coalition parties do not sufficiently cure the defects of the bill to enable us to support it. However, we will support the amendments that the opposition will move because we accept the reality that the bill will probably pass, since the coalition is intent on supporting the government on the basic substance of the bill. Despite the concerns that have been raised not only by the Vietnamese community but by others, the opposition is prepared to support the bill. So while we will put on record our strong opposition by voting against the second reading of the bill, we will also support the opposition's amendments to the second reading as well as during the committee stage.

I wish that Senator Short had accepted the Vietnamese community's suggestion that what it has asked him to do should be moved as an amendment to the bill rather than as a second reading amendment. Members of the Vietnamese community are on record during a hearing before the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs as requesting Australian parliamentarians to ensure that this bill does not pass. So it is with a great deal of regret that I stand here today and have to say that it is shameful for this parliament to pass this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not believe that it would be shameful for the Australian parliament to pass the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4). This is absolutely necessary legislation. It is legislation that does not just deal with a couple of boats of unauthorised arrivals of people who have landed on our shores in recent months. It is legislation that looks at one very important worldwide program conducted by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, and that is the comprehensive plan of action—a world action plan for what to do with a large number of people who have fled from their homelands of, generally speaking, Vietnam and Laos. It is a problem that has not gone away quickly. It is a problem that will remain, particularly in this region of the world, for some time to come. Hopefully, this problem will have gone away by the end of next year, but that is still 14 months away.

PARA.TAB: This comprehensive plan of action has to deal with a very large number of people, and has already done so. According to the minister's evidence in relation to this bill given during the public hearing of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs held in Melbourne on 30 September, some 112,000 people have been accepted as refugees through the comprehensive plan of action. This bill is supportive of that comprehensive plan of action, and in that sense it is not disgraceful at all.

I make this plea to academics or advocates who want to write about the history of this bill. I suggest that they should read not only the submissions that were made to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in relation to this bill, but also the evidence that was presented to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on Friday, 30 September and in Sydney on 5 October. They should read not only the submissions but also the advocates' evidence when they attended the hearing and were subjected to questioning by members of the Senate. I ask them not to make the same mistake as some people made in writing up and reviewing the report presented earlier this year by the Joint Standing Committee on Migration by going off half-cocked and making somewhat of a fool of themselves.

I make that plea on the record because if similar reviews of the committee's report appear again, I might be less restrained in my critique of the critics of government legislation on matters of refugees, boat people or illegal entrants. Some of the advocates who appeared before the two public hearings have been very critical of the government's efforts in dealing with the boat people problem. One would think from reading their immediate comments that Australia is in disgrace because of what we are doing in the area of re-settlement and in dealing with claims made by boat people or illegal entrants to this country.

I was very happy to read the submissions from one of the critics of government policy in this regard. It was a submission made by Dr Mary E. Crock, a solicitor and immigration consultant, who gives a registered number in submission No. 8 to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. On page 8 of her submission she makes this claim:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia now has in place a very good system for determining the status of people who come to its shores claiming to be refugees.

Dr Crock has been one of the most forceful critics of our system over the years. I am happy to be able to quote Miss Crock on this occasion, just as I have quoted her submission in another bill before the parliament.

PARA.TAB: There is another element that the parliament has to consider in dealing with this legislation. It is a matter of great concern which I understand was brought to the attention of all senators and members by way of a letter dated 19 August from the New South Wales chapter of the Vietnamese community in Australia. The letter appears under the signatures of Mr Cuong Vo and a Mr Nguyen, who is president of the refugee fund committee. The letter concerned me greatly when I read it because it contained allegations that, because the minister had issued a press statement to deny 17 boat people the ability to apply for asylum in this country, he was making Australia an undemocratic and an uncivilised nation. The letter suggested that the minister:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . may not be fully cognisant that the screening process that these 17 boat people had been subjected to is gravely rigged by corruption, bribery and demand for sexual favours.
The letter went on to quote a Mr Simon Jeans, who gave evidence before the committee in Sydney.

PARA.TAB: I took the assertions and allegations contained in the Vietnamese community letter so seriously that I actually wrote back to the New South Wales chapter of the Vietnamese community by letter dated 22 August and asked for further information. I also offered the community some suggestions as to how it might address the matters raised in the letter with the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. I gave the name and address of the regional representative.

Unfortunately, I did not receive a response to my letter. That surprised me somewhat because of the very serious allegations that were made in the letter to me. On 20 September I was motivated to again write to the Vietnamese community asking for further information. I asked for evidence and support of the assertions and allegations contained in the letter. Today, 18 October, some two months after I received the letter that was written to me, I still have not received a response.

I also wrote to the regional representative of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and received a reply from Mr Pierre Michel Fontaine. The United Nations representative denies the allegations, but it was not just a flat denial. Because of the assertions contained in the letter from the Vietnamese community, Mr Fontaine asked for further evidence. Part of Mr Fontaine's letter reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to the allegations of Mr. Simon Jeans, previously engaged as a Legal Consultant with UNHCR in Galang, on no occasion did our Office in Indonesia ever receive such information or reports on corruption from him. Having received the report from you, we contacted Mr. Jeans with a view to obtaining names or other details which might assist us in investigating this matter.

PARA.TAB: Mr. Jeans has advised us that he is unable to name any UNHCR-recommended case who might have been denied refugee status by the Government of Indonesia due to not being able to pay a bribe. Mr. Jeans also said that, notwithstanding difficulties certain refugees might have had in getting positive decisions at the first instance, he expected UNHCR-recommended cases would be accepted on appeal. He had no knowledge of any specific case ultimately being denied refugee status due to "failing to come up with the cash". It therefore must be said that neither we, nor Mr. Jeans, have been able to identify a single person who was ultimately denied refugee status simply because he or she could not afford to pay a bribe.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously that is of great concern to those of us in this parliament who care for people in the world who are in a less fortunate position than ourselves—those in need of protection.

PARA.TAB: The allegations contained in the letter from the New South Wales chapter of the Vietnamese community caused concern right across the parliament. I am aware that a number of representations were made to the minister's office regarding the content of the letter. When these things are thrashed through and when evidence is asked for, the evidence is not produced. From my reading of the Hansard of the two public hearings of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, that evidence still has not been brought forward. Obviously that will leave some doubts in people's minds as to the veracity of the initial claims.

I want to direct a few comments to the evidence that was given to the committee in its deliberations on this bill. I am a member of the committee, but unfortunately for personal family reasons I was not able to be present—much as I would have liked to have been in a position to address questions to the advocates and the witnesses. Those things happen from time to time. I found the transcripts very interesting reading. Summing up, I think the advocates were arguing that it did not really matter if a person had been screened out of the refugee system in another country and had been through appeals; he or she should be given an opportunity in Australia to apply for refugee status. This bill will address that situation.

It seems to me that the advocates have suggested a very dangerous course of action in how to address the problem. It was suggested by at least a couple of groups that people like the people on the Vagabond from Galang Island who arrived in Australia should be given access to our Refugee Review Tribunal. In other words, they should be allowed to appeal in Australia against decisions taken in another country. Were the government to accept their recommendations, I wonder what that would do to the whole comprehensive plan of action and its effect on close on 50,000 people who remain in camps throughout South-East Asia—people who will have to make decisions about their future prior to the end of next year. I am pleased that the government is not accepting the suggestion that the RRT be brought into the process.

It is also interesting to note in those submissions that some people went to some length to say that people like the Vagabond people should be given access not only to the RRT but also to our judicial process. I have had some words to say publicly and in this place about people who, I assert, are using our judicial process, after they have been through the administrative process, to delay their departure from Australia. The reason the non-compellable ministerial review is contained in this bill is to block out those continual delaying tactics that some people have already engaged in, to the detriment of the people who are currently held in detention in this country.

I was happy to quote Dr Mary Crock earlier in my comments, who said that advocates—and she certainly is one who has been critical of government and government action on boat people—take the view that we have a very good system in place. There is another advocate who also commented on the circumstances which led to the presentation of this bill in the chamber. I am referring to the president of the ACT Indochina Refugee Association, who is well known outside of Canberra—she is not just known in Canberra—as a very strident advocate of refugee issues. This year she was so respected by her peers that during Refugee Week she was awarded the coveted Paul Cullen Award for services to refugees in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —An excellent advocate.

—Senator Short has picked who it is already. I am referring to Ms Marion Le. She has been an outspoken critic of the government on just about everything to do with refugees. She seems to have a view on just about everything in relation to immigration and more often than not her views are diametrically opposed to the views of the government and probably of successive governments.

PARA.TAB: But on this occasion she was one of the first advocates to enter into the debate over what should be done concerning those screened out asylum seekers who arrived from the CPA camp of Galang. Ms Le was far from critical on this occasion. She started pushing the government right from the beginning. In the Canberra Times on 13 July, Ms Le called on the government to remove from Australia the newly arrived refugees from the Vagabond. Ms Le said that it was crucial Australia take a tough stand on this group, given that they had already been found not to qualify as refugees in Galang. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: If we were to allow them to seek refugee status we'd have a problem with Indonesia—and with the whole international community.
Interestingly, she also said:

The fact that I am a refugee advocate doesn't mean I assist every Tom, Dick and Harry. By definition I'm interested in people who have genuine claims to refugee status. Everyone else should be sent back.

She also said that she believed the refugee assessment process in Indonesia, supervised by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, was as good as, if not better than, Australia's system. I will not comment on whether Indonesia's system or any country's system in the region is better than Australia's; but the system has worked and worked quite well so far in the sense that the CPA plan has put 112,000 refugees through the system.

PARA.TAB: If the system is flawed, as some of the advocates put in evidence to the committee, it brings into doubt the refugee status granted to some of those 112,000 refugees. Some of the advocates really need to look at the evidence that was put to the Senate standing committee and examine the damage that they may have done to their claims on behalf of boat people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to touch on what the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) proposes to do. It proposes amendments to the Migration Act 1958. It inserts into the principal act new sections 91A to 91F and refers to the comprehensive plan of action, popularly known as the CPA.

PARA.TAB: Before I continue, I should touch on the CPA. The genesis of that plan lies in the exodus of Vietnamese refugees from Vietnam following the fall of Saigon in April 1975. There really were not many avenues of departure from Vietnam other than taking to the ocean, and so the refugees became known as boat people. The outflow of these people in the region has increased dramatically over the years and during the 1980s was the subject of a good deal of concern in the region.

Finally, the matter came to a head and the CPA was perhaps born out of a frustration over how to handle the situation. The region, as it were, was put under intense pressure. In particular, Malaysia, Hong Kong, the Philippines, Indonesia and Thailand felt the pressure of the refugees. That was due to the geographical proximity of these countries to the problems that were being experienced by the refugees and the people of Vietnam.

The new system introduced by the CPA did not substantively label those leaving as economic migrants; but, due to the introduction of an objective standard in determining who would be resettled, it had this effect. There was a perception that the previous agreements had contributed to the problem by encouraging people to leave Vietnam.

The situation is one of great significance to Australia. We have a situation where refugees might go to one country in the region, be refused that refugee status, and then come to Australia again. This has become known as forum shopping. It was thought that if refugees went to a third country, applied and were processed in an appropriate manner, they really should not have two bites of the apple and come to Australia, tie up proceedings here and take up positions that could be occupied by other more deserving cases. That seems to be the background to the bill.

I was a member of the committee which took evidence in relation to this matter and a number of concerns were expressed in relation to the legislation. It would be fair to say, though, that the greatest concern was in relation to the term `safe third country', which is provided for in proposed section 91D.

The term relates to a principle whereby the government gazettes a safe third country; if refugees have passed through that safe third country, whether or not they have applied for asylum status, before they get to Australia, they can be refused any application made here and sent back. The minister has discretion, of course, but that really is not appealable, and a good deal of concern was expressed about that.

I concede that one can go only so far in these matters. Australia has to look realistically at how it lives up to its international obligations. During the course of the hearing I was impressed by Mr Fontaine, the representative of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees in Australia, New Zealand and the South Pacific. The amendments proposed by Senator Short entail, in the main, the suggestions made by Mr Fontaine. In the submission he made to the committee, Mr Fontaine stated:

SPEECH.PARA: In addition, we would like to recommend that the following be further added to section 91D(3) as part of the statement to be laid out by the Minister before the House of Parliament, after subsections (a) and (b):
"(c) the willingness of a safe third country to accept returned asylum-seekers and refugees;
(d) the willingness of a safe third country to allow asylum-seekers to remain while their claims are examined and to allow refugees to remain until a durable solution is found; and
(e) whether the non-citizen has strong links to Australia or other compelling humanitarian reasons for the person not to be returned to the safe third country."
Those sentiments are borne out by Senator Short's proposed amendment, which would go some way towards alleviating the concerns about a safe third country.

PARA.TAB: The problem that various witnesses had was the question of the standards that a safe third country had to meet. Australia can pride itself on a judicial system which is second to none. Senator McKiernan has mentioned Dr Crock's submission that this country has a good record on refugees. Certainly, this country has provided refugees with assistance to take action where there has been a breach in the due process of the Migration Act or where a legal remedy is available. Not many countries afford that. We have provided assistance by way of process and representation.

What has muddied the waters in Australia over the years is a good deal of confusion over the legislation. Previous legislation put forward by the government has demonstrated that the department has not had a crystallised view of its obligations, to say the least. But at the end of the day Australia has set out to do the right thing and meet its international obligations. The CPA is an agreement via the international community which has endeavoured to settle a pressing matter in the region. Therefore, Australia's participation is quite appropriate.

I return to the process which is available to refugees landing on our shores. It may well be that other countries do not have the standards that we would like to see: they might not offer due process; they might not offer the individual the ability to have his or her case for asylum status adequately heard. That is where the problem arises.

The amendment sought by Senator Short goes to the scrutiny allowed by the parliament of what is laid before it. Subsection C mirrors the comments made by Mr Fontaine. More important, however, is the addition which states:

SPEECH.PARA: "but the Senate:

PARA.TAB: (a)calls on the Government to strongly request the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees to re-examine and evaluate its mechanism for reviewing claims of boatpeople seeking asylum, to better identify those who may have been erroneously processed; and

SPEECH.PARA: (b)resolves that there be laid on the Table of the Senate, by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic affairs, by not later than 1 February 1995, a report setting out details of:

TAB.TAB: (i)the Minister's written, diplomatic and other approaches to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees requesting the Commissioner to re-examine and evaluate its mechanism for reviewing claims of boatpeople seeking asylum, to better identify those who may have been erroneously processed;

SPEECH.PARA: (ii)the Commissioner's responses to those approaches;

TAB.TAB: (iii)the Commissioner's examination and evaluation of the mechanism for reviewing such claims; and
(iv)the Minister's response to the Commissioner's examination and evaluation.".

SPEECH.PARA: That provides some sort of assurance that process will be followed. If there were any breach of that, a return to order there could well be an appropriate measure, and Senator Short has touched on that. That may well allay some of the fears of the witnesses who appeared before the committee about the whole system of the safe third country and questions of the processing of boat people in general.

PARA.TAB: There is a principle of non-refoulement contained in article 33 of the 1951 convention relating to the status of refugees. Basically, that principle says that a signatory may not send a refugee back to his or her country of origin or any other country where his or her life or freedom would be in danger. Australia should not breach that basic principle, and I do not believe that we do.

I am not entirely at ease with other aspects of this legislation. The government has accounted for the retrospective aspect on the basis that a press statement was made by the minister prior to the date from which this legislation will have effect. I sound a word of caution to the Senate. Retrospectivity by press release is a practice that should be looked at with a good deal of caution. It is not a practice that should be abused or become commonplace. It should be used sparingly.

Senator Short's amendments go a long way to sorting out this bill and providing some sort of assurance to those who appeared before the committee. We will never please everybody all the time but, in these circumstances, with these amendments Australia will meet its international obligations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1994 continues the well-worn theme of government policy trying to turn its back on people in our region who are or might be in need of this country's protection. The bill is part of the ever-growing tradition of responding to small groups of asylum seekers with big stick legislation. As an aside, I mention that we will be seeing more of the same during this session when the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3), which declares that what was illegal is now legal in relation to the boat people detainees, comes back into this chamber.

PARA.TAB: This is not the first time that this chamber has had an opportunity to put paid to the government's shameful treatment of the so-called boat people, and it seems that it will not be the last. But I wonder how many people have closely followed the developments in refugee policy since the first of the recent boats arrived in 1989. Those who have would be amazed by the difference between the response of this government and that of the Fraser government when the much larger influx of boat people started to arrive in the aftermath of the Vietnam war.

In the latter case, the government, led by the Prime Minister and the minister for immigration, worked hard to create a climate of welcome in the community for those who came needing our help. The current government has also worked hard to shape community attitudes—unfortunately, in the opposite direction.

The naming of the latest boat to arrive is, I hope, merely an aberration and not part of the process of vilification. For those who have missed it, the boat has been given the name Vagabond, which allows those on it to be referred to as Vagabond applicants. This looks fine on paper when we can see the capital V but could be badly misconstrued through the electronic media.

The government has been spectacularly successful with its campaign. I am sure that many honourable senators receive, as I do, phone calls from people in the community who begrudge the boat people anything at all. But the government is seeking to take its response one step further with this bill. At the very heart of this proposed legislation is an attempt to unload onto other countries the whole problem of dealing with certain asylum seekers in our region.

I want to make it clear that I understand the government's dilemma with regard to the comprehensive plan of action, the CPA. No-one wants to undermine the plan because at the moment it is all we have in relation to the vast numbers of people who have fled Vietnam or Laos and who are now in camps scattered throughout the region. But it is one thing to say that the plan is all we have; it is quite another to suggest that it is perfect or even that its administration is effective and uniform across signatory countries. If it were so, we would expect the proportion of positive refugee application outcomes to be roughly uniform wherever the applications are assessed.

Clearly, the outcomes are not uniform, not even remotely so. In the Philippines, 47 per cent of applications are assessed positively. In Thailand the figure is 20 per cent. In Hong Kong it is only eight per cent. That is hardly what one would expect when the numbers involved are as large as is presently the case.

If we examine this bill carefully from a human rights or social justice perspective, we quickly come to the realisation that there are competing forces at work. On the one hand, the bill seeks to uphold the CPA and, as I have said, that is a worthwhile goal. But on the other hand, with this legislation, that goal is at odds with the goal of protecting the human rights of the individuals whose presence has led to the formulation of the CPA.

When the refugee convention was brought into being in 1951 it was a response to an immense human tragedy, a situation in which millions of people were in need of the protection of countries other than their own. The convention ensured that each case would be assessed individually, according to the needs of and the dangers facing the individual. I am not sure that the CPA gives the same rigorous attention to the individual as the convention does, but I am sure that this bill does not consider the wellbeing of the individual to be the paramount issue.

Under the convention, Australia is required to ensure that it never returns a person to a situation of danger. We are not allowed a margin of error; we are simply not to do it. With this bill, the government is trying to off-load that responsibility onto third countries. That is the effect of it. Moreover, the attempt to deny people the right to apply for protection is clearly in breach of article 14 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights unless Australia is absolutely satisfied that a decision made about a person's application in another country was fair and proper. I am sure that honourable senators would appreciate just how difficult it would be for us to achieve a process by which we could monitor those processes.

Furthermore, if we have returned someone, to Indonesia, for instance, on the grounds that his or her application for refugee status has been properly and fairly assessed and that person is subsequently returned to a situation of persecution and danger, it would be legal mumbo jumbo to suggest that we have not been guilty of refoulement. The fact that three of the 17 people aboard the Vagabond have been accepted as refugees in Australia bears out that argument.

The regional representative of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, Pierre-Michel Fontaine, made a submission to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. I believe that some of my colleagues have already referred to that. The second paragraph of that submission says:

SPEECH.PARA: In exceptional circumstances, UNHCR has exercised its mandate to grant refugee status where persons have been rejected on appeal. In effect, the UNHCR mandate acts as a "safety net" to ensure that all those who meet the criteria of the UNHCR Statute qualify for the protection of UNHCR. These persons are referred to as "mandate refugees."

That is all very well but in the case of the people from the Vagabond, if they had arrived subject to the conditions being put in place by this bill, they would have been returned to Indonesia or sent on to Vietnam. That is why we are concerned that this so-called safety net will not operate once we have a legislative face that says that we actually send people on and that we do not reconsider their claims. That would mean that those three people out of 17 would not have received the consideration that has allowed them, for the right reasons, to stay in this country because of their refugee status. Paragraph 9 of the submission to which I earlier referred says:

Furthermore, there may be circumstances where a person who once had the protection of a country, no longer does so and is required to leave that country for another country of asylum. This is another reason why past entry or residence is less important than the potential for future protection.

This bill actually denies people future protection in view of their past entry or residence because, in effect, it says that we can send them back if they have been in another country. That is why, notwithstanding the UNHCR's assessment that, despite its limitations and providing there are safeguards, this bill may well be worthy of support, the Greens are not convinced that we should be supporting it.

PARA.TAB: Sadly, that is not the only reason for arguing against the proposed legislation. The administration of the CPA has been criticised, not only for inconsistency but also for perceived levels of corruption in various countries in the region. I understand that this is a matter that concerns the opposition and the Democrats in relation to this bill, and that the opposition is seeking assurances from the government that allegations made against certain countries will be looked into. I am of the view that, at the very least, the bill should be delayed until such time as the reports which are currently circulating are thoroughly investigated. I might add that I wrote to the minister recently about this matter and I will be interested to hear his comments in this debate.

This legislation also attempts to enshrine in the Migration Act the notion of a safe third country, but we should examine that concept a little more fully. I note that the bill is carefully worded in proposed section 91D(3) (b) to refer to `relevant' human rights standards rather than suggest that safe third countries are distinguishable by absolute human rights standards. I think that there should be some kind of provision for countries in this area to be signatories to the refugee convention and the other international conventions, such as the ICCPR and the human rights convention, that provide human rights protection.

It is interesting to note that Canada enacted such a provision in 1989 and so far has not been able to find a country with which it is prepared to sign a safe third country agreement because it cannot find countries with acceptable human rights standards. One cannot help but wonder whether, firstly, this provision would ever be used or, secondly, the government intends to limit the definition of relevant human rights standards to such an extent that any agreements will be meaningless in terms of protecting asylum seekers. I do not believe that this concern about the legislation is simply alleviated by the fact that safe third country agreements will be disallowable in the parliament.

I also want to draw the attention of honourable senators to the provision in section 91D(2)(a), which allows for a person to be returned to another country if he or she has previously been `present in the country at a particular time or at any time during a particular period'. I referred to that earlier in the submission from the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. I am referring to those asylum seekers who are currently in detention camps. If this obscure Australian legal definition is what is meant in the bill, it gives me some little bit of hope for the proposed system. If, however, it is the plain English meaning of `present in the country', that could mean that any people on a boat which stops in Indonesia on its way to Australia could be sent back under this provision.

Finally, I would like to make a point about the government's readiness to reach for retrospective legislation when it comes to asylum seekers. We have witnessed this time and again, and always found it wanting. In this case, the first boat to arrive from Galang, with people on board who had been rejected under the Indonesian administration of the CPA, is considered under the old rules. But, of course, the government wanted to nip such approaches in the bud and quickly announced that it would legislate at the first opportunity. This bill picks up the intention of that announcement and is, according to the government, quite reasonably effective from the time of the announcement. That might be a reason for considering act No. 4 before act No. 3.

Therefore, the second boat is caught up by the new provisions. I know that in the past—most recently in the discussion on the treatment of shares held by pensioners—the government has argued that people should be aware of announcements and act accordingly. But in this case it begs the question of how a group of people in Galang, or already on a boat on their way to Australia, are supposed to hear about the Australian government's press releases.

At its heart, this bill attempts to make the refugee convention a lesser document and its obligations less important than the comprehensive plan of action. That is unacceptable. The bill creates a legislative means by which Australia can breach longstanding obligations under international law.

As I indicated at the beginning of my speech, it is not in anyone's interests to undermine the CPA. But this bill does not deal adequately with the situation of the individuals whose presence in our region brought about the plan. I urge the government to withdraw the bill and rethink its approaches to the issues raised in this debate. While we will be supporting the amendments put forward by the opposition with the view that they may ameliorate some of the concerns, we do not feel they adequately deal with them and, therefore, we will be opposing the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had a look at this Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1994 and had discussions about it. I am aware of the consideration given to the bill by the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade and of the minority report. Having regard to all of those factors, I too will not be supporting the bill.

PARA.TAB: It seems that the bill is not pursuing what I believe it should pursue—that the bill should uphold the international obligations of Australia. Many things have been said around the chamber about the legislation and I do not want to repeat them but it seems that, if an agreement, binding or otherwise, is to be entered into between our country and other countries, that would trigger the provisions of the legislation which would enable or actually require Australia to refuse status to applicants seeking refugee status if they have been refused that status in another country.

It has also been said in the chamber by other honourable senators that this appears to give undue weight to the legal systems of particular other countries and how they interpret their international obligations. I do not think that is appropriate. I will say no more. I will vote against the bill and hope, though not very expectantly, that the bill will be defeated.

TALK.START.PARA: —In summing up the second reading of the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1994, I thank honourable senators for their contributions. Even those who wished it something other than a speedy passage I thank for their thoughtful and considered contributions.

PARA.TAB: I will respond to the major points raised by honourable senators in the debate. Firstly, Senator Short sought an assurance that all potential asylum seekers arriving in Australia would be interviewed by officers of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. All persons arriving in those circumstances, such as unauthorised boat arrivals, are interviewed by officers of the department on arrival. That has always happened in the past and I can give an assurance on behalf of the minister that it will always happen in the future. The purpose of such interviews is to establish the person's identity and circumstances.

If the bill is enacted and persons arrive who are subject to its provisions, we envisage that they would ordinarily be returned to the safe third country or CPA country. However, if issues of public interest arise, such as where there are strong compassionate or humanitarian grounds, the minister could consider allowing the person to apply for a visa. The starting point for whether the minister should consider exercising his non-compellable discretion to allow an application based upon an assessment of whether a person is advancing cogent reasons will be available through the routine initial departmental interview. The minister's non-compellable power is an important safeguard and will be exercised accordingly.

In going to the next point of principal concern, I will deal with some of the issues that might normally be stated in the committee stage but it might be easier to do it now. The opposition indicated to the government that it intended to support some of the UNHCR's recommendations regarding section 91D(3) concerning the minister's obligation to table a statement regarding the type of countries that will become safe third countries by way of regulation. Consequently, the government is seeking minor amendments to proposed subsection 91D(3). The proposed subsection relates to the obligation on the minister to lay a statement before parliament providing relevant information about all of the countries prescribed as a safe third country.

There are some numbering and lettering changes. There is only a slight variation to the wording relating to those. Proposed paragraph 91D(3)(c) introduces an additional requirement to that proposed originally in the bill. It requires that the statement of the minister must also refer to the willingness of the country or each of the countries prescribed as an STC to allow any person in relation to whom the country is prescribed to go to and to remain in the country while any claim for asylum by the person is being determined. It also provides that, where the person is determined to be a refugee while in the country, the statement should contain information about the willingness of the country to allow the person to remain until a durable solution relating to the permanent settlement of the person is found.

The government is firmly of the view that the words in proposed paragraph 91D(3)(a), namely, `compliance. . . with relevant international law concerning the protection of persons seeking asylum', include the fundamental concept of non-refoulement. Non-refoulement means that there must not be the non-voluntary return of a refugee to a country where his or her life or freedom would be threatened on account of race, religion, nationality, membership of a particular social group or political opinion. Article 33 of the refugees convention prohibits refoulement.

Senator Spindler sought an assurance that the words `public interest' in proposed section 91F incorporate `strong compassionate or humanitarian circumstances'. The non-compellable discretion is there to provide the minister with the power to act when the circumstances of a case are such as to merit his intervention in the public interest, which would include when there are strong compassionate or humanitarian reasons. The powers involved provide for a safety net to ensure that no person will be disadvantaged by the statutory regime.

Senator Spindler also raised some concern about the retrospective nature of the amendments. The amendments effectively cover persons who have arrived in Australia on or after 1 September 1994. This gives effect to an announcement by the minister on 29 August 1994. The government's view is that the proposed commencement date is entirely appropriate, given the minister's earlier announcement. The proposed amendments are necessary to maintain the integrity of Australia's borders and the efficiency of the refugee determination system.

In her most recent contribution, Senator Chamarette suggested that the bill contravenes our obligations under international law, including the 1951 refugee convention and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. I am advised that the bill was drafted in close consultation with the Office of International Law in the Attorney-General's Department, which advises that it is consistent with our obligations under international law. The bill was also discussed with the UNHCR prior to its introduction.

I also refer to the amendment proposed by Senator Short. Honourable senators would be surprised to know that the government opposes that proposed amendment! Effective review mechanisms are in place for persons covered by the comprehensive plan of action. In the case of Galang, these mechanisms are as follows. Firstly, applicants are first interviewed by a legal consultant appointed by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees who makes a recommendation to the Indonesian screening team. The UNHCR has observer capacity on the screening team. Secondly, if the screening decision is negative, the UNHCR provides, on request, legal counselling on preparation of a review application. Thirdly, the UNHCR is represented on the review committee. Finally if, after the process, the UNHCR considers a screened out person to be a refugee, it can exercise its mandate and declare the person a refugee.

The UNHCR has given an unequivocal assurance that under the CPA no person it considered to be a refugee has been denied refugee status. Asylum seekers can seek redress through either the Indonesian authorities or the UNHCR. In June 1994 at the CPA technical meeting in Bangkok, the UNHCR gave an assurance that it would arrange the re-examination of the case of any person who was able to bring forward new information or changed circumstances relevant to his or her claim for refugee status. Cases which have been brought to the Australian government's attention, claiming that screening decisions were incorrect, have been referred to the UNHCR for re-examination.

The screening process under the CPA has been finalised. No party to the CPA would want to encourage a massive re-screening exercise. To do so would be costly at a time when there are more pressing humanitarian situations around the world. It would raise unrealistic expectations about resettlement in the camp populations. It would discourage those screened out from voluntarily returning to Vietnam, and it may encourage further outflows from Vietnam.

In conclusion, I will refer to the communications between the government and the UNHCR. This might be relevant to the concerns that motivated Senator Short to move the amendment. Allegations made in October 1993 were referred to the UNHCR on 11 November 1993. On 18 November, the UNHCR advised that the allegations had been referred to its office in Jakarta. Further allegations were made in mid-1994. They were raised by Australia at the CPA technical meeting in Bangkok in June 1994, and UNHCR headquarters agreed to investigate.

In September 1994, a report covering the allegations was referred to the UNHCR representative in Canberra. The UNHCR has advised that no person deserving refugee status has been denied that status through not engaging in corrupt practices. The UNHCR is continuing its investigation. With those responses to the principal contributions made in the second reading debate, the queries raised by some senators and the proposed amendment, I wish the bill a speedy passage.
Amendment agreed to.
Question put:
That the motion, as amended, be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before we go any further, I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the government amendment to be moved to this bill.

PARA.TAB: Clauses 1 to 3—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Schedule.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a question about the interpretation of the word `agreement'. The provision states:

SPEECH.PARA: `agreement' includes a written arrangement or understanding, whether or not binding;
I would like the minister to explain a couple of things to me because of the importance of that agreement. We see in 91C(1)(b)(ii) the following wording:

an agreement, relating to persons seeking asylum, between Australia and a country that is, or countries that include a country that is, at that time, a safe third country in relation to the non-citizen . . .

It seems to me important—I would like the minister to respond to this—that if asylum seekers are to be returned and denied access to Australian law to determine their refugee status, there be some binding agreement with the third country to which the asylum seeker will be returned and under whose law his or her claim for refugee status will be determined. It seems a funny way for Australia to discharge an obligation by allowing itself to give it over to another country which is not bound in respect of that obligation. I would like to know why the government chose to include the words `whether or not binding'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that I am dealing with Senator Harradine's concern because I am not sure whether I understand Senator Harradine's concern, but let me try. The words `whether or not binding' are there to indicate that there may well be agreements dealt with under this set of arrangements which are not in any way legally enforceable in a court anywhere, but we are still proposing to act in accordance

SPEECH.PARA: with such an agreement. That is what we are saying.

PARA.TAB: If the words were not there, I am not sure whether it would change the meaning, but it would be less clear; and I do not think we would want to have the opposite meaning, because I do not see how what Senator Harradine is envisaging is the process of enforcement of such an arrangement or understanding. I am not sure whether that goes to Senator Harradine's concerns, but those are the facts that I have at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us take Indonesia as an example. That is a good example because, as was probably mentioned in the second reading debate, all of the 17 Vietnamese refugees were denied refugee status by Indonesia, but three of them subsequently succeeded here. Under this regime there might be an agreement, a written arrangement or an understanding between Australia and Indonesia. This says that it is written. Clearly, it may not be binding in international jurisdictions. Could it not be binding or could it be able to be binding? That is the whole point about it.

PARA.TAB: If there were some sanctions written into the agreement—I find it difficult to imagine what they might be—and if there was some way by which the agreement ensured that the same processes that are applied in Australia to asylum seekers and applicants for refugee status were applied in Indonesia, then that would be okay. What would need to then occur is that, if those procedures were not followed, there should be some appeal process which would enable the procedures to be reviewed and followed. I am not sure why the minister actually left the words `whether or not binding' in. What is the point of having an agreement, a written arrangement or undertaking on a very important matter unless it were binding?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grappling with what might be the sanction that would be in such an agreement. There are many international agreements that have significant moral force in that all nations are observed by other nations as to the way in which we keep undertakings we give in agreements—not just our standing in terms of reputation, but preparedness of other people to enter into subsequent arrangements with us, many of which we would wish to have being significantly influenced by whether or not people accept that we keep the word that we give.

PARA.TAB: I cannot see how we would benefit by taking those words out. It is simply saying that we do not want to have a quibble about whether or not such an arrangement or understanding is capable of being enforced at law. If we have entered into such an understanding, we accept that we should operate within its terms and we expect other parties to do so. That is our experience, as an international citizen, of the way in which we and other countries operate, in which other countries expect us to operate, and in which we are entitled to expect others to operate. That is the clause, as I understand it. If there is more complexity to it, I am not sure what it is.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to buy into this discussion too much, but I think Senator Harradine has got quite a point. I am not sure whether the minister has the advisers there who can help him on this point, but can he tell me whether those terms and the definition of agreement, particularly the words `whether or not binding', are contained in other acts?

—All I can say, without reference to the statutes, is that the inclusion of the words is on the recommendation of the Office of Parliamentary Counsel rather than on some unique initiative of the initiating department—on this occasion, the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. As to whether that means that is the standard practice of OPC and they have done it with regard to other legislation, I cannot say. But it is their view about the appropriate wording to avoid doubt on this occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Schedule, page 3, item 1, proposed paragraph 91D(2)(a), line 14, omit "or", substitute "and".

This amendment seeks to omit the word `or and substitute the word `and' between paragraphs 91D(2)(a) and 91D(2)(b). The effect of the amendment is that before a person can be prescribed as a person who is affected by these provisions that person must have been present in the country at the particular time or at any time during a particular period, but, as well, that person must have the right to enter and reside in the country.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of the amendment is that it is clearly not sufficient to apply the provisions of this act which deny that asylum seeker access to the Australian determination process simply if that person was present in a particular country at a particular time. I commend the amendment to the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I be equally brief in response. The government's concern with this amendment is that to require that a person have been both in a country as well as having the right to enter and reside in a country would be too limiting and inflexible. The crucial point is the agreement: a safe third country may agree to take back a person who was merely present in that country during a particular period. On the other hand, it may require a stronger link. The circumstances will vary between countries. I would have thought the committee would be keen to have flexibility in these circumstances. The government certainly thinks that such flexibility is required, and we will not be supporting the amendment.

—The coalition also will not be supporting this amendment. As I understand it, the purpose of the amendment is to try to limit the scope for the return of people to a designated safe third country. Inserting the word `and' into the subsection would mean that a returnee would have a right to enter a safe third country—such as citizenship, a valid visa or entry permit—as well as having been present in that safe third country at some time.

PARA.TAB: We do not agree with the purpose of that amendment because the effect of it is almost certainly to handicap the safe third country component of the legislation. The coalition supports both the CPA and the safe third country components of the bill. This seems to work against that.

That said, I do not think the aim of the amendment will be achieved anyway because the relevant provisions state that `the regulations may provide'—I underline `may'—therefore making the provisions purely voluntary. This means that the likely effect of this amendment is to render the amended subsections basically inoperable. That is my understanding of it. For those reasons, we will not be supporting it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not agree with the analysis offered by Senator Short. Obviously, the regulations may or not provide these things. We are concerned that if the bill and schedule are passed as drafted, they are likely to be used. We simply want to make sure that before a person is refused access to the Australian system, the connection with a third safe country must be more substantive than is implied by the `or' which applies to one or the other.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule, page 3, item 1, lines 21 to 25, proposed subsection 91D(3), omit all the words and paragraphs after "about:", substitute the following paragraphs:

PARA.TAB: "(a)the compliance by the country, or each of the countries, with relevant international law concerning the protection of persons seeking asylum; and
(b)the meeting by the country, or each of the countries, of relevant human rights standards for the persons in relation to whom the country is prescribed as a safe third country; and
(c)the willingness of the country, or each of the countries, to allow any persons in relation to whom the country is prescribed as a safe third country:
(i)to go to the country; and
(ii)to remain in the country during the period in which any claim by the person for asylum is determined; and
(iii)if the person is determined to be a refugee while in the country—to remain in the country until a durable solution relating to the permanent settlement of the person is found.".

SPEECH.PARA: In effect, I spoke to this amendment when summing up the second reading debate. I will say nothing further.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government amendment follows the circulation at the outset of today of my committee stage amendments. This amendment deals basically with the same issues. I have discussed this matter with the government and I note the comments in the additional explanatory memorandum that has been circulated with the government's proposed amendment. Parts (a) and (b) of the amendment seek to effect a minor and technical amendment. We have no problems with that and agree with it.

PARA.TAB: Part (c) covers basically the same territory as is covered in part (c)(ii) of the coalition's amendment. I do not see any basic difference between the two. I understand that the government's amendment has been drafted in consultation with the parliamentary counsel. We would therefore be prepared to accept the government's amendment and withdraw ours on the basis that they basically do the same thing.

I point out, though, that the two amendments differ to the extent that the government amendment goes slightly further than our amendment in the sense that it introduces an additional requirement on the minister in relation to the things on which he has to report in the parliament when he is tabling. I would have thought it a somewhat surprising extension, but we agree with it. To the extent that the bill relates to asylum seekers, as distinct from refugees, this addition does imply that, at least in part, it extends to refugees—namely, someone who has been determined as a refugee in the safe third country. We think that is sensible and agree with it. I just draw that to the attention of the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats welcome the government's amendment as an improvement to an otherwise unsatisfactory bill. We would have supported the coalition's amendment, so we will support this one.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule, page 3, item 1, proposed subsection 91D(4), line 27, omit "3 years", substitute "2 years".

This amendment refers to proposed section 91D(4) and seeks to replace `3 years', which currently applies when a safe third country is so designated by regulation, with `2 years'. We move this amendment because we are conscious of the fact that, particularly in our region, political and legal arrangements in various countries which could well be designated safe third countries under this legislation could change. We believe that three years is too long a period for a country to be so designated. A safety factor would be introduced if that period were reduced to two years. It is my understanding that the opposition may be supporting this amendment. Senator Chamarette has asked me to advise that the Greens will certainly be supporting it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief. This amendment was proposed by the UNHCR representative to the constitutional and legal affairs committee. I must confess that we did not feel terribly strongly about this matter, because it seems to us that the designation of safe third country can be rescinded at any time. The three years does not really have any particular significance. If one argues and accepts that proposition, then I guess that two years does not have any great significance either. In a spirit of cooperation, we are prepared to accept Senator Spindler's amendment, unless I hear from the government any overwhelming reasons as to why two years is fundamentally different from three years.

—I have to confess that the committee is not going to hear an overwhelming argument. We have a subjective assessment before us. There is nothing inherent in having three years or two years. The government's distinct preference is for three. I will rephrase it and we will vote against the amendment, but it is not a matter of such passion that we will call for a division. The key point was made by Senator Short and I accept the manner in which he made it. It is always open to the government to initiate a change at an earlier period than three years. That is not saying that we cannot change it in less than three years; it is simply the proposed outer limit—in effect, the sunset clause on a regulation. We think that as the outer limit it is quite reasonable. If it were a minimum, it would probably be too much. But there is flexibility and that flexibility will be exercised.

PARA.TAB: We think it is a quite significant and positive feature of the bill that a sunset clause will operate after three years. I understand the wish of the committee and I am not going to waste its time. I am sure that the representatives of the UNHCR had genuine concerns that somehow or other there might be a lock-in that they would find unsatisfactory in the face of changed circumstances. This overlaps a bit with the discussion we will have on the next amendment. Although I do not agree with the amendment, I will certainly be giving some assurances about the flexibility with which we will respond to changed circumstances. I would have thought that those two things together were a satisfactory package. I cannot say other than a subjective assessment has been put before us and the majority of the committee does not agree with the government. While opposing the amendment, we will accept the decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the merits of the new committee system is that it does enable people to come along and give their views on legislation. In this instance, the representative of the UNHCR has done so. I have given the matter consideration, having seen the request and Senator Spindler's amendment. I will be voting for the amendment, together with Senator Short and the opposition.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule, page 3, item 1, at end of proposed subsection 91D(4), add the following subsection:

" `(5) If changes occur to a prescribed safe third country which adversely affect, or are likely to adversely affect, or are intended to adversely affect the protection of persons seeking asylum, regulations must be made to terminate the status of that country as a prescribed safe third country.".

This amendment in effect seeks to put into the legislation the commitment the government has foreshadowed that it will make changes at an early stage—and not wait until the now two-year period has elapsed—to the designation of a third safe country, if a change in circumstances requires that.

PARA.TAB: I understood the minister to say earlier that, while the government agrees with the principle, it may not be supporting the amendment. I find that rather curious. If the government means what it says, if it is prepared to accept that there may be circumstances which require action earlier than the designated period, I find it difficult to see why the government cannot accept this amendment. It is couched in the terms of an obligation on the government and would enable this chamber, and the parliament as a whole, to challenge the government when such circumstances arise to take the appropriate action.

TALK.START.PARA: —If we look at the wording of the proposed amendment we see that, meritorious as the underlying concern may well be, there is the capacity for a lawyers' bonanza and the possibility of endless litigation. If we say that regulations must be made in these subjective circumstances, we will be in the courts from now until forever about every such decision. It would be open to lawyers to argue that the minister had not exercised his legal obligation under this clause. We will then get the fine nuance being determined not by the Senate but by the courts as to whether we have a changed circumstance.

PARA.TAB: I am very happy to give the assurance that, if the situation in the prescribed safe third country were to change to such an extent that the conditions giving rise to its prescription no longer existed, the government would amend the regulations to remove that country forthwith. However, to be required to amend the regulations would create an unclear and uncertain circumstance and therefore would be bad law. It would raise the possibility of a proliferation of litigation. In effect, the problem at law is that it does not give citizens certainty as to the circumstances which face them.

In terms of the situation in the Senate and the Senate's capacity to review, the Senate will be unaffected in its capacity to review any regulation the government makes or to question, through question time or debate, the failure of the government to have enacted such a regulation, based on the assurance which I have just given. But including that clause would not in any way give more debating capacity to the Senate to pursue its interests in this matter. If the government were of the view—whether or not this amendment is passed—that such change of circumstances had not arisen, it would not introduce a change to the regulations, it would not be before the Senate, and a disallowance motion would not arise.

I do not think the clause would achieve that purpose. It would make the legal situation of the citizen uncertain, and that is not something we should lightly do. I accept the premise, but I do not think it makes good law to seek to make it a binding requirement in this way.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition has basically a similar view to the government in relation to this amendment. I say that after noting very carefully the assurance that Senator McMullan has given that the situation will be monitored and the legislation administered flexibly. Putting Senator Spindler's amendment into the bill would cause some uncertainty. I do not know how we would determine precisely when the changes were such that we had to act in terms of making regulations and so on. So, somewhat unusually, I again find myself agreeing with Senator McMullan.

PARA.TAB: But Senator Spindler has done well. He got amendment No. 2, which I think was his important one. The fact that this debate is linked with the bill and the act, and therefore in relation to the Acts Interpretation Act is given full weight, is sufficient for us to accept the government's undertaking.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to be offensive, but I think the assurance is second best to the actual amendment being passed and put in the bill. Let me assure the minister that the commitment made is noted and will certainly be acted upon. In other words, we will remind the government when the circumstances arise. This would indicate that the government should take the action that is foreshadowed.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Colston)—The question is that the schedule, as amended, be agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that no further amendments are before the chair, but I want to raise a couple of points in relation to the schedule and to seek some undertakings and an explanation from the minister. In regard to subparagraph 91D(3)(a), can the minister confirm that he explicitly stated in his summing up of the second reading debate that this subparagraph covers quite unequivocally article 33 of the international covenant dealing with the prohibition of expulsion or return—that is, refoulement?

PARA.TAB: The main reason we did not go ahead with the proposed amendment was that we were told that we could not have such a word as `refoulement' in an act in Australia. I am simply asking the minister to reconfirm what he may have said in the second reading debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did say that. I have just sought and received reassurance that that clause does cover the matters which he has raised.

—One of the concerns that was expressed by the UNHCR representative in the hearings of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs related to section 91F and the phrase `the public interest'. The UNHCR representative put various proposals to the committee for additional amendments to section 91F to include some additional matters.

PARA.TAB: I do not want to press that in the sense of proposing particular amendments, but I would like the minister's understanding of what is meant by `the public interest'. The point that the UNHCR representative made was particularly in relation to the question of compelling humanitarian reasons. It is possibly difficult to put that into legislation for a variety of reasons, but may we be told what is meant by `the public interest'?

TALK.START.PARA: —Such definitions can cause more problems than they solve and may limit the discretion in a circumstance where one wants to exercise it. What I did say in summing up the second reading debate—and I think it goes to the real concern people have about this phrase—is that it would include the circumstances where there are strong compassionate or humanitarian reasons for an exercising of the discretion.

PARA.TAB: I was not present at the committee hearings, but I understand that the underlying concern was for people to be reassured that those sorts of factors would be included. I did give that assurance and I repeat it now.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say a few words in relation to the second reading amendment that the Senate has passed. It was not possible for me to do it in committee because we had gone past it.

PARA.TAB: I am very pleased that the Senate has passed the amendment because—contrary to some of the comments that were made during the debate about the views, in particular, of the Vietnamese community in Australia in relation to this bill—I have had very strong representations from significant sections of the community in Australia about the point I am about to come to. The point I want to make is that that community took a very responsible attitude towards the bill. The community—and I quote from the letters received from all those people whose names I read out, the only exceptions being the two Vietnamese newspapers—said:

SPEECH.PARA: We share the government's concern on this matter.

They undertook to make sure that the community in Australia would do all in its power, if the amendment were passed, to discourage boat people from sailing to Australia. Let me quote from the letters that I have received which said:

TALK.START.PARA: —I began my contribution to this debate last night by stating the Democrats' view that this bill is a solution to a non-existent problem. I was emphasising the importance of leaving Australia Post in a position to properly fund its community service obligations and, in particular, services to remote and rural regions of Australia.

PARA.TAB: I also highlighted the generally undisputed fact that Australia Post is a high performing utility and that the push coming from some quarters for full deregulation is a poor reward for the staff who have lifted their productivity so much. In our view, the public would not gain a great deal, and in many cases they would lose.

Indeed, Australians in rural and remote Australia stand to lose even under the partial deregulation provided for in this bill. The problems that exist in Australia Post's service—for example, the low number of deliveries to some remote areas—cannot be solved by competition. To the contrary, increased competition will reduce Australia Post's ability to fund the increased level of service recommended by the Industry Commission.

In our view, the push for deregulation will not stop with the passage of this bill. One does not have to be Nostradamus to realise that Australia Post's reserved services will be further cut back as time goes on—particularly if the coalition ever wins office. This will put more pressure on Australia Post to cut services to remote and rural communities.

Indeed, the Democrats believe that this decline must be stopped and reversed, and the best way to do it is to set minimum performance standards to be met by Australia Post—particularly in unprofitable rural and remote communities which will not reap the benefits of competition. We will be moving an amendment which would allow the minister to set performance standards by regulation. Australia Post's performance against those standards would be measured by the Auditor-General and reported to parliament. Where Australia Post underperforms, it would have to develop service improvement plans to rectify the problems. Those plans would also be tabled.
