We believe that this scheme would provide a useful framework for the periodic review of remote and rural services which the minister has announced will be conducted by the House of Representatives Transport, Communications and Infrastructure Committee.

A concern has been expressed that our amendment pre-empts the committee's work, but this is entirely unfounded. This proposal would leave the minister free to consider the recommendations of the first committee review before drafting the regulations—surely a sensible provision. We are strongly of the view that our scheme provides an excellent framework by which services to remote and rural communities can be improved.

The opposition has plans to move an amendment which would require Australia Post to provide communities which receive roadside deliveries with at least two deliveries per week. As I said yesterday, we understand the aim of this amendment. However, we are concerned that the way it is drafted could actually reduce services to some communities to which twice-weekly deliveries are not feasible. It also could prevent communities that now receive no mail deliveries from getting a roadside service—again because a twice-weekly service was not feasible.

In our view, the best way to handle roadside deliveries is for the minister to set an appropriate performance standard following the committee review which I mentioned before. It must be said that there is an irony in the opposition's professed concern to improve services to rural and remote areas while, at the same time, it proposes amendments which, we believe, would cut further into Australia Post's reserved services. Those amendments are guaranteed to reduce Australia Post's capacity to fund its community service obligations. Although we, too, understand private sector concerns that the bill places artificial restrictions on competition, the fact is that the funding of community service obligations requires that a line be drawn somewhere. Wherever it is drawn, there will be pressure to push it back. We believe that is what the opposition's amendments try to do. Because we believe this bill exposes more than enough reserved services to competition, we will not be supporting further moves in that direction.

The Democrats are not convinced that there is a significant public benefit in the further deregulation of postal services, as proposed by this bill. In our view, the efficiency gains of increased competition will be minor, but the decline in services to rural and remote parts of Australia could be very significant. On the other hand, the Democrats believe as a matter of principle that those postal services which are now open to competition should remain so.

We have received representations from some firms in the direct mail industry suggesting that competition for the delivery of catalogues and leaflets will be more restricted by this bill than by the present act. We have held a number of discussions with the minister's office and the department on this question, and we believe they now understand our concerns.

The bill requires that, if a direct mail company wants to wrap a catalogue or leaflet and address it to a particular person, it can now use only plastic wrapping and not paper envelopes. This raises two concerns. Firstly, the act, as it stands, allows envelopes to be used and to take away that right seems unreasonable and contradictory. Secondly, the use of recycled paper instead of plastic would be prohibited, even though paper is an environmentally preferable alternative.

The arguments which have been put in favour of this new restriction are that it reserves part of the catalogue and leaflet market to Australia Post and that it allows the contents of private advertising mail-outs to be scrutinised to see whether they are legitimate exceptions to Australia Post's reserved services. We do not accept those arguments.

For one thing, a service which is now open should not be withdrawn from competition; and it is not clear to us that plastic wrapping will greatly assist enforcement. An addressed letter can easily be concealed by folding it or placing it inside the catalogue or leaflet. The fact is that Australia Post's best protection against illegal competition is its own employees, who, like the rest of us, receive advertising material in their letterboxes. We will be moving an amendment which clarifies the existing situation; namely, that catalogues and leaflets can be enclosed in addressed paper envelopes for delivery by direct mail firms.

Australia Post is understandably concerned that the definition of the word `leaflet' should not be stretched to include form letters. We agree with that view. There is a potential grey area between the definitions of a letter and a leaflet. But that grey area is not created by my amendment; it already exists in the act and the bill. Ultimately, it is up to the Federal Court to clarify the distinction.

The Democrats' final concern about this legislation is the summary power it confers on Australia Post's employees to destroy physically offensive mail articles. This seems to be an unjustifiably broad and unaccountable power. At the very least, the details of the article should be recorded before it is destroyed and the sender or addressee should be notified. We will be moving an amendment to that end.

As I said at the beginning of my speech, this bill is a solution to a non-existent problem. It has the potential to further undermine postal services to remote and rural areas, and our top priority is to prevent that from happening. We would see little benefit in the legislation if our amendment on performance standards was defeated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know there are only a couple of minutes left before the dinner suspension, but at least it gives me time to comment on Senator Woodley's speech. It seems as though we have the bob-each-way Democrats again. They say, `What the government is going to do is no good; what the coalition would do is worse; and only we the Democrats are fit to wear the halo of doing exactly the right thing for country people in Australia.'

PARA.TAB: I would like to remind Senator Woodley that, if the Democrats ever had a chance to put into place the policies they had prior to the last election, it would not be just the postal services that are adversely affected. Think what would have happened to rural and remote areas of Australia if the Democrats had put up the price of petrol by 18c a litre and increased other charges. There would not have been any rural industries left to deliver post to.

TALK.START.PARA: —You must not tell a half-truth.

—I am not telling a half-truth; that is a fact. The Democrats' policy was 18c a litre. I do not know how many rural businesses or rural homes would have been left for Australia Post to commit its community service obligations to.

PARA.TAB: It seems a long time since 25 August, when my colleagues Senator Alston, Senator Tierney and Senator Ian Macdonald spoke during the second reading stage of the Australian Postal Corporation Amendment Bill. I certainly support the comments they made in their speeches on 25 August.

It was in July of this year that the Business Council of Australia called on federal and state governments to make the Hilmer report proposals on exposing government enterprises to competition a top priority for economic reform. An Industry Commission report recognised Australia Post as one of the last government sheltered business enterprises in the country, particularly as it is one over which the Commonwealth has absolute and total responsibility. But it is clear from this bill that the government has chosen to take a softly, softly approach in the face of concerted campaigns of opposition by Australia Post and the Communications Workers Union—or the CEPU, as it has now become.

Because of concerns expressed by people involved in the communications industry—and we had a variety of people who had expressed concerns—this bill was sent to a Senate committee to assist in the consideration of it. I want to refer to some matters that were raised during those public hearings and matters that were brought before the committee by those interested parties. We have submissions on the public record from Streetfile and from the Post Office Agents Association. We had representatives on behalf of Ausdoc Ltd, Mayne Nickless and the Communications Workers Union, together with members of the Department of Communications and the Arts. It is only natural that there was a variety of points of view put forward, but some of the issues raised need to be highlighted. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: ATSIC AMENDMENT (INDIGENOUS LAND CORPORATION AND LAND FUND) BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 21 September, on motion by Senator Crowley:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the opening of the Constitutional Centenary Conference in June last year, Ms Matilda House, the chair of the Ngunnawal Local Aboriginal Council said:

SPEECH.PARA: The honour of Australia lies not only in negotiating a treaty with the indigenous people of the nation but also in recognising the civil, political and human rights of a people whose physical possession and sovereign rights over their country were violated.

The ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill 1994, which creates an indigenous land fund, reflects on the honour of this nation in the way the native title legislation did. Indeed, our complete response to the High Court's Mabo decision is about an honest acknowledgment of the past and a bold commitment to a fairer future.

PARA.TAB: Last year's native title legislation was part of the first and fundamental stage in the process of reconciliation. The creation of an indigenous land fund represents the next stage in meeting honourably our responsibilities as a nation. It goes to the very heart of the reconciliation process.

We have heard that there can be no reconciliation without justice. The Australian Democrats think that part of this justice requires an awareness by the entire Australian community of the historical, cultural, social and political significance of land and sea to indigenous people. This bill is about land. In making that point I explain that land for indigenous people means the whole environment: the lands, the water, the sea, the air, the flora and the fauna.

The Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation's key issues paper `Understanding Country' helps to explain why and in what ways the land and sea are significant features of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander societies. Indigenous people have a holistic view of land and sea; it is central to their heritage, their identity and their economic future. The historical fact is that we took that land from them. In the case of Torres Strait Islanders we are reminded of the particular significance not only of land but also of the marine environment.

I am sure that we all recall, for one reason or another, the passage of the Native Title Act 1993. It was historic. Most of us believed it was about honour and integrity. That act established a land fund for Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders. Underlying the creation of that indigenous land fund is the recognition of those people who have been dispossessed of their land and are unable to claim native title.

The bill before us this evening creates a new indigenous land fund under the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989. The fund will be enshrined in legislation, not regulation. One important feature of this land fund, unlike the one created in the Native Title Act, is that it allows money to be spent on land management on indigenous held land, not just those properties acquired under the fund. That is an important proposal. According to the chairperson of the United Nations working group on indigenous populations, Professor Erica-Irene Daes, there is a need for recognition of `indigenous people's right to own, control and use their lands and territories as well as recognition of their land tenure systems and institutions for the management of resources'.

The Democrats are committed to the provisions in this bill, which encourage self-sufficiency, environmental protection and sound land management. I do not think we can afford to overlook the significance and the importance of sustainable development of indigenous held land. The bill also encourages the use of Aboriginal labour, goods and services in undertaking these activities; a feature we are also committed to.

The Democrats believe that the principle of the right to self-determination must also be reflected in this bill—whether we are talking about the use of Aboriginal and Islander goods or allowing the Indigenous Land Corporation the flexibility to determine its strategies. Some of the changes suggested by the opposition deny the right of self-determination. I speak specifically of allowing the parliament to interfere unnecessarily to stall the implementation of a national strategy and to stop the purchase of land in regional areas.

The Liberals have said that, in the granting of land, the ILC must have regard to that grant's improving the health, housing and education of Aboriginal and Islander people. We are talking about land being granted. We cannot and should not attach what should be citizenship rights—basic rights to basic services such as housing, education and health—as conditions to the acquisition and management of land. The principle should be of equity. Other citizens have a right to expect such citizenship rights; so, too, should indigenous Australians. We should not have to trade it off for the acquisition of land. We should not prescribe different sets of conditions and standards for indigenous communities from those which apply to the rest of us.

Land is not about welfare; it is about rights. Nor is the social justice package a welfare measure. It will address outstanding issues such as education, housing and health—issues that we all agree need urgent attention. But let us not forget what this legislation is about. It is about land: its connection and spiritual relationship for Aboriginal people. For too long, in my view, we have failed to understand or we have undermined the significance of this relationship.

Nobody denies the urgent and desperate need for attention to matters such as Aboriginal health, which the opposition has pointed out. Many of us, including the Democrats, have made realistic suggestions about funding increases. We have done this after negotiation and consultation with different indigenous communities. Unfortunately, it has proven a very difficult area. It has taken this government and other governments a long time to act on the matter. My personal view is that we have not yet put in place the most appropriate structure for decision making and program delivery.

Let us not fool ourselves into thinking that land in itself will automatically solve the other problems facing Aboriginal people. We must acknowledge that the dispossession of land is at the centre of disempowerment and oppression of indigenous people in our country. That is what the opposition fails to see.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read my speech and find out how much they hold in Western Australia already.
—I do not think that Senator Panizza understands that. I think he sees land primarily as a commercial commodity. That is not the way that Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders see it.
—Can you sort out your policy; not invent our policy, Cheryl?

—I have said what I am saying. The Democrats are committed to the creation of the land fund. We are committed to consultation and self-determination. We support the composition of the Indigenous Land Corporation board. We think that the presence of ATSIC is an important part of a balanced structure and it is appropriate that a majority of the directors are Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders.

PARA.TAB: The government says that the establishment of a self-sustaining capital fund will provide a secure and ongoing source of funds to the ILC. This is fundamental to the success of the land fund. The Democrats have some reservations about the government's ability to meet this goal of self-sustainability. The government claims it can deliver sustainable real returns of four per cent for the fund. I will be asking for convincing evidence of this during the committee stage of the debate.

It is this concern about the sustainable nature of the fund that has prompted us to seek a constructive solution via wider investment powers with no increased risk. We do not seek to undermine the fund, nor to tie it to welfare principles. We genuinely seek to ensure that the maximum amount of money will be available to Aboriginal people for the implementation of this package, as promised, at the end of the 10 years. We genuinely hope that because we support the economic independence of Aboriginal people and a recognition of the importance of land.

I urge the opposition to support this legislation. I think that it might fail to appreciate how important it is to the process of reconciliation. We have said all along that we will not support amendments that are vexatious or unwarranted but, of course, we will engage in constructive debate on amendments. We have said all along that we will not compromise the process of justice and equity for indigenous Australians. Yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald editorial says:

SPEECH.PARA: There is a long list of amendments to the legislation that could be made and that some Aborigines will argue should be made.
It goes on to say that:
. . . a land fund doesn't preclude future negotiations over property rights or Aboriginal living standards.

That is an important point, although one wonders whether the current focus on Aboriginal issues will be maintained by future governments, especially if this land fund is defeated. The editorial poses a final question to be answered by the opposition, the Greens and the Democrats. It is:
whether the Government's legislation represents a prudent response to Mabo in present circumstances.
In the main, the Democrats think it does represent a prudent response. But we also have to wait and ask whether it is also a just response to Mabo in present circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —The ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill 1994 is a very important piece of legislation. Let it be clear from the outset that the coalition has a very strong commitment in this area. We very much recognise the extent of Aboriginal deprivation and disadvantage. I am sure most honourable senators in this chamber would at one time or another have travelled in the Northern Territory and in other parts of Australia and seen at first hand the conditions in which many Aboriginals still live.

PARA.TAB: As a regular visitor to the Northern Territory over a number of years, and certainly having travelled fairly extensively through outback Australia, I am very conscious of the need for this parliament to do what it can to assist that cause. But it does not follow that simply providing land necessarily brings about any improvement in the conditions of the indigenous population. Indeed, the experience of Bathurst and Melville islands, where the inhabitants were never dispossessed, is stark testimony to the fact that one does not necessarily end up any better off because one remains on one's own land.

Similarly, since the enactment of the land rights legislation in the Northern Territory in the mid-1970s, we have not seen a significant improvement for very many of those people, despite the fact that they have had the benefit of that legislation. So let there be no hypocrisy in this argument. The idea that somehow the government can call up land and then pretend that it is solving particular problems is simply misleading those who might be otherwise persuaded. The fact is that the government needs to do a great deal more. It needs to ensure that, in many respects, any acquisition of land is accompanied by a number of other major initiatives.

That is why we understood that the concept behind this bill was to assist those Aboriginal people who could not benefit from native title, having been previously dispossessed. Those people are said to constitute the vast proportion of the Aboriginal population—perhaps 90 to 95 per cent. It is understandable that they should be the ones who ought to be the principal beneficiaries of a land fund; but merely giving them land will not necessarily improve their condition.

It is our view that the bill does not address in an adequate way the unacceptable deprivation of Aboriginal people in Australia. If the government is serious about those matters, it will also want to ensure that any acquisition of land is accompanied by specific initiatives to improve such fundamental social indicators as health, education and housing. That is why we have said from the outset that the concept of Aboriginal health is a holistic one which encompasses the special and unique relationship that Aboriginal people have with the land and that, whilst land is important, it is simply no panacea in itself.

All of the moneys that have been spent over so many years which have been designed to bring about a measurable improvement in the state of the health of the Aboriginal population have, in many respects, not been very successful. So if the government is going down a new path and argues that land will somehow make a significant difference, unless it has regard to those crucial indicators, it will find yet again that it is a blind alley. Therefore, we very much want to hold the government to its original commitment that the fund ought to be available to those who do not otherwise qualify under the native title legislation.

It is said on behalf of the government that there may well be people who only benefit to a marginal extent, who may have what are called usufructuary rights, or rights of passage and easement over the land, and they should not be excluded. By all means they ought to be taken into account. They may well be those who get last priority after all those who have missed out altogether. But to ignore the distinction completely, as this bill does, is to essentially ignore the very reason for which it was proposed in the first instance.

That seems to be a fundamental shifting of ground which must give rise to a lot of concern on the part of those who genuinely believe that the purchase of land in certain circumstances can make a measurable difference. If it is going to make that measurable difference for those people who have missed out in the first instance, the legislation ought to reflect that commitment. So our first concern is that the purchase of land ought to be linked to attempts to ensure that other social benefits will flow from it.

It does not follow that if people own urban real estate their standard of living will be necessarily any better off. It certainly does not follow that, if they have chronic health conditions and little or no education, by putting roofs over their heads they will improve their standard of living. It will not because there are a range of other factors that have come into play and have caused them to be in that unhealthy state. Therefore, if we simply link the attempt to the purchase of land only, I think we are selling short those we seek to benefit. So our commitment is very real. We are very anxious to ensure that this legislation makes a significant difference. Therefore, the crucial linkage between health, housing, education and economic independence must be acknowledged if that deprivation is to be meaningfully addressed.

A number of other matters concern us in relation to the bill. But if one just takes, in a sense, a philosophical approach for a moment, a lot of the justification for special legislation designed to assist the Aboriginal people has been on the basis of what is sometimes called self-determination or self-improvement—giving them responsibility over their own affairs. I think that is a commendable initiative. Just as we often say about small business that people ought to have the right to fail, people can only ever make a significant and permanent improvement in their own conditions if they stand on their own two feet as much as possible and are encouraged to make their way in the world without the props of government assistance in the same way that welfare can often be counterproductive.

I think it can certainly be the case that if people have a paternalistic approach to disadvantage then they will tend to perpetuate it. That is why we take the view that it is very important that land that is made available ought to be made available under conditions that would enable the acquirers to dispose of the land if they believed that to be in their own best interests. After all, the land that they acquire under this legislation is not theirs by virtue of the fact that they have a deep, spiritual attachment to the land. It is theirs by way of a form of compensation. If that is the case, then that compensation ought to be theirs to do with what they will.

One would expect, and certainly hope, that they would have access to very good professional advice and that they would not rush into disposing of land or, indeed, any other possessions without making sure that they were aware of the consequences. Obviously, those monitoring the legislation and those within ATSIC will be taking a close look at how land which is purchased is used in practice. But that is no excuse for saying that, therefore, it needs to be purchased in the name of a corporation; it ought to be inalienable title; and those living on the land should not be able to directly control it.

Probably one of the best ways people can improve their individual well-being is to have their own home. That is why home ownership is at such a high level in this country. Most people recognise that if they have that personal, tangible possession they are well on the way to achieving a degree of income and personal security for themselves and their families. It is a matter for the Aboriginal community to make their own decisions in that regard. No-one is saying that they ought to be forced to own land individually, but it ought to be an option available to them. I suspect that in many instances they would prefer that. People do not share their wives and children. People like their own space. People are more than happy to share communal resources and to interact with their friends and relatives, but that does not mean that they should not be able to own their own possessions. Therefore, I think it is very important that there should be individual acquisition, ownership and responsibility. That is a major amendment that we would like to see made to this legislation.

There are other matters which I think are of particular concern to us. Certainly the composition of the board should be such that there are persons with business or financial skills. We do not have to talk to too many people in the Aboriginal community to realise that they themselves acknowledge the necessity to responsibly handle their own investments. Quite often these days they are required to act as fund managers and to invest substantial sums of money, which have been made available by way of a royalty or otherwise. If people are responsible for a land fund which will have $45 million, or $21 million in the first instance, over a period of time, building up to very substantial sums of money, the very least we ought to have are people on that board with business or financial skills. We also ought to take account of the interests of the states and the state land management systems and, to that extent, have someone on the board who is cognisant of the interest of the states. I think that would make a very valuable difference.

The upgrading of Aboriginal and pastoral properties to be given priority over the acquisition of land in areas where there are already substantial land holdings by Aboriginal people, again, ought to be a matter of commonsense. There is no point in people buying a second piece of land if they cannot maintain the first. If they are not able to make it productive it is simply not in their interests or anyone else's interests to, nonetheless, go ahead and acquire further land.

If those board members are trustees for the communities and individuals, as they should be, then their interest ought to be not just in the mere acquisition of the land but in ensuring that the land is used in the most productive manner. To do that, people need to ensure that the land is maintained, improved, upgraded, cared for and, if necessary, significant amounts of money should be spent in doing just that. At the end of the day, that is a much more productive use of resources than simply going off and buying more land. People are much better off to have a few improvements on a lesser amount of land—I can even recall that from my Monopoly days. People are better off to have two or three holdings with a couple of hotels on them than they are to have a whole range of properties where they are getting almost nominal rental. I think the same proposition can be properly applied here.

Moneys available to ATSIC for the purchase of land should be immediately transferred to the ILC because of the problems within ATSIC's land acquisition and management program. A very good suggestion that I know Senator Campbell has been pursuing diligently is the ability to place a caveat on the title so that the interests of third parties are protected. That system of land management has worked very successfully in state jurisdictions for very many years—certainly more years than I would like to recall in my time in the law. There is absolutely no reason why the principle could not be applied in this instance. It would be in the interests of all concerned.

There are a number of very important ways in which this legislation can be improved. In the interests of the beneficiaries, I think we have a responsibility to do just that. In many ways the government has already pulled a con trick on the community by pretending that somehow a billion dollars will be made available for land purchase. The reality, of course, is that over a period of 10 years or so we will build up a fund, but the amounts of money that will be available for purchase will be relatively modest—certainly in the early years. Therefore, it is critically important that the exercise be treated in such a way that we are able to look back on it and say, `Well, that was a successful experiment. That did make a measurable difference.'

If it is simply more money thrown at a festering problem, we can once again expect a community backlash in non-Aboriginal areas because, with the best will in the world, the taxpayer expects to see a return on the investment. In the same way, I think the Aboriginal community itself would like to think that at the end of any period we will be able to say, `This is the benefit that has been derived from that expenditure.' If it is simply the purchase of land without any concern for productivity or for the improvement of the beneficiaries, I do not think we will have a workable piece of legislation.

I hope very much that the government will reflect on the amendments that will be put forward and that it will operate in the spirit of much better will than we saw on the part of Mr Tickner, who, I think, in the first instance was prepared to reject all of our proposed amendments out of hand, certainly without consulting the Aboriginal community and without in any way having time to take advice from his department—in other words, playing politics to the hilt.

We simply do not accept the proposition that anyone has a mortgage on compassion, a mortgage on commonsense or a mortgage on concern for disadvantaged sections of the community. Our credentials are impeccable. We have a long history of achievement in government and we are determined to ensure that when legislation is introduced it is in the best interests of those that it purports to assist and is not simply there as a weapon that one political party can use to beat the other around the head with.

We will be looking very carefully to see whether the government is serious about improving this legislation and whether indeed it does consult widely. If it does, it will find that a number of our proposed amendments have very significant support in the Aboriginal community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: The land nourished them spiritually as well as materially. In the landscape and the life upon it they saw evidence of the epoch of creation. Down through the generations they passed on laws, customs, traditions and ceremonies reflecting an obligation to care for the land which went to the heart of their society.
The first European settlers declared that the land had belonged to no-one and the indigenous Australians were shunted aside, often with appalling brutality.
Much of the despair and degradation, conflict and disease, and many of the problems which Aboriginal Australians face today are a consequence of this dispossession.

I am echoing the words of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) during his address to the nation at the height of the native title debate last year, when he talked so eloquently about the dispossession of Australia's indigenous people. On the introduction of the Native Title Bill on 18 October last year, Mr Keating said that the bill would:

. . . make provision for a land acquisition fund to address the land needs of those Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people whose dispossession from their land means they will be unlikely to benefit from the Mabo decision

And so it did. Now, exactly a year later, I stand in this place and condemn the government for bringing a bill into the Senate which repeals part 10 of the Native Title Act 1993 and replaces it with amendments to the ATSIC Act which are a disgrace.

PARA.TAB: I am on the public record as saying that the bill is unacceptable in its current form, and I would like to reiterate that here and now and explain why. Firstly, the bill fails to live up to the government's promises. Where is the so-called `billion dollar fund' that the Prime Minister keeps talking about? It is a mirage. The fund will never actually leave the Commonwealth Public Account. Only the $45 million a year leaves the tight fists of the Minister for Finance to be available to Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders for the purchase of land and the management of that land through the government appointed Indigenous Land Corporation. This represents $124 a year for every Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander in Australia. It is a pittance and a disgrace.

This amount will not even come close to meeting the desperate land needs of dispossessed Aboriginal people across Australia. As the Prime Minister pointed out in a media statement on 30 June this year:

SPEECH.PARA: The native title legislation is fundamental to the process of addressing dispossession, and will benefit greatly those people who have been able to maintain a connection with their land sufficient to prove native title. Unfortunately, this will be a very small proportion of Aboriginal people, because the majority have been forced from their traditional lands.
The purpose of the Land Fund Bill is to enable indigenous people to acquire land, and to manage and maintain it in a sustainable way to provide economic, environmental, social and cultural benefits.
In a letter to me on the bill last week, the Prime Minister said:
It is the major financial component of social justice measures arising from the Mabo decision.

How dare the Prime Minister speak of a land fund to relieve the land needs of this country's indigenous people and then hand over only a pittance? Why does the Prime Minister not just admit what the government really did?

PARA.TAB: How can such a small amount have been deliberately set to this enormous and valuable task? A few simple calculations tell us that all the government did was double the existing land acquisition funds available to ATSIC and add $3 million for the administrative costs of the ILC. There really is no billion dollar fund. The fund is just a clever sleight of hand, played out by shifting pieces of paper around within the Department of Finance, but the government never has to front up with the actual money.

The government expends $1.49 billion on foreign aid each year. It provides a direct subsidy to mining and agriculture each year of over a billion dollars. The government is setting aside over $20 million a year on the athlete preparation strategy for the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games. I am sure that most people welcome this expenditure, and no-one would begrudge our fine athletes this valuable expenditure. However, it highlights the inadequacy of the money being provided by the government for the vast number of our indigenous people who have been dispossessed of their land. The Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans, stated during the Finance and Public Administration Committee hearing:

SPEECH.PARA: You can always argue about these quantums, and we would always like to do more, but I think most people have taken the view that this is really a pretty generous response to what is obviously a very major need.

At least Senator Kernot had the prudence herself to call it a prudent response. I think it is a disgraceful response. It is obviously a very major need which the government is meeting with a totally inadequate amount.

PARA.TAB: The government finds over $10 billion for the Australian Defence Force each year, or over eight per cent of entire government outlays. Yet the drain on the public account this year in real terms will be only $45 million, that is, 0.04 per cent of total government outlays.

Another significant problem which already faces ATSIC is that, as the amount of land required to be managed increases, so the amount of funds available to buy land will reduce. It already costs ATSIC around $9 million out of its $21 million just to manage the land it has already bought. Advice we have received points to the fact that ATSIC considered spending over $13 million on management this year but decided it could not afford that amount. The proportion of the funds spent on land management will have to increase as more land is acquired, meaning a diminishing amount will be left to acquire land. It is a bill of diminishing returns.

Incidentally, there is no mention of dispossession in the entire legislation. In my letter of reply to the Prime Minister last week, when he stated it was `the' fundamental amount of money they were going to give to this task, I said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the bill's operation will once again favour the least dispossessed indigenous people and the most dispossessed will once again be the most disadvantaged.

It is easy to envisage a time in just a few short years when there is no money left for acquisition because it is all being spent on managing the often economically marginal land which Aboriginal people desire. In simple terms, the Greens (WA) are concerned that the fund will not be sufficient to meet the land ownership needs of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. We are concerned that the fund will not be self-sustaining. We believe that the fund is unlikely to provide any degree of historical justice for the 95 per cent of Aboriginal people who will not gain anything from the recognition of native title.

PARA.TAB: We will be moving an amendment which would place one per cent of total Commonwealth government revenues in the land fund per annum for 10 years. This follows the example of the one per cent clause that was in the WA constitution. In 1890, when the British handed self-government to Western Australia, there was a clause placed in the constitution to ensure that the new government of Western Australia fulfilled its obligations to protect Aboriginal people. Under the clause, one per cent of total government revenue had to be spent on the indigenous people of Western Australia. The clause disappeared mysteriously in 1904. One per cent of total revenue would see a government contribute about $1.12 billion per annum—a genuine billion dollar fund. But it is not simply the amount of the fund that exposes the Prime Minister's rhetoric as simply that—rhetoric.

This bill is a great leap backwards for Aboriginal self-management. Under this bill, Aboriginal people are not respected enough to manage their own affairs. Despite a majority of the board of the ILC being indigenous people, the ILC is still a government bureaucracy and in no way can it be seen as an Aboriginal organisation. All members of the board are appointed by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs.

The Greens (WA) believe that the ILC needs to be as independent of government as is possible and if it is to address the needs and concerns of Australia's indigenous people, then it must work closely with existing Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations and consult fully when planning its programs. Consequently, we will be moving amendments which ensure that the Indigenous Land Corporation has the highest level of independence from government as possible.

The bill provides for the formulation of national and regional land strategies. However, it does not set out principles or guidelines as to how the ILC will function or how it will distribute its acquisition and management funding. This gives a large amount of power to a central bureaucracy. The bill may satisfy the government's concerns about accountability to the Minister for Finance, but where is the accountability to the Aboriginal community?

Unfortunately, it is a practical impossibility to create an organisation which accurately reflects the diversity of views, needs and desires of all Aboriginal people. In the light of this, the Greens (WA) believe that the ILC's land acquisition and management decisions should be based on the needs and aspirations of Aboriginal people as expressed through regional strategies. These regional strategies must be derived from consultation with every Aboriginal community around Australia on a regional basis.

Our amendments seek to make the regional strategies have precedence over the national strategy. The national strategy would be constructed on the basis of the regional strategies and the regional strategies would be drawn up, as I said, after full consultation and negotiation with all Aboriginal groups in a given region. The Indigenous Land Corporation board could then base its land acquisition and management decisions on those strategies.

Under the bill, the land fund is a trust account within the Commonwealth public account. As such, the fund is owned and controlled by the Commonwealth government. Investment of the money in the land fund is to be made by the Minister for Finance or his delegate within the Department of Finance or ATSIC. We see that the proposed structure of the land fund falls a long way short of the level of self-determination bestowed on the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory by the Fraser government in 1976 in the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976.

The New South Wales parliament passed legislation in the mid 1980s which allowed the New South Wales Land Council to manage a fund which will eventually be worth over $500 million. The New South Wales model allows 7 1/2 per cent of all land tax collected to be available for investment and immediate funding over a 10-year period. It is a much better example both of self-determination and of a self-sustaining fund. It also has a rationale that is not based on what we can afford; it is based on a legitimate percentage of land tax collected.

The Greens (WA) believe that the Indigenous Land Corporation should own and control the land fund. We see it as totally unacceptable that the ILC should be allowed to place any terms and conditions on grants to Aboriginal people. This is the most dangerous clause in the bill because it can be used to manipulate indigenous people. Our amendments would remove the capacity of the ILC to place terms and conditions on the grants and limit its capacity to place terms and conditions on loans and guarantees to repayments.

With the land acquisition fund bill the government wants to stop any of the land bought through it from being claimed under the Northern Territory land rights act. As we heard during the hearings of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration on this bill, this is to meet Paul Keating's commitment to Marshall Perron. But in order to not lose favour with the two Northern Territory land councils, the government is attempting to divert half the money available for land acquisition over the next three years through ATSIC away from the ILC and thus escape this commitment. The Greens (WA) see no reason why land acquired under this bill should not be claimable under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976. If this were the case, then there would be no need for a split of monies between the ILC and ATSIC.

We will be moving amendments to remove the restriction on claims under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 and alter the bill so that, as of the beginning of financial year 1995-96, all land fund monies should be made to the Indigenous Land Corporation and not ATSIC. We will also be moving an amendment to remove the sunset clause from the Northern Territory land rights act. It was the Hawke government which put in that sunset clause in 1987.

When in 1987, the then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Gerry Hand, in the Hawke government snuck subsection 50(2A) into the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976, an outer limit was placed on the processing of claims under that act. There was not a murmur against the move by any of the then senators—not Labor, Liberal or Democrat.

In those days it would appear that the parties in this place managed to match each other's policy positions on Aboriginal affairs. In fact, until then the Liberals could have rightly claimed a large stake in furthering the Aboriginal cause. As Chris Puplick, a former senator of this place, said in his recent book Is The Party Over:

SPEECH.PARA: It is . . . apparent that from at least 1962, through the 1967 referendum, the 1976 land rights legislation, the administration of Chaney and Baume, up until the ATSIC debate, the Liberal Party was rightly regarded as playing a major part in advancing the cause of the indigenous people of Australia.

But now at least in rhetoric, the ALP is way out in front. Perhaps this is an opportunity for the opposition to redraw its stand. The rhetoric of the ALP is certainly sounding pretty hollow at the moment.

PARA.TAB: The key principles underlying the amendments we will be moving on this bill are: Australia's indigenous people should enjoy the highest level of self-determination possible; they should be treated as equals and enjoy the same rights and responsibilities as anyone else in this country; any land returned to them should be handed over free from precondition; and we should take this opportunity to work towards the restoration of a historical justice for our indigenous people. There are many other areas in respect of which we will be moving amendments and I will speak to those during the committee stage.
I have an extract from the Aboriginal tent embassy press release of today summarising the things we find abhorrent about this bill. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: A meeting at the Aboriginal Tent Embassy discussed the indigenous land acquisition fund and found it to be a paternalistic and racist piece of legislation. It is to be controlled by the Minister for Finance and the Indigenous Land Corporation Board is appointed by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs . . .

Aboriginals question the motivation behind the Land Fund—That it is purely to appease the international community by appearing to provide one billion dollars compensation for the loss of the land by 95% of indigenous people unaffected by Native Title . . .
It ignores any Aboriginal Rights to self-government and self-determination and fails to meet the needs and aspirations of people in relation to land and compensation . . .
The federal government still refuses to relinquish its power and oppression over Aboriginal People.

The meeting also addressed the necessity for the Tent Embassy to remain, as a focus for Aboriginal Sovereign Claim and as a symbol of the living conditions endured by many Aboriginal people across the land. A central desert woman recently commented how `flash' the tent was: `My mob don't live in conditions as good as this.'

I believe that the Aboriginal tent embassy is a wonderful witness to the courage and survival of its people. I believe that that tent embassy should remain until all Aboriginal people—the indigenous people, the first people of this land—are living in conditions that are certainly far better than what we are seeing. However, it is not money but the principle of justice that we should be seeing at this time. Clarrie Isaacs, a well-known Ngungah, said to me recently:
You can keep your money, we want our land.
Why don't you use the money in the land fund to compensate the gudya who lose there land when we take it back.

Of course, in a sense that is precisely what is happening here except that the non-Aboriginals who lose their land will be doing so voluntarily through a sale. That sale will be provided by the fund. All that it would take to put Clarrie's vision in place is one small compulsory acquisition clause. I wonder how comfortable we would feel if we knew that all there was was $45 million a year to pay all of non-Aboriginal Australia compensation for the loss of the land we should give back. Robert Bropho, who appeared before the committee, said:
The $45 million is like a grain of sand against Ayres Rock compared with the $164 million that Mr Keating allocated to the farmers.

The Government can legislate and hand back the reserves that belong to the Aboriginal people. Those were the last bits of land that were set aside in the early days for the Aboriginal people to use. That should be given back—all crown land. You do not need money; you legislate.
He also said:

. . . we will be waiting forever and a day for land. With the little bit of money that has been allocated towards having this set up, a lot of people will be dying and going to the cemetery. The long continuous wait will go on forever and a day.

We cannot talk of reconciliation without the restoration of historical justice. On the government side, there appears to be an inverse proportion of political will to rhetoric. It has adopted the now familiar crash through or crash approach. What does this mean? Is the failure to consult not just Aboriginal people but also parliamentary colleagues the pure arrogance of executive power? Or is it that the government really does not care whether this bill passes or fails? Where is the commitment to Aboriginal people that Mr Keating talked about when, during his historic Redfern speech on 10 December 1992, he said:

Isn't it reasonable to say that if we can build a prosperous and remarkably harmonious multicultural society in Australia, surely we can find just solutions to the problems which beset the first Australians—the people to whom the most injustice has been done.
The Prime Minister's words are okay but this bill makes a mockery of them.(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill 1994 continues the legislation which was debated in this place almost 12 months ago. I wish to add my words to other words which have been spoken in this place and, by way of introduction, read from the overview which is contained in the explanatory memorandum in part A. The overview, in part, says:

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation is part of the Commonwealth's overall response to the High Court's historic Mabo decision and complements the Native Title Act 1993. As most indigenous Australians have been dispossessed of their lands, they have been prevented from meeting the criteria laid down in Mabo which requires a continuing connection with land or waters. This legislation represents a further significant step in reversing the process of dispossession which has been oncoming for over 200 years.

A little time ago, when this debate began, Senator Sandy Macdonald quoted some words from a poem which, in effect, said that we cannot compensate today for wrongs done long ago. Unfortunately, the wrongs which have been done were not simply done long ago but continue to the present day. There is a myth which seems to be common in the community that somehow or other the roots of this bill and the injustices perpetrated on the Aboriginal people go back 200 years and, therefore, we are not responsible. We often hear people saying that we cannot do anything about something which happened 206 years ago.

PARA.TAB: Tonight I want to place on the record my own experience of a little over 30 years of what has happened in my lifetime in my home state of Queensland; to say that the process of dispossession has been going on right up until the present day. It is not something which happened long ago; it is very much current.

Let me give a little history, at least going back to the late 1950s and early 1960s. I will tell honourable senators about a place called Mapoon in North Queensland, which was required by Comalco in order to mine bauxite. At the time, the Presbyterian Church was the administrator of that small community. The Presbyterian Church negotiated with the government and the company but consulted not at all with the Aboriginal people, who refused to shift from the small community at Mapoon. Early one morning in the early 1960s—I do not have the exact year—a boatload of police arrived at the community of Mapoon. The people were handcuffed at gun point; the houses, shop and church were burnt to the ground; and the people were scattered to the communities of Weipa South, New Mapoon and Thursday Island. I remember well the moderator of the Presbyterian Church and first moderator of the Uniting Church saying with great emotion that never again would he be part of a church which agreed to that kind of injustice.

Let me take honourable senators to 1975. In 1975 the Aurukun Associates Bill was passed through the Queensland parliament. It was a bill that granted even more land to the mining companies to add to what they had already acquired when they took over Mapoon and established the town of Weipa. The Aurukun Associates Bill, again without any consultation with Aboriginal people, granted further vast tracts of land to the mining company. This bill was challenged in the Supreme Court of Queensland by the Aboriginal people and they won their case there. The Queensland government took the issue to the High Court and again the Aboriginal people won. The Queensland government then appealed to the Privy Council, which was still possible in those days, and the Privy Council overturned the decision of the Supreme Court of Queensland and the High Court of Australia. On a technical legality, it granted the appeal of the Queensland government.

The Aborigines Act of 1971 had given absolute power to the director of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs to enter into a contract with anyone, including mining companies, with respect to Aboriginal reserve land. The director had no legal obligation to consult with Aborigines or to respect their wishes—and usually did not. In 1977, the Reverend Gordon Cootes and I, as a delegation from the Uniting Church, approached the director of the Department of Aboriginal and Islander Affairs, Mr Pat Killoran, and sought from him an assurance that the Uniting Church would be able to continue its work at the communities of Aurukun and Mornington Island. He gave us an absolute assurance that that would happen. However, a few months later, in March 1978, the Queensland government delivered a letter to the Uniting Church, giving it three weeks to quit its ministration of those two communities. I will read again from the overview, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth's specific objectives in establishing the Land Fund and the Indigenous Land Corporation are to enable indigenous people to acquire land and to manage it in a sustainable way to provide economic, social and cultural benefits.

That is a worthy objective. But I will give another little slice of Queensland history, coming closer to the present day, that again shows that this worthy objective, whether or not it is fulfilled by the bill, is at least needed. In the late 1970s and early 1980s, a Mr John Koowarta of the Aurukun community sought funding from the Commonwealth government to purchase a pastoral lease at Archer River Bend. The Queensland government opposed his taking over of the pastoral lease and negotiated with Comalco to purchase the lease instead.

PARA.TAB: The vendor, when he received an offer from Comalco, contacted the Uniting Church and said, `I want to sell to the Aboriginal community at Aurukun because they know this pastoral lease and they have done a good job when they've been working for me.' So he refused to sell to Comalco. The Premier at the time, Joh Bjelke-Petersen, wrote to the Prime Minister and said that he would not allow land rights by the backdoor. So the Racial Discrimination Act was applied, and the Queensland government challenged that act in the High Court.

It took some years before the act was tested. In the meantime, the government changed the pastoral lease to a national park lease. So even if Johnny Koowarta could have obtained justice, it would have been too late. In any case, after some years the Racial Discrimination Act was upheld and Johnny Koowarta's right to purchase the land was upheld. But by this time he had died.

Let me outline for the Senate some other history which again underlines the fact that we are not talking about injustice 200 years ago. We are talking about injustice which has continued up to the present day. In 1982 the Uniting Church's Commission for World Mission and the Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace, because of the conflict between Aboriginal people and mining companies at Aurukun, Mornington Island and Noonkanbah, commissioned a study into the contact between mining companies and Aboriginal people to help Aboriginal people understand the way in which mining companies were structured.

This study was eventually published as a book entitled Aborigines and Mining Companies in North Australia. However, in order to make it more accessible to Aboriginal people, the two church commissions had it published in a comic book form, with tapes in about seven Aboriginal languages and posters, et cetera. The Australian Mining Industry Council sued not the two church commissions but every Uniting Church moderator in every state of Australia, the Uniting Church president as well as every Catholic bishop in Australia. The churches caved in, I am sad to say, and agreed to destroy all the copies of the comic books, the tapes and the posters. This left a vacuum, which I believe allowed the Australian Mining Industry Council to mount a campaign against both the national Aboriginal land rights legislation, which had been promised by Bob Hawke, and also against land rights legislation in Western Australia.

However, I need to tell the Senate that not all church people have agreed at any time with the stance of the Uniting Church officials or of its commissions. Recently in Victoria a group was formed which calls itself `Galatians 3'. I will not go into the reasons behind its choosing that title. Recently this group, Galatians 3, had a conference in Melbourne. It had a number of very well-known speakers, such as Geoffrey Blainey; Dr Stephen Davis from Western Mining; Max Champion and Warren Clarnett, well-known members of the Uniting Church; Dr Ron Brunton and others.

I decided to check today with the Uniting Church in Victoria and discovered that this was a very small disgruntled minority in the church which had organised the conference. It had sought at different times to have its point of view placed before the Uniting Church national assembly and the Victorian synod but had been beaten on each occasion.

At the conference there were no Aboriginal speakers. No invitation was given to anyone in the Uniting Church to attend in an official capacity. But some friends of mine from the Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace attended the conference. The only Aborigines present were the ones who went with officials of the Catholic commission, and they included Vicki Walker and Graham Mundine.

The report I got from them today is that they were appalled by the racist attitudes expressed at this conference. I do not know whether the conference I have just described is the same one Senator Grant Tambling quoted extensively from in his speech yesterday. The interesting thing is that the same people were involved and the same quotes check out.

I was very interested to read what Senator Tambling had to say about the conference to which he referred. He said that at the conference there were damning statements that set out to address this particular issue and that he was attracted by some papers that were produced recently by a group of Christian leaders who were attempting to address this issue. I have no idea whether it is the same conference, but it does seem to correspond. If it was the same conference, I am concerned about the quality of the extensive evidence which Senator Tambling read into his speech.

The point I am trying to make is that, no matter what has been said in this place and certainly repeated ad nauseam outside this place about injustice to Aborigines being something that happened 200 years ago, those injustices continue. They are part of my history and part of the history of all senators in this place. It behoves us to take seriously what the government is seeking to do through this legislation, late as it is and perhaps small as it is. The Democrats, in principle at least—at the same time as wanting to do far more—nevertheless support this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition's view of this ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill 1994 is that it will be supported, with significant amendments. Before I go further, I would like to say, I guess, almost a cheerio as well as a vote of thanks to an old Senate colleague, Winston Crane, and his new wife, Thea Crane, who, at a very early stage of the coalition's consideration of amendments to this bill, were involved particularly with Senator Chris Ellison, with the shadow minister, Chris Gallus, with a range of other coalition members and senators, and with myself, in formulating a position on our amendments to this bill.

PARA.TAB: I had the pleasure of attending Winston's and Thea's wedding reception two Fridays ago at the Cottesloe Civic Centre. Winston made a point of telling me that he actually wanted me to incorporate a second reading speech, which I do not have yet. I want to pay tribute to the enormous effort that Winston and Thea put into particularly drafting some of the amendments and assisting us in putting them into some sort of order that would be available, first, for the debate in the House of Representatives and then for the committee stage here.

This debate got off to a very bad start when the coalition put together what I thought was a very positive and constructive approach to a land fund bill. We looked at the legislation the government finally presented to us in June to see whether it matched the rhetoric of the government back in December and found very quickly, as Senator Chamarette and a range of other senators have found, that the bill is indeed a deception of all Australian people, particularly of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, because it fails in a number of regards to match the government's rhetoric during the Mabo debate as to what it would do with the land fund. We set about quite constructively with a range of coalition members and senators who have a specific interest in these affairs, including the two former shadow ministers, Peter Nugent and Michael Wooldridge in the other place, to put together a very constructive package.

I listened to the contribution of Michael Wooldridge, who has a passionate interest in Aboriginal affairs, at the second reading stage of the bill in the House of Representatives. I saw a very angry man who had put weeks of his life into designing a set of amendments which would constructively reform this flawed piece of legislation. His anger reflected his frustration at knowing that the coalition had put up to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) a range of what we thought were constructive amendments that would empower Aboriginal people and get away from the legacy of an all-powerful bureaucracy controlling much of Aboriginal affairs policy in this country in a paternalistic manner.

Those amendments were rejected out of hand within some four or five minutes, clearly without any consultation with Aboriginal communities. The opposition understands that that out-of-hand rejection of our reforms of this bill was the work of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), who basically said, `No, we are not going to deal with the opposition on this. We are not going to discuss their amendments.'

The government finds itself in an interesting position now that the bill is in the Senate and finds a range of amendments which have broad support—some proposed by the opposition and a raft of amendments proposed by the Greens—and which all seek to empower Aboriginal people and create a land fund that earnestly seeks to redress some of the very significant problems suffered by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians.

I do not want to fall into the trap of traversing the many amendments that will be debated in this place over the coming days. I want to pick on some of the broad aspects of the bill that we think require reform and some of the positive aspects of the reforms proposed by the coalition. Last night, when Senator Cooney was addressing the second reading debate, I noticed that he read the preamble of the ATSIC Act—and he may well have read the preamble of the Native Title Act. He said, if I quote him correctly, `No-one has attempted to take it out.'

I remind the Senate that one of the fundamental features of the bill before us tonight is that, contrary to what Mr Keating has told the Australian people about the coalition's views on the native title legislation, the first move to make significant changes to the Native Title Act, only 10 months after it was passed through this very chamber late at night, has been made by the government. By effectively abolishing clause 201, the government is abolishing the land fund as it was originally intended under the Native Title Act. The government is also taking a red pen right through the heart of the preamble. I remind the Senate that, in relation to the land fund, the preamble specifically said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is also important to recognise that many Aboriginal peoples and Torres Strait Islanders, because they have been dispossessed of their traditional lands, will be unable to assert native title rights and interests and that a special fund needs to be established to assist them to acquire land.

The Finance and Public Administration Committee heard evidence to suggest that the only reason that the land fund is being taken out of the Native Title Act and put into the ATSIC bill is to effectively avoid the direction that the preamble provides to the land fund; that is, to assist those Aboriginals who are unable to assert native title rights.

PARA.TAB: I remember Senator Cheryl Kernot describing the preamble as a splendid preamble which should be incorporated in the constitution. The effect of what this government is doing is to take a red pen and run it through the preamble to the Native Title Act—a preamble which was regarded as sacrosanct back in December.

Senator Kernot has indicated that she will support this bill with virtually no amendment. So far, we have seen only a package of amendments from the Democrats that seek to change slightly the investment criteria of the fund, but we have seen no significant amendments to any other aspect of the bill. Senator Kernot is giving the bill the green flag and waving it through with virtually no amendments. She is complicit in ripping a knife through what she regarded as a splendid preamble.

That is at the core of a number of the opposition's concerns about this legislation. The legislation in no way seeks to assist those Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians who are suffering the most disadvantage and who have been most dispossessed. A range of our amendments seeks to address that situation.

I turn now to the straw man that has been built up by the government, by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, by the Prime Minister, and again tonight by Senator Kernot in saying that this is all about land and that health, housing and education are separate identifiable problems that are in no way associated with land. It is a straw man because the coalition's proposals simply make it a requirement that these important social goals for all Australians—citizenship rights and birthrights of all Australians, which is not the case for many Australians or for many Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians—be taken into consideration.

These goals should apply to all land that has been granted to Aboriginals in the Northern Territory and Western Australia. Senator Panizza reminded me earlier this evening that in Western Australia Aboriginal land made up a total land area equivalent to the combined land area of Victoria and Tasmania. That is a massive amount of land. Most Australians are aware that many Aboriginals suffer significant disadvantage, particularly in the area of health, housing and education.

The government has built up this straw man by saying, `The coalition says that unless it can be shown that they have demonstrable improvements in health, housing, education and economic viability, they will not be able to purchase the land.' We do not prescribe a check list of health, housing, education and economic viability before they can make an offer to purchase some land. That is not what is proposed. If the members of the government bothered to turn the cover page of the amendments, they would know that that is not what is proposed. I suggest that Senator Kernot knows that that is not what is proposed.

We propose the quite sensible proposition that some of these areas of disadvantage be taken into consideration when the Indigenous Land Corporation goes out and considers purchasing land. Where there is a choice in the matter, we are proposing that these important social goals for Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders—goals that all Australians would share—be taken into consideration when purchasing land. They certainly are not a prerequisite and they never have been.

Those who have not taken the time to read the coalition's amendments have been building up this straw man and knocking it over. They say the coalition is creating a reason not to support the bill. I put on the record again that the coalition will be supporting this bill as long as it seeks to redress the disadvantage that most Australians know Aboriginal Australians suffer.

Senator Chamarette made some very important points about the paternalistic nature of this fund. It is indeed a structure that ensures that the Indigenous Land Corporation maintains an interest and tight control over any land that it grants or any other activities for, as best we can determine, time immemorial. It ensures that virtually anything that goes on on that land requires the approval of the Indigenous Land Corporation. Unless the land granted to Aboriginals is given in good faith, unless they are allowed to develop it in their own way, to have a sense of ownership and to be able to determine for themselves how they use that land, the coalition believes that we are giving them something much less than all other Australians can enjoy.

Most other Australians can enjoy the right of owning some property in an unencumbered state. This bill creates a mechanism to ensure that if an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander person gains a grant of land from the Indigenous Land Corporation, then as a land holder that person will have an encumbrance against their title for the period that they enjoy that property right. That is less than what is enjoyed by other Australians. One of the purposes of the reforms that we seek to make to this bill is to ensure that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people do enjoy the same rights that all other Australian citizens seek to enjoy.

One of the other sad and paternalistic approaches this bill takes is to ensure that land can be granted only to corporations. I noted an article in the Australian, I think it was on 26 August, wherein Noel Pearson, the Chairman of the Cape York Land Council, referred to white structures being imposed on Aboriginal culture. And here we are in this bill imposing an Anglo-Saxon, Anglo-Celtic corporate concept on Aboriginal communities.

As has been outlined by a number of my colleagues, we seek in our amendments to ensure that the ILC has the flexibility to ensure that land and assistance can be granted not only to a body corporate or a corporation but also to individuals, persons, partnerships and trusts, something that we consider is an important empowerment of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians—again putting them on the same footing as Australians with European heritage and not discriminating against them by saying, `You can hold land only if you are a corporation.' We believe that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders as individuals should have the freedom and the flexibility to hold that land.

We have also looked at the problems created by the foundation of two funds. Most Australians, if we stand around at a barbecue or a pub and have a beer and talk about Aboriginal affairs policy with them—and just about everyone has an opinion on it—will tell us that there are billions of dollars going into Aboriginal affairs, that it all seems to get sucked up by the bureaucracy in Canberra and that very little of it seems to get down to the cliff face or into the communities to solve the problems that these Aboriginal people suffer. We only need to travel to Kalgoorlie, or Roebourne, or Meekatharra, or Carnarvon, or Broome or Fitzroy Crossing to see the plight of many Aboriginal Australians who really do suffer in comparison to the majority of Australians who enjoy a good living standard.

The average Australian standing around a backyard barbecue or leaning up against the bar at a pub having a beer will tell us that that is the problem. So what does the government do when it sets about redressing some of the disadvantages of Aboriginal people in granting them land? Instead of setting up one bureaucracy to deal with land, it establishes two. This bill clearly establishes the existing administrative and bureaucratic regime of the ATSIC land organisation and then creates a new one called the Indigenous Land Corporation. So for the next three years we have two—not one—land administration regimes in Canberra for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, with all of the cost of the administrative and bureaucratic burden that will be met from that.

Every dollar and every cent that will go into the additional expenditure required to run the two bureaucracies will be another dollar and another cent that will not go towards helping Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to purchase land, to get land management advice or to upgrade existing properties. It is money which will, in the quite proper perception of the average Australian leaning up against the bar, be sucked up by the Canberra bureaucracy and not help one Aboriginal person.

There are some other matters that I wanted to deal with. One of them was raised in the Finance and Public Administration Committee's consideration of this bill. It was a matter raised by a Northern Territory minister—I think it was Mr Hatton—who said that he believed that business principles should apply to all of the decisions of the Indigenous Land Corporation. Mr Dillon, the bureaucrat from the Attorney-General's Department who was left to deal with the committee's hearing during the afternoon, defended the fact that a range of the corporation's activities would not require business principles to apply by saying that, in some cultural and education considerations, business principles should not be required to apply. Again, that is a quite dangerous approach to take when what we are really seeking to do is to assist many Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to overcome disadvantage.

Even without a requirement, and even if the corporation is undertaking a non-profit operation or an educational activity, there is nothing to say that we should not apply sound business principles. There are many sound business principles that apply to non-profit organisations and voluntary organisations and those principles should apply. Unless they do apply, the Indigenous Land Corporation will come under the same cloud that many of the operations of ATSIC have come under over the years—the doubt many people have about the credibility of ATSIC when it comes to handling money and a range of other accountability problems that have been raised from time to time about that organisation.

The consultation process in relation to this bill is something that has also been of serious concern to the coalition. We took evidence on the Senate Legislative and General Purpose Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration in relation to that lack of consultation. I sought specific details from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet as to the consultations it made. It is quite clear from the list that it provided to us that the consultations were effectively with the inner sanctum of the Prime Minister, the minister for Aboriginal affairs, and his advisers.

This government and this Prime Minister seek to consult with those Aboriginal groups which reflect the views of the government and which quite often receive financial benefit from that government. They exclude those who do not agree with their views. Sprinkled through this bill is the same consultation processes. So when it comes to regional strategies there is only one group that is required to be consulted—the ATSIC regional councillors—ignoring all the other people who have an interest in that area.

We believe that the whole process of the formulation of this bill was flawed. We believe that consultations were not wide enough. We believe that the bill does require reform. We look forward to the committee stage debate of this bill where, we believe, a number of the Green amendments and a number of the coalition amendments will improve this bill. We hope that the government will put an end to its dogmatic and dog in the manger approach to not accepting any of our amendments.
