SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw Sen M.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some years ago in the late 1970s the decision of Justice Blackburn in Milirrpum v. Nabalco Pty Ltd and the Commonwealth of Australia, otherwise known as the Gove land rights case, was required reading for law students. I can recall the reaction that I and many fellow students at that time had to the doctrine enunciated in that decision. It was one of disbelief.

PARA.TAB: The doctrine was terra nullius. It was a doctrine that held that prior to European settlement nobody owned the land in this country. It was a doctrine that meant that because Aborigines did not mount a full-scale armed struggle against white settlement they therefore had no property rights to lose. It was a doctrine that said that this land was settled, not invaded, and therefore the existing inhabitants at the time and their descendants had no legitimate claim to having been deprived of their land.

Most people today recognise that this doctrine was flawed. In fact, it was really an excuse to legitimise the dispossession of land from its traditional owners and, more importantly, to legitimise that dispossession without compensation being duly paid. Thus the Mabo decision in 1992 was certainly historic. It overturned terra nullius and forced us as a nation, as a people, as a government, to come to terms with the issue of traditional ownership and dispossession.

It has also meant that finally we have had to recognise what the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have been saying for so long and what has been largely ignored for so long—that is, land is of fundamental importance to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, to their history, to their culture and to their existence. This relationship with the land was so eloquently expressed by Mick Dodson, of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: To fully understand why land rights are so important to indigenous peoples, you have to move out of the paradigm that sees land as purely a commodity to be exploited . . . For us, land has a spiritual, cultural, political and economic value. It supports our identity, our spirit, our social relations, our integrity and our survival. Land is the source of our physical and spiritual sustenance. Removed from our land we are literally removed from ourselves.

It is a mark of our time that non-Aboriginal Australians today are increasingly recognising and appreciating the importance of the relationship that Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders have with the land.

PARA.TAB: The ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill is the next stage in the process which began with that historic Mabo decision in 1992. Just as was the case with the Native Title Act, the land fund bill has been brought to fruition after an extensive and exhaustive process of consultation. This extensive consultation has been undertaken by the government not just because it is integral to good legislation but also because it is an inherent part of the overall process of reconciliation. The government did not come to the table with a fait accompli. There was a real determination to consult, to consult widely and to arrive at a consensus position. The various Aboriginal communities, the farmers, the miners, the state governments, the major groups and those who wished to be involved were involved in the process.

It is a shame, therefore, that consensus of that nature, such broad-based community support, is not enough for the opposition. The opposition's definition of consensus is really to appease a few reactionary state premiers and other rednecks who have never accepted the Mabo decision. On this most important issue, an issue which goes to our nation's integrity, the opposition has clearly failed. It has abandoned the bipartisan approach that existed in the parliament just prior to the last election. Moreover, its leaders walked away from that bipartisan approach simply to shore up support with the reactionary elements of the coalition parties. Sadly, the decent members of the opposition, those who have in the past taken a reasonable and responsible approach to Aboriginal affairs, have been muzzled.

So what, then, is the approach of the opposition to the land fund bill? How does it respond to this bill, which is specifically about land, which aims to provide justice and which is directed to those who have been dispossessed but are unable to pursue a successful Mabo-style claim under the Native Title Act? The opposition tries to shift the entire focus of this bill on to other issues. Rather than deal with the actual purpose of the bill, the opposition seeks to negate its fundamental importance by introducing a range of other issues, particularly Aboriginal health, education and housing.

The government recognises the importance of these issues and recognises that things must be done in these areas, but the land fund bill should not be emasculated by trying to broaden its scope, thus undermining its essential purpose. Members of the opposition, indeed all senators, should take note of the editorial in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The land fund then is a matter of justice, not welfare. Aborigines are entitled to welfare because of the continuing social and economic disadvantage they experience. They are entitled to the land fund as just compensation for past dispossession and dispersal from their land.
This is the Sydney Morning Herald saying this—no great friend of the Labor government. To continue:

To demand, as the Opposition does, that land purchased under the new fund be used to improve Aboriginal welfare is to confuse these two principles. It is also to deny that Aborigines regard their acquisition of land as a good thing in itself.
Unfortunately, the opposition is not interested in what this bill is really about. Indeed, its whole approach to this legislation demonstrates that it is engaged in a grubby tactical exercise.

PARA.TAB: It is clear from the progress of the debate in the other place and in this chamber that the opposition's amendments have been cobbled together on the run without any consultation with the people affected. The real intention of the opposition's amendment is to scuttle the bill. It knows that the amendments are unacceptable to Aboriginal groups and to the government. The amendments are a device intended to give the opposition a way of voting against the legislation but still postulating that it is committed to reconciliation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you read the amendments?
—You are compounding the disorder, Senator Kemp.
—The specific details of the bill regarding the establishment of the land fund and the Indigenous Land Corporation have already been canvassed by earlier speakers.

PARA.TAB: I know that certain senators—we have heard particularly from the Greens—are concerned that the amount to be allocated is too low and are therefore considering voting against the bill. Many of us would like to provide more money both for the purpose of this bill and for other areas of need. The amount to be allocated to the land fund, in excess of $1 billion over 10 years, is not insignificant. But of course the irony is that, if those who believe the fund should contain more money decide to vote against the bill, they will form an unholy alliance with those who are opposed to a land fund and who criticise such expenditure as a waste of money.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who are they?

—I will tell Senator Campbell. Yesterday a number of opposition senators raised the spectre that this land fund is a waste of public money. Senator Tambling, in a rather insulting, disgraceful remark, warned that we must take special care that the Aboriginal communities do not waste the money of the land fund. That is the usual cry of the opposition.

PARA.TAB: It is a paternalistic, hypocritical approach to attack Aboriginal groups and Aboriginal people who are seeking to come to grips with the immense problems that their communities face. Previous governments and administrations of various political persuasions have had a sorry record of dealing with these issues over 200 years. We have no right to make such gratuitous assumptions, as Senator Tambling did, about how indigenous people will manage their own affairs.
In the debate Senator Panizza also talked about the supposed waste of money. He said, `They are throwing money at them.' He went on to lecture us as to what we should do in health and education.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!
—We all recall, Senator Kemp, the infamous visit of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) to a number of Aboriginal communities in the Northern Territory in August this year.
—We remember Graham Richardson going there too.

—Just wait and listen. During that visit the Leader of the Opposition reversed opposition policy on Aboriginal issues on a number of occasions. In trying to resurrect his tattered public image, he attacked the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the government on Aboriginal education, health and housing.

PARA.TAB: Whilst the Leader of the Opposition was no doubt distressed by what he saw, his rhetoric was not matched by action. At that time the Leader of the Opposition visited the Yuendumu community just outside Alice Springs. The following week—within a matter of seven days—the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training visited that same community as part of its inquiry into open learning. It looked at the problems associated with education for Aborigines living in remote communities.

How many opposition members attended that hearing, where members of the Aboriginal community at Yuendumu spoke directly to committee members about their problems? How many opposition members were at that hearing in Yuendumu? The answer is not one.

The opposition was unable to get a single coalition senator to attend an inquiry specifically looking at this vital issue of Aboriginal education that the Leader of the Opposition berates us about. How then can we take the opposition's amendments and the opposition leader's statements seriously? I also draw attention to the remarks of Senator Sandy Macdonald. In his speech, he stated:

SPEECH.PARA: It is a fact of history, mostly unfortunate, that people and peoples are overtaken by events outside their control. Such an event occurred when Europeans came to this land. From our European heritage we have formed one of the most tolerant, inclusive and decent countries of the world.

The problem with opposition members is that, whenever we deal with issues that are peculiar to Australia, they cannot help referring to England and Europe. No matter how well intentioned some of them might be on Aboriginal affairs, they simply cannot bring themselves to acknowledge the rich Aboriginal heritage of this country—a people who exemplify tolerance and decency in the face of decades of intolerance, exclusion and exploitation.

PARA.TAB: In his closing remarks, Senator Sandy Macdonald quoted from William Wordsworth. I am a great admirer of English literature but I would have thought that quoting from an 18th century romantic poet who spent most of his time in the Lake District in England was largely irrelevant to this debate. But it does demonstrate how far removed from the real issues Senator Macdonald is. Of course, the Lake District in England is a long way from Arnhem Land or the streets of Redfern. It would have been far more appropriate for Senator Sandy Macdonald to have quoted from Kevin Gilbert, Oodgeroo Noonuckle or Archie Roach. Senator Macdonald would then have more fully understood what the struggle of the Aboriginal people has been about.

The outcome of this legislation and the Native Title Act is the outcome of a long struggle by indigenous people to achieve justice and equity with respect to land. It is a struggle that has gone on for some time and will continue.

In 1966, the Gurindji people commenced a strike at Wave Hill station in support of their claim for tribal land at Wattie Creek in the Northern Territory. They took on the might of Vestey Ltd, the giant British pastoral company, which at that time leased much of the Gurindji's traditional land. They were headed by Vincent Lingiarri, a man of gentle persuasion, a tolerant man, but a man with a fierce determination to see justice for his people. The struggle lasted from 1966 to 1975, when the Aboriginal Land Fund Commission purchased 3,250 square kilometres of Wave Hill station and handed it over to the tribe. The struggle of Vincent Lingiarri and the Gurindji people is well recounted in Paul Kelly's moving song From Little Things, Big Things Grow.

The historic High Court decision in Mabo, the Native Title Act and now the land fund bill have a similar history. These historic landmarks had their genesis back in May 1982, with the claim before the High Court by Eddie Mabo on behalf of the Meriam people in the Murray Islands. In geographic terms, it was a small claim but out of this long struggle have come profound and lasting effects upon this nation and its people.

This bill today is an essential step along the way in the wider process of reconciliation and recognition of land rights. It is essential that this bill be passed. We have a clear duty to Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders and to all Australians to pass this legislation. Having overturned terra nullius, having recognised native title, having given Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders an expectation that justice will be delivered, we cannot now close the door in their faces. If we do not pass this bill and if the land fund is not established, we will do significant damage to the hopes and aspirations of indigenous people and, therefore, damage to our nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill 1994. It was fascinating to listen to Senator Forshaw's contribution because, quite clearly, he has very little understanding of what the bill will do and no understanding whatsoever of the coalition amendments. It would have been quite advantageous if he had bothered to spend a little time prior to his contribution tonight reading the amendments so as to understand their basic thrust. If he did so, he might have realised that the coalition's amendments will benefit Aboriginal Australians, who demand that some of these amendments be agreed to. Be that as it may, as is quite often typical in a situation such as this, the Labor Party is so blinkered by its ideological bent that it cannot take anything outside the four dots into consideration.

PARA.TAB: If the federal government thought that its Native Title Act did not go far enough in killing off states' rights in terms of the Aboriginal land rights issue, then this bill will go the rest of the way to finishing off the job. From the 1982 Koowarta case in Queensland to the Mabo case some 10 years later, the issue of Aboriginal affairs, particularly land ownership, has seen a very steady erosion of the states' rights to legislate on land management, which is rightfully their area under the provision of the Australian constitution. Unfortunately, that is an issue that is consistently forgotten by this Labor government. I hope that, sooner or later, the government will recall that the states do have such control over this issue. Ron Castan QC, part-time commissioner of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, said:

SPEECH.PARA: There seems no limit to the kind of laws that may be passed by the Federal Parliament to benefit Aboriginal people. Any federal laws relating to Aborigines will prevail against any conflicting state laws.

That comment, which was published in the Age of 25 May 1992, is as relevant today as it was then. This legislation makes a lot of promises to Aboriginal people. It will give them the right to claim land in cases where they are unable to demonstrate an ongoing connection with the land and it will provide them with money to acquire and maintain that land.

PARA.TAB: One of the main features of this fund is that allegedly it will allow for the investment of fund money in order that the fund will become self-sustaining and that it will provide ongoing economic, environmental, social and cultural benefits to Aboriginal people. The initial funding, which is a substantial amount, will be $200 million in 1994-95 and $121 million indexed for nine years to a total allocation of $1.463 billion over a period of 10 years.

The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) describes this as a measure of justice to indigenous Australians, but in the long run it may prove to be little more than a smoke and mirrors illusion with the possibility that responsibility for funding may eventually come crashing down on the state and territory governments. I have heard absolutely no guarantees to the contrary. The minister claims that it is part of the government's efforts to work towards establishing a new relationship between Australia's indigenous people and the wider community—a relationship in which Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander culture is protected and valued and a relationship in which indigenous people participate fully in Australian economic life.

As my colleague Senator Panizza said last night, what will throwing money around for land possibly achieve for indigenous people in the areas of health and general living conditions? As I said before, Senator Forshaw made it his business not to read the very substantial amendments that the coalition is putting up.

Will this bill alleviate the fact that Aborigines have a mortality rate four times greater than the total population; that Aborigines live 15 to 17 years less than the rest of the population; that the Aboriginal infant and peri-natal rates are three times the national rate; and that Aborigines are three times more likely to be hospitalised? Will this bill resolve that? The answer is no, it will not.

How will this bill resolve the fact that Aborigines remain 18 times more likely to end up in prison and that just 23 per cent of Aborigines between 15 and 24 attend an educational institution? Do we ever hear a squeak out of the Labor Party about the way in which these problems can be resolved? No, we do not.

The contributions that I have heard thus far from the Labor Party have not even attempted to focus on these major problems confronting the Aboriginal communities in Australia today. Quite simply, this bill does not focus on those problems. I do not see any benefits for these areas which could flow on from either the High Court's Mabo decision or this new legislation concerning the land fund or the Indigenous Land Corporation.

Where are the government's policies and measures to address these problems? We have asked repeatedly throughout the Mabo debate and many other debates in this parliament over a number of years, and we ask again in this debate: where are the measures addressed to solve these problems? Why does the government commit $500 million over five years to the health of Australia's 270,000 Aborigines and $1.4 billion to land? That is an appalling contrast. How can this government honestly come into this parliament and go out into the Australian community with that sort of record? The funding for health pales into insignificance by comparison.

In her second reading speech on this bill, the Minister for Family Services, Senator Crowley, told the Senate that the coalition had expressed opposition to the bill, saying there were higher priorities in Aboriginal affairs. Her answer to the coalition's concerns was that, while there is still a great many things to be done, land ownership would be fundamental to the wellbeing of the indigenous community and that the required benefits would flow from the reattachment of indigenous people to the land.

She said that the opposition should be swayed in the interests of justice and in the cause of righting historical wrongs in the hope that Australia could be delivered into the future without the scars and stigmas of the past. What a whole lot of hyperbole coming from a senator who also is a medical practitioner. It shows just scant regard for the major problems confronted by the Australian Aboriginal community today to say that, somehow, giving land will solve these problems.

We will never, ever be free from these scars. Like the traditional and ritualistic scarring of the Aboriginal people, we have these scars forever. Just throwing land and money at the Aboriginal people will not heal one single, solitary scar. The only way we can deliver ourselves is to offer indigenous communities better access to all services: health, education, justice, and better standards of living. Just simple things like giving them better shelter and better quality water would be a start. But does this government bother to look at those issues? The answer is no.

In the West Australian on 12 October there were reports on Oombulgurri, a remote Aboriginal community in the Kimberleys, the northernmost region of Western Australia. Oombulgurri covers 500,000 hectares and was formerly an Anglican mission. It is claimed in that report that Oombulgurri is the most poorly resourced community in Western Australia and that the 250 residents live in Third World conditions—and that is no exaggeration. What is the government doing about it? Nothing! Houses are overflowing with sewage. The rate of infestation from scabies, threadworm, hookworm and trachoma is chronic. Other infections include: gastroenteritis; ear infection; chronic diarrhoea; chest infection; skin infection; and, of course, sexually transmitted diseases. What is the government doing about any of that? Nothing! It is throwing land and money at the problem. It is not resolving a single, major problem affecting Aboriginal communities today.

Set in an environment of extreme heat and humidity, with flies galore, the spread of infection is easily facilitated by inadequate housing and hygiene facilities. Is that problem addressed in this bill? No, it is not. The one outdoor sink in Oombulgurri is used by all the residents to wash dishes, prepare food, wash children and do the laundry. Does this government honestly believe that that is an adequate environment in which Aboriginal communities can be expected and demanded to live? I think it is an appalling situation that this bill is before the parliament and none of these considerations are even given the slightest thought in legislative terms.

The statistics for this community are even more alarming than the national rate. The incidence of diabetes is reported at 25 times the state's average, and life expectancy is at least 20 years below that of non-Aborigines. There are few men over 45 years. Most have died of alcohol-related illness or accidents. Most women over 30 are diabetic and have high blood pressure, and the oldest woman is 67 years of age.

In Halls Creek, it is estimated, 85 per cent of the town's Aboriginal population are locked in an alcoholic miasma. Last year the town's two liquor outlets sold 146,000 litres of cask wine, or 90 casks per day, to the town's less than 3,000-strong Aboriginal population. What is this government doing about the problem of alcoholism in Aboriginal communities? Nothing. There are countless communities like this one and like Oombulgurri. These people would not experience a boom in their standards of living if they suddenly acquired the land they lived on. It is not going to solve the problem.

I wonder how many times we have to stand in this place or go out among those communities and spell this out, because somehow or another we cannot get the message through to the Labor government that these are the major problems affecting Aboriginal communities. They need clean water. They need refrigerators to store fresh, healthy food. They need an extensive education and a preventive health program, including education on diet and nutrition. They need to be taught in order that they can pass on their knowledge to their children as in the times of old. Not only that—they want to be taught. They want to have these facilities. Is this government delivering them? No, it is not. They need to be able to identify important health issues, including alcoholism, and then to solve the problem. This requires money and a collaborative approach with the states and territories, not one which simply rips the reins from the hands of the state or territory governments. That is what we are seeing repeatedly put into place by this government—overriding effects over the Aboriginal communities, the states and the territories.

In the July-August edition of Quadrant of this year, John Hirst, a historian from La Trobe University, described land rights as one of the five fallacies about Aboriginal policy. In his essay, he described land rights as a cure-all and argued that the 20 years experience of land rights in the Northern Territory demonstrated that traditional land ownership did not guarantee that Aborigines could become self-supporting. He attributed the failings to the fact that the land which is guaranteed and/or acquired is usually non-productive and that it is in too remote a location for government assisted projects to be of any real benefit. He described land grants as islands of despair. I think, quite frankly, that is very apt. He said that Canberra can regulate life but it certainly cannot create it. That is equally true.

Mr Hirst said that it is not so much prejudice that is burdening indigenous people but the flawed assumptions upon which the federal government bases its policies for the indigenous. True again. How quickly the government lays the blame on white prejudice, in particular the coalition's alleged prejudice, rather than examining its own policy foundations and policy flaws.

Giving land is a populist approach based upon the flawed assumption that land rights is a cure-all. It may go part way to assisting outback Aborigines, but it does not, on the whole, solve the kinds of problems that I have outlined. How ironic it would be if the vast amounts of money being thrown into this fund were to perpetuate the problems in the areas of health and general welfare. It is, therefore, imperative that funding for grants of land is accompanied by a guarantee that indigenous community living standards will be significantly improved. The coalition wants demonstrable benefits, and that is the basis for one of our major amendments. All we ask the government to do is demonstrate that it is prepared to undertake that course of action. Sadly, from the contributions that we have heard so far, that is not going to be the case.

We also want to see accountability. It is a real concern that the ILC in its present form lacks the accountability which would ordinarily be required of any department with a large budget. Currently, there is no requirement for the ILC to develop strategies which stand up to scrutiny, although its powers are quite extensive. They include land purchase and transfer, making land grants and guaranteeing loans for the management of land, developing national and regional land strategies and, more generally, making contracts, investing money, accepting gifts, grants and requests and entering into partnerships and joint ventures.

In one of our other amendments, we want at least two members of the board to have business experience in land and land dealings. Currently, there is no provision for this. Surely, that amendment is not too unrealistic. Is the government going to agree to it or not? According to Senator Forshaw's comments tonight, he has not even seen that amendment and cannot comment on it.

We are also concerned about the effect the legislation will have on the pre-existing mechanisms of most of the states and territories for the provision of land for Aboriginal people. As with much of the government's legislation in recent times, this bill sets the scene for unnecessary competition between state and federal land funds. Such an approach lacks coordination and becomes self-defeating in the end.

We do not want grants to be limited to corporations. They should include individuals and trusts, because the consultation process with many of the Aboriginal communities has been simply and utterly inadequate. Not enough consideration has been given to the grants being made to individuals, and this amendment is surely one that the government will be prepared to look at. Once again, to this moment, I have not heard one thing to indicate that that is the case.

In my home state of Western Australia, some Aboriginal land is vested in Aboriginal land trusts, and some remains under direct government ownership and control. Under section 41 of the Western Australian Land (Titles and Traditional Usage) Act, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs is able to grant an indigenous community freehold title to a tract of land on the grounds of Aboriginal advancement. It is not a requirement that traditional usage or native title be proven. While there are no statutory land councils in Western Australia, a number of land councils have been formed in response to various land claims, notably the Noonkanbah and Utemorrah land claims.
We are putting forward many amendments. Unfortunately, time this evening does not

SPEECH.PARA: allow me to go through them all in detail. One of the major amendments we propose is that due recognition be given to health, housing and education. I have given enough examples tonight to prove that there is a requirement in those Aboriginal communities for such action. I certainly hope that the government will bite the bullet and do something about it.

PARA.TAB: What is required overall is for the ILC to confer with the states in the development of regional policies which do not overlap or conflict with those of the states and the workings of those councils I have outlined. This can best be achieved by having a state representative on the ILC board, which will comprise seven directors. This would ensure coordination with the states. It would not give them the right of veto but a right to request coordination and cooperation with their state's trusts and councils.

If this legislation passes without amendment, not only will there be several state funds but two federal land funds—one managed by the Indigenous Land Corporation and one managed by ATSIC. Duplication is always costly, unnecessary and, of course, causes delay in any decision making process. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen C.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with great pleasure that I speak tonight in support of the government's ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill 1994. This bill represents the second stage of the government's response to the Mabo High Court decision. It was originally intended that the land fund form part 10 of the Native Title Act. However, it will now be removed from that act and established within the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989. I note Senator Campbell's sterling defence of the Native Title Act and its preamble, and I am glad to see he has obviously changed his view about the worthwhile nature of that legislation.

PARA.TAB: The Native Title Committee, established under part 12 of the Native Title Act, will continue its charter of monitoring the operations of the land fund. This will allow the parliament to review, in a coordinated way, the parliament's response to the Mabo judgment. In pursuing its work, that committee has already experienced a great sense of optimism and expectation among Aboriginal people regarding the recognition of native title and the establishment of the land fund.

This bill must be considered in the context of the native title legislation, the social justice package currently being developed and the continuing role of ATSIC in delivering services to Aboriginal people. It cannot be assessed or criticised as if it were a single response to the Mabo decision or to Aboriginal needs. This bill has been developed in consultation with all of the interested parties, particularly with indigenous people.

The bill establishes a new land fund to allocate money for the purchase and management of land by the Indigenous Land Corporation. This will enable indigenous people to acquire land and manage and maintain it in a sustainable way to provide economic, environmental, social and cultural benefits. The land fund will operate as a trust account and will be subject to the Audit Act.

The Indigenous Land Corporation will receive an indexed amount of money each year for land purchase and/or management. Once land has been purchased by the ILC, it will be granted to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander corporations. However, the land will not be able to sold or mortgaged without permission from the ILC. The majority of the moneys allocated to the land fund will be invested to enable it to become self-sustaining after 10 years. By the financial year 2004-5 the ILC will receive funds based on the realised real return on investments by the land fund.

The ILC will be an independent statutory authority with a commercial orientation. It will be dedicated to focusing on land matters, particularly land and environmental management. By helping Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people attain greater access to land, the ILC will significantly advance the cause of their self-determination.

In addition to the purchase and management of land, the ILC will be required to prepare a national and regional indigenous land strategy. It will be required to directly involve indigenous land holders in land management activities, and to maximise the employment of indigenous people. The ILC will be required to act in accordance with sound business principles when operating on a commercial basis.

The bill is an explicit recognition of the importance of land in Aboriginal cultural. It is difficult for non-Aboriginal Australians to fully appreciate the importance of land and the feeling of dispossession suffered by Aboriginal people. The Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody found that dispossession from the land had far-reaching and serious effects on all aspects of Aboriginal people's lives. The commission's report states:

SPEECH.PARA: There are issues underlying the alienation of Aboriginal people and their continuing conflict with the law which cannot be solved by police and Aboriginal people alone. The key is to be found in the hearts and minds of all Australians. It lies in the recognition of the Aboriginal people as a distinct people, the indigenous people of Australia who were cruelly dispossessed of their land and until recent times denied respect as human beings and the opportunity to re-establish themselves on an equal basis.
About Aboriginal people who have been removed from their traditional land, the report goes on to state:

Notwithstanding this break from specific traditional attachments to land that some Aboriginal groups in the more remote areas of Australia have been able to maintain, Aboriginal people in the settled areas of Australia have continued to maintain the core elements of their spiritual association with land. This association is an assertion of their Aboriginality. Their loss requires redress that is, in essence, the same, even though the form of redress may vary considerably.

Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders regard the ownership of land as being fundamental to their wellbeing. The land provides a religious, legal, social and economic code for them. Land defines the identity of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders—their spirit, social relations, integrity and survival all come from the land. When they are removed from the land, they are removed from themselves. To quote Galarrwuy Yunupingu:
The land is my backbone . . . I only stand straight, happy, proud and not ashamed about my colour because of the land. I can paint, dance, create and sing as my ancestors did before me.

I think of land as the history of my nation. It tells how we came into being and what system we must live. My great ancestors who live in the times of history planned everything that we practise now. The law of history says that we must not take land, fight over land, steal land, give land and so on. My land is mine only because I came in spirit from that land, and so did my ancestors of the same land . . . My land is my foundation.

It is because of this special relationship to their land and the dispossession of Aboriginal people that will not be rectified by the native title legislation that the government is so committed to this bill. The opposition is unwilling or unable to recognise this special relationship to the land. It was put clearly by Alexander Downer in an interview on 16 June this year, when he said:

We've said that all along we would oppose the establishment of the Fund, because purchasing land isn't as big a priority as we see it as dealing with the issues of Aboriginal health, education and housing.
Downer is on the record as saying that the opposition will oppose the fund.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Downer to you.

—Sorry, Mr Downer. The Liberal and National parties do not see the purchase of land for Aboriginal people as a priority or indeed as appropriate. They resent the implicit recognition of a different culture with different priorities. That is a genuinely held view and they are consistent. They opposed the native title legislation, they support Richard Court's abolition of native title rights in WA and they oppose the land fund bill. Mr Ian McLachlan reflected that view when he said in May this year:

SPEECH.PARA: I can promise you that Coalition policy is that the Land Fund will be opposed, and that the Native Title Bill will be repealed.

That is the opposition's position. The opposition comes to this debate after what has been a tortured and well-publicised internal struggle. It now says, `Pass our amendments and we will support the legislation.' The Canberra Times, I think, best described the opposition's approach in a headline to its story `Fund tack smacks of insincerity'. That is the best description I have seen of the opposition's approach on this issue.

PARA.TAB: The opposition's amendments to do not seek to improve the bill. They are, in essence, a denial of the recognition of that special relationship with the land. They seek to make land grants conditional on:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . health, housing or educational needs or economic viability of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and communities being improved as a result of the acquisition of land.

At first glance the amendments seem innocuous enough, but ATSIC describes those Liberal amendments as `tearing away at the integrity of the bill and the negotiation process which created it'. The Liberal amendments would create pressure for Aboriginal communities to force their needs into artificial criteria and to suppress references to their own cultural criteria. It would thus perpetuate the non-recognition in Australian law of the intrinsic value of indigenous culture in its own right and require the indigenous people themselves to subordinate that culture to the criteria imposed by the bill. It is unconvincing and insincere to attempt to say, as those opposite have said, that if we make this bill about something else—that is, if we make this bill about fundamental human rights of all Australians to health, housing and education—they will vote for it. Sorry, but the bill is about establishing a land fund so that dispossessed Aboriginals can buy land. Senators must vote according to their position on that issue. That is the issue at stake.

PARA.TAB: The land fund is to be established as part of the Commonwealth public account, ensuring the maximum level of security and accountability for the fund. The allocation of moneys to the fund was determined in the knowledge that by remaining in the public account there was not a direct effect on the deficit. Critics of the bill have suggested a more entrepreneurial approach to the management of the fund. A submission to that effect was made by J.P. Morgan in conjunction with the Northern Land Council. Higher yields may well be available from investments requiring greater risk. The higher risk factor, however, would endanger the flow of funds to the ILC and impact on its ability to regularly commit to land purchases and management.

While J.P. Morgan's presentation was understandably up-beat—Senator Ferguson, with his superannuation experience, would have enjoyed it—a report in the Australian Financial Review of 12 October 1994 revealed the other side of the equation. It reported the performance of capital stable superannuation funds for the year to September 1994. These funds have been sold by fund managers to super fund trustees with an unwritten promise that they would not post negative returns over any 12-month period. The poorest performer among them was J.P. Morgan, whose capital stable fund posted a negative return of 5.8 per cent for the year—a sobering downside to the entrepreneurial approach to investment of taxpayers' funds.

The Greens in particular have sought to ridicule the amount of funds made available to the ILC. The point that must be made is that the allocation represents a doubling of current funding. An annual allocation is established in perpetuity and it is managed by Aboriginal people. The availability of $45 million per year for purchases is not to be ridiculed as insignificant, particularly if the integrity of the fund is protected from the opposition's amendments. Aboriginal representatives have accepted the funding as a significant and appropriate allocation.

The Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, when dealing with this bill, received some criticism of the consultation process associated with this legislation. It was a theme taken up by the opposition in its minority report on the bill, arguing that the passage of the bill be delayed until further consultation had occurred. I had this terrible feeling of deja vu. I for one am a little tired of being lectured by those opposite on consultation. It is clearly another smokescreen for their basic opposition to the land fund.

The land fund proposal was included in the Native Title Act that dominated parliamentary proceedings last year. During and since that time the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has consulted with Aboriginal organisations in framing this bill. ATSIC has conducted its own extensive consultations. A broad consensus among Aboriginal groups was reached in June and the bill has been available for months.

The opposition seeks to gain support for its position from a Mr Dickey Cox, who appeared as a witness before the finance and public administration committee and who complained of a lack of consultation. It is worth noting not only that he had correspondence with his local MP on this issue in May and received a copy of the bill from the Prime Minister's office, but also that, to my knowledge, Mr Cox has appeared before three parliamentary committees since December last year. Each of those committees was dealing with native title and land fund legislation. Clearly, Mr Cox has had some opportunity to be consulted on these issues. He has offered no substantive objections to the bill.

For the Liberal Party to raise consultation as an issue in this debate is the height of hypocrisy. The government's consultation process is on the record. The consultations involved in developing the Liberal Party's amendments, publicly revealed only as the legislation was introduced into the parliament, remain a mystery. Those amendments, developed in isolation, remain devoid of Aboriginal support. That the Liberal Party in WA introduced its Land (Titles and Traditional Usage) Act 1993 into parliament without any consultation whatsoever should also be remembered when assessing the Liberal's criticism of consultation processes in the area of Aboriginal affairs.

An argument has been raised by the New South Wales Land Council primarily regarding the purpose of the bill. Concern has been expressed that the absence of the preamble to the Native Title Act in this legislation has some profound implications. I see this issue has now been taken up by the Liberal Party. It is not the case.

The Prime Minister made it clear that the whole purpose of this legislation is to address land acquisition for those dispossessed and unable to benefit from the native title legislation. The two pieces of legislation are constituent parts of a total response.

It is true that the legislation does not set out detailed criteria for determining who should benefit from land acquisition. It makes no attempt to determine priorities between dispossessed indigenous people or to determine who might benefit most from land acquisition. That role is quite properly given to the directors of the Indigenous Land Corporation, the majority of whom must be Aboriginal people.

The opposition comes at this issue from yet a different angle. It is keen for a strict separation to be kept between native title and land acquisition. It fears the land acquisition fund being used to purchase pastoral leases that may then be converted into native title under section 47 of the Native Title Act. The parliament particularly provided in that section an opportunity to redress prior extinguishment on pastoral leases provided that the applicant would still need to show the existence of any connection with the land or waters concerned that may be required by the common law concept of native title.

There is no good reason for a lease purchased with ILC funds to be treated any differently from leases purchased with funds from other sources. The Liberal Party's objections are a reflection of its ideological opposition to native title and the public funding of Aboriginal purchase of land.

There is a delightful irony in the Liberal Party's approach on this issue. It dismisses the government's attempts to recognise that native title rights may not involve full proprietorial ownership of land and insists that purchases from the fund and native title must be completely divorced. This is from the party which legislated in Western Australia to replace native title rights with rights to traditional usage. The Liberals, of all people, should acknowledge that native title may not provide exclusive proprietorial ownership and that purchase of land might be required to fully restore Aboriginal connection with the land. That is what this bill provides for, without in any way diminishing the commitment to providing land for those already dispossessed.

In conclusion, this bill represents a genuine attempt by the government to partly redress the dispossession of Aboriginal people from their land. If enacted it will, together with the native title legislation and the social justice package, mark a tremendous commitment to addressing the wrongs perpetrated against Aboriginal people.

This bill does have widespread support among Aboriginal people and is the result of extensive negotiations with Aboriginal representatives. The government's consultation and negotiation process in forming this bill compares favourably with the consultation process of the bill's critics. I urge the Senate to support the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill 1994. I make my remarks in the context of having been a member at the time of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration which looked at this bill. First, I would like to refer to the remarks made by Senator Coates yesterday when he rose to speak on this bill. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe that he—
Senator Ellison—
Senator Campbell or Senator Troeth read the draft of this minority report before they signed it. I do not believe they could have.

I beg to inform Senator Coates that of course we read the report. I would not be signing a report that I had not read. The remarks contained in that report, as those made by coalition senators maintaining a dissenting report, are those that I wish to comment on. I take exception to the remark by Senator Coates that I had not read the minority report.

PARA.TAB: During those committee hearings we had an opportunity to hear those people representing Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders who, as they said at the time, had no input into consultation. Considering the point of view put by those witnesses who were called on the day, I could then make the comment that I was annoyed, angry or puzzled, to quote the remarks of Senator Coates, that the government had not taken into account the views of those witnesses.

I would say to Senator Chris Evans that if he felt that Mr Cox was the only Aboriginal who had not been consulted on the provisions of this bill, then indeed he is one person that the government should have consulted with in the sense that the government should have had wider consultation with the Aboriginal community than it did.

If consultation had taken place to the extent spoken about by the government, why did those witnesses not know about it? We are talking here about one of the most far-reaching changes ever made to land ownership in this country. It is a piece of legislation designed to affect a small section of the population only. If the government had consulted as widely as Senator Coates and Senator Chris Evans would have us believe, then I would have thought that the Swan Valley Noongah Community Group and the Kimberley Aboriginal Association would have heard about some of the details of the proposed legislation. Obviously they have not.

It was also pointed out on page 20 of the dissenting report that even after Mr Cox from the Kimberley Aboriginal Association had registered his interest in the outcome, no further effort was made by the government to contact him, other than to send him a copy of the bill on 9 June after its introduction. We are not talking here about millions and millions of people on the Australian continent. We are talking about a comparatively small number of organisations and individuals. This was also pointed out by the Barunga community. The coalition does not concede that sufficient consultation has taken place.

Over the period of time involved, it would surely have been possible for the government and its advisers to have informed the peak Aboriginal groups of the exact ramifications of this legislation. This information would have filtered through the groups to people living in outback Australia. Also, the government has not delineated how urban Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities are to be involved in these decisions. Were these people consulted? Are they included in the list of groups mentioned on page 7 of the committee report? It would be interesting to know the range of the `wide ranging consultation process'.

Another aspect of this legislation on which I wish to comment is the amount of expertise that should be required of board members. This bill does not require that any members of the board have business or financial experience. The board of the Indigenous Land Corporation has the responsibility of spending $45 million per annum on property purchase, development and management. The members of the board are to be appointed by the minister as he sees fit. Obviously, a board charged with these responsibilities should have a range of experience and background. It is the view of the coalition that, as the board should be accountable, it will be much better served if individuals with business and investment skills as well as the background of cultural and environmental matters are given the opportunity to be on the board.

To move to a wider appreciation of the board's responsibilities, it is essential that there be adequate accountability for the full value of money spent. Does the land fund bill provide for this? The coalition believes that it does not. Therefore, we will be moving amendments, none of which will restrict the operation of the Indigenous Land Corporation. National and regional strategies must be subject to scrutiny, parliament should be able to inform itself of the activity of these bodies, review should be carried out annually and not from time to time as laid down in the legislation, and grants given for a purpose should be used for that purpose. Also, the Indigenous Land Corporation should have the statutory power to ensure that this is done.

During my 15 months in the Senate, I have attended estimates committee hearings which have shown time and time again that, in spite of the seemingly large amount of money allocated to funding for ATSIC programs, only a small proportion of funds seems to have reached the most disadvantaged people. Aboriginal health statistics for the last 10 years, and indeed the then Senator Richardson's comments after his visit to the Northern Territory in his capacity as health minister, should indicate that, in spite of comparatively lavish funding for programs over recent years, no substantial improvements have been made in Aboriginal health. Why is it going to be so different for the land fund?

I feel sure that all the assurances that have been given in other legislation that conditions will improve have been given here. But what will be the result? None of the initiatives so far put forward by this government have substantially improved living conditions for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community. How is the legislation at present before us going to achieve such a transformation?

To set up another land fund when one already exists under the ATSIC legislation will surely compound the problem. If Aboriginal people have not found living conditions to be improved under existing legislation, why would they expect life to be any better with a second bureaucracy ready to use most of the money allocated to the land fund? Surely the staff and executives at present within ATSIC who are responsible for land matters would be available to the Indigenous Land Corporation. What we are looking at here is unnecessary administrative duplication. This waste, when all available money should be used to improve the appalling living conditions of many Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders, is disgraceful.

Senator Forshaw mentioned in his remarks the attitude taken by Mr Downer when he visited the Northern Territory. I point out to Senator Forshaw that former Senator Richardson, when the Minister for Health, emerged from his tour of the Northern Territory to say, `Something must be done.' As we saw during the remaining part of the former Senator Richardson's ministry, nothing was done. Indeed, the money allocated in the next budget did not enable anything more to be done to improve Aboriginal health services. The coalition has real concerns about this legislation.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Herron)—Order! It being 10.30 p.m., we are required to move to the consideration of government documents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: As a Tasmanian representing a state, I would like to point out what is likely to happen when the Australian Labor Party centralises power in Canberra. We all know that there are many in the Labor Party who have that commitment of centralising power in Canberra, weakening the power of the states and increasing the power of local government. That idea has been around since Gough Whitlam, but I wonder how some of the local government areas feel when they see the way they have been treated in this era. I cite Tasmania, for instance.

PARA.TAB: The letter that was sent to me by the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe)—and to all Tasmanian senators, I guess—points out with much pride that there has been an increase of 2.12 per cent over the 1993-94 entitlement of untied grants to local government throughout Australia. It pointed out that this is the fourth year that these grants have been increased by at least the rate of inflation.

Yet we see that in Tasmania—and it is even admitted in this letter—the total funding of untied grants is 1.73 per cent, compared with the overall average of 2.12 per cent. This might not seem a lot, but when we relate it to the local areas, we see that it has certainly had quite an effect on the overall balance of funding in some municipalities. Three of the major ones that were hit were the city of Launceston, the city of Clarence and the city of Glenorchy. In the case of the city of Launceston, in real terms it received a reduction of $216,000; the city of Clarence, in real terms, suffered a loss of $158,000; and Glenorchy lost $102,000.

Those three areas, as my colleagues from Tasmania Senator Murphy and Senator Sherry would know, contain areas that are battling with chronic unemployment as a result of the `recession we had to have'—places such as George Town, Gagebrook, Clarendon Vale, Claremont and Chigwell. When I checked with the Clarence Council today to see what effect it has had, I found that it is considering cutting some of its programs. The ratepayers are still recovering from the recession and most local governments have regard to their ratepayers and are trying to keep their rates down. I think most councils in Tasmania have made every effort, because of the recession and because of the inflation rate being reduced, to keep their rate increases to an absolute minimum. But it makes it very difficult when there are funding cuts from Canberra.

We are getting used to this in Tasmania. Over the last 11 years since this Labor Party came to power, funding cuts in real terms to local government and state government programs in Tasmania are approaching $400 million. For a small state of some half a million people with such a large area and such a large infrastructure to control, it is very significant. It really makes me wild that we are cutting back what seem to be small amounts of money. In the case of Clarence, for instance, $158,000 is 1 1/2 per cent of its rates. In the case of Glenorchy, it is about one per cent. When that is measured out to the families that are struggling to survive, it amounts on an individual basis to quite an amount of money.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—Does Senator Murphy expect me to calculate that right here and now? One per cent on an average rate bill is about $60. On top of that, when we hear that the government has spent $4 1/2 million on landscaping the Social Security building at Tuggeranong and then we turn around and see the real effects of what is happening in some of the state and local government areas, it is very hard to work out the government's thinking. I thought I would just point that out tonight. The government is very good at telling us what it is doing for the country. In the case of Tasmania, once again it is reducing in real terms local government funding.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to speak briefly to this document, as it is not possible to deal with all the matters contained in it in the time available. In particular, page 7 of the document refers to Acton Peninsula and the West Basin and the consultations that took place during 1993 and 1994 on the future of Acton Peninsula and the West Basin with a view, as the document says, `to developing a master plan, urban design guidelines and a comprehensive development plan.' The authority says:
As the land is a key site in the central national area, the NCPA has argued that a major national use would be appropriate.
The document then points out:
The land is Territory Land, managed by the ACT Government on behalf of the Commonwealth. Because it is in a Designated Area, it is subject to NCPA detailed planning control.

It refers also to consultations that have taken place with the community on the future of this particular site. It is interesting to note that the ACT government, contrary to the views of just about everybody, has gone ahead and placed a hospice on this site. At the time it did so, the Chief Minister of the ACT indicated that it would be inappropriate for the hospice and a national museum to share the same site.

PARA.TAB: The next paragraph in the annual report refers to the National Museum of Australia, which, of course, after today no longer exists even though the name may still be around because the legislation is still in existence. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: As part of the review of Acton Peninsula and West Basin, the NCPA undertook preliminary investigations into the possible siting of the National Museum of Australia on the peninsula, consistent with its view that the peninsula should accommodate a major national use.

I agree that this site should be used for a major national purpose; I disagree that it is an appropriate site for the National Museum of Australia. It certainly is not a place to put the odd building willy-nilly, as seems to be happening at the present time.

PARA.TAB: In referring to the document it is interesting to look back to the Labor Party policy on the museum at the time of the election in 1993 and, if I had time, the Labor Party policy on the museum in 1990. Most people will remember the fanfare—the breakfast at the museum and the television cameras—when it was all announced in 1993. I quote from the ALP cultural policy of 1993:

SPEECH.PARA: Labor believes that the Commonwealth has a major role to play in preserving and making accessible our experience as a nation and that all Australians should have the opportunity to share in this inheritance.
That is election rhetoric. It is not the reality today, after Labor has abandoned the museum. The policy goes on:
For that reason, Labor will proceed with the development of the national museum, with a Commonwealth contribution of $26 million over four years . . .
At the end of the document, it states:
Concurrently, over the next four years there will be a staged development of the museum site at Yarramundi including exhibition, education and conservation facilities.

What do we have today? Today we have an abandonment of the National Museum of Australia. We have the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies being placed as another building, along with the hospice, on the Acton site.

PARA.TAB: There should be an Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies as part of the National Museum of Australia. It is an integral part of that. To segregate it in this fashion is, as I heard mentioned on the radio today, almost a form of apartheid, of setting the Aboriginal culture apart from the rest of Australia.

The government then pretends in this statement issued today that things will happen. It will still use the expression the `National Museum of Australia'—meaningless though it be. The statement goes on to talk about the interactive multimedia resources, electronic exhibitions, et cetera. All of those things would happen, in any event, at the Yarramundi site, so there is nothing new in that.

I wonder what the NCPA annual report will say next year about Acton Peninsula and the museum. As of today, the museum has been abandoned by this government in spite of the government's election commitment in 1993, the requirement that this museum should be built, the money that has already been spent developing the site and planning the museum, and the exhibits that already exist.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: In this world there are people who make things and try to sell them and there are bureaucrats. On the whole, the people who make things and try to sell them do not hold the bureaucrats in very high regard. One of the reasons is that the bureaucrats continue to produce documents such as this Anti-Dumping Authority annual report, which I think is a most extraordinary document.

PARA.TAB: On page 2 of the annual report the authority suggests—in quite colloquial language which makes light of matters on which many Australian jobs depend—that the reason the basic chemicals industry had made fewer anti-dumping complaints in 1993-94 than in previous years was that the past protection of the industry by the authority had been so successful. I can offer an alternative explanation which, sadly, strikes me as much more likely: it could be that the basic chemicals industry has given up making anti-dumping claims because it was finding the process a waste of time and money. It could be that the basic chemicals industry has given up producing some of the items which dumped imports were hurting them in. I understand that is the case with at least one product. The authority goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . anti-dumping policy seems to have become less contentious. There was less shouting in 1993-94 than in earlier years about the `facts' that while Australia took months, other countries took only days to impose provisional anti-dumping measures; that an industry had to be on its knees before the Authority would recommend action; that action would be taken only if dumping were the sole cause of the industry's woes; and so on. All these `facts' were, of course, figments of the shouters' imaginations.

That is a remarkable attitude for a public authority to take in answer to legitimate criticism of its services by the constituency which it is supposed to be serving. Again, I am afraid, the far more likely explanation for the lack of shouting about anti-dumping policy in 1993-94 is that the authority's constituency—the men and women of Australia who make things and try to sell them—has given up. They have given up because of the genuine problems in getting relief from dumping in this country.

PARA.TAB: We only have to look at the cases quoted in the attachment to the report. In the case of CDs from Taiwan, the authority concluded that dumping was taking place, but refused to take action because the industry was still making profits. This is unacceptable. It is not for the authority to decide what is an appropriate level of profits for an industry. Without the dumping the industry could have been more profitable. According to this reasoning, any company making profits or expanding in Australia automatically forfeits its right to protection from dumping.

A similar argument appears to have been made in the case of home brewing kits. In the case of textile yarns, the authority reached the bizarre conclusion that the product was being dumped and that the Australian company was being damaged, but refused to take action because it was not sure that the dumping was causing the damage. I would have liked to hear a bureaucrat explaining to a businessman why dumped imports that were taking his market and cutting into his margins were not causing damage to his company.

In the case of formulated trifluralin, the authority took no action against subsidised imports because the importer had switched to importing the major product input and making up the product in Australia. In other words, the foreign `dumper' was let off on a technicality while the Australian industry continues to suffer. Again, in the case of insect screening, the dumping of an inferior quality Chinese good was found not to have caused material injury. Again it is hard to imagine how it would not have caused injury.

On 12 September 1994 there was a report in the Business Review Weekly that the government was considering a review of anti-dumping regulations with the intention of softening them. The same article says that ICI has warned that multimillion dollar investment proposals for its manufacturing site at Altona in Melbourne would not be accepted by its British parent if there were doubts about protection against dumped products. Amcor, it was said, has warned that investment in white paper manufacturing would go out of Australia.

We call on the government to go ahead and review anti-dumping legislation in Australia, but with the intention of providing the businessmen and women of Australia with real protection against unfair trading practices. In particular, the government should look at making it less difficult for companies to prove that dumping has caused them material injury. (Time expired)

SPEECH.PARA: I looked briefly at the report of the Australian Maritime Safety Authority and noted with some alarm that many of the aspects of safety that the Senate expressed concern about in relation to the Civil Aviation Authority seemed to also exist within the Australian Maritime Safety Authority. The problem with the lack of urgency that people attach to the implications of safety is that, if there is not enough attention paid to aircraft safety, there is a strong possibility of them falling out of the sky. In the case of maritime safety, the implications are more likely to be accidents, slackness in addressing bilge water problems or a serious oil spill which would impact on the local economy but more importantly impact on the ecosystems in such a way that we might have permanent problems in our huge coastal area.

PARA.TAB: This is a huge problem for Australia. The Maritime Safety Authority boasted that during the year it had an operating profit of $1.1 million. In the report it states:

SPEECH.PARA: This was a particularly pleasing result given that 1993-94 was the first year in which there was no government contribution . . .

The government has removed its contribution. Not only that, but the government paid itself a dividend of $3.065 million. According to the figures, the Maritime Safety Authority is not employing enough people to provide the services that we feel are necessary. It is hardly going to do the trick to provide even the same number of people, considering the amount of concern there has been expressed in things like the Ships of Shame report and in the oil pollution of sea legislation which actually assured everybody that we would be paying more attention to shipping safety and not less.

PARA.TAB: There are some figures in the report that relate to inspections. There were a total of 2,157 foreign ships inspected. Some 39 per cent of eligible ships were inspected in the year. One can only wonder how we can judge productivity. If this means that we have had to inspect more ships because there is a recognition that we have a higher number of single-voyage permits and an increasing age in the ships that are using our coast and travelling into and out of Australia, how does one judge productivity?

If we have an increasing number of inspections taking place and possibly an increasing number of ships needing inspection, what does that say about the nature of the inspections that can take place with either the same or, I would argue, perhaps a decreasing number of people available to perform those inspections? Yet according to this report, during the year staff numbers declined from 533 to 440. That is a reduction of 17.4 per cent. So fewer people are available to perform the inspections.

TALK.START.PARA: —That might be a bit more productive.
—How can it be more productive, Senator Panizza? It must be noted that at the front of the report it states:

SPEECH.PARA: In looking at the quality of international shipping the need for Australia to detain a significant number of sub-standard ships during 1993-94 confirms that improvement in quality has been disappointing.

Do we judge this report on whether or not there is safer shipping? Nowhere in this report does it say how close we have come or how much the Maritime Safety Authority has contributed to safer shipping in Australia and the possible impacts on the ecology and other industries that this might have.

PARA.TAB: The reports states that there have been 252 reports of marine oil pollution. We are not looking at a diminishing problem; we are possibly looking at a greater problem. As I mentioned before, the actual age of shipping around Australia is increasing, so the possibility of a major oil spill and a breakup of the shipping that exists becomes greater. TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: For all of those people who find a lot of pleasure in reading annual reports, I recommend the 1993-94 annual report of the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions as quite good reading. I received it only today, but I did have a quick look through it. I note with interest that the federal government has had a review of the DPP and its role.

PARA.TAB: What interested me in the annual report were the case reports put forward to give some indication of the range of cases dealt with by the DPP. They range from fisheries offences to drugs. There was a large number of cases of Commonwealth employees defrauding the Commonwealth. The thing that struck me was all these good Australian names such as Chun and Bipati, and Ladocki and Sundar.

Operation Rustic was mentioned, which involved people such as Postiglione, Kapeliotis, Mari and Dufek. Then there were names such as Sinsamboon and Pukdeekul. There seems to be an awful lot of drugs being brought into this country by people from outside of Australia. I note that in Operation Aladdin in Victoria there were six Japanese people sentenced for importing 12 kilograms of heroin. They received sentences ranging from 15 years to 25 years imprisonment, which I presume everybody agrees with.

An interesting case mentioned in the report is one that I have brought up more than once in this place and in estimates—the Iranian Embassy. Let me refresh the memories of honourable senators. In April 1992, a group of demonstrators attacked the embassy of Iran, causing considerable damage. It was all there for everybody to see on SBS television. Not only did the demonstrators cause a lot of damage, but also they reportedly stole about $US60,000—or somebody did, because it went missing.

Our government, which is very good at handing out money, then funded legal aid to the tune of $644,000 to defend these people. On top of that, the Australian government, in its generous mood, compensated the Iranian Embassy for nearly $500,000 for damage that was done. The government believed that the security arrangements that were supposed to have been provided by the Australian Federal Police were not sufficiently good enough. So we had over $1 million of taxpayers' money handed out.

I read with some dismay in this annual report the sentences received by the 11 defendants, who were obviously well defended with our taxpayers' dollars. Three of them convicted received custodial sentences and the remainder received suspended sentences. Two defendants are appealing against the sentences.

There is no mention of the quite generous $60,000 compensation to the Iranians. There is no mention of anybody being charged with stealing it. There is no mention of anybody even looking for it. It is a fair example of just how generous the government can be in some areas with taxpayers' funds. In this particular case, it is unfortunate that the people who caused so much damage and embarrassment to the government—and also obviously stole $US60,000—received such light sentences.

The report then talks about all of these other cases. There are a few recognisable names such as Bond, Fairlie from Tasmania and a few others. It is good reading. I just thought I would raise that matter again tonight, because it struck me as somewhat significant that in the drug related cases, quite rightly, quite heavy sentences were received, whereas these demonstrators, who did so much damage to the Iranian Embassy, and on whom Australia spent so much money defending, received sentences that were virtually mandatory.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
