SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address tonight the issue of smoking, the biggest public health problem in Australia today, and in particular the government's rejection of a recommendation, as presented in the documents to the Senate this evening, by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee to place transdermal nicotine patches on the PBS list. Quite clearly, this is a stupid, callous and short-sighted decision which reeks of hypocrisy on the part of the government and one which sadly will cost thousands of lives and waste millions of dollars.

PARA.TAB: Transdermal patches are essentially a nicotine replacement therapy to help alleviate the withdrawal symptoms of those who want to give up smoking. They take the form of patches placed upon the skin and the nicotine is absorbed across the skin. There is no doubt that they are effective. The PBAC itself has recommended listing on the basis of efficacy and there are several studies, including some in Australia, which support this. There is no question about them being effective. Estimates indicate that they are probably going to improve the chances of someone giving up smoking by between five and 10 per cent.

At present a 10-week course costs around $300. That is about $5 a day, which is about the same as a packet of cigarettes. By itself, it is quite a sizeable amount if you happen to be a low income earner. An agreement with the pricing committee saw the manufacturer actually slash the approved price for the proposed four-week course of treatment, the proposal being that the patient would then be expected to fund the rest of the course from the savings made by not having to purchase cigarettes.

There is some debate about how these should best be used, and the government's rejection indicated that it was not happy with the proposed method. The company itself supports the product with a free anti-smoking kit, tapes, diary and brochures to support people going through a tough time. It supported the idea of a PBS listing as a restricted once only script available through GPs, who are then meant to counsel patients and to go through the important things such as triggers that start people smoking again, to make sure that those who are genuinely motivated to give up smoking and who could benefit from the patches, therefore, would be able to wheen themselves off nicotine.

There are some alternatives such as support groups, but there really is a need for professional input from the medical profession because, although side effects are fairly minor, they do occur in patients with blood pressure and other cardiovascular problems. The PBAC, for those who are not familiar with it, is a committee appointed by the government made up mainly of medical and related experts who process applications largely from drug companies seeking to have their products listed under the PBS. It meets four times a year and operates under guidelines requiring that it takes into account that the medication is effective and is cost efficient. The recommendations are usually sent to a pricing committee and then referred either to the health minister where the cost is less than $10 million or to the cabinet if above $10 million.

The only previous rejection of a PBAC recommendation that I am aware of was by the previous minister, Graham Richardson, who refused to list the migraine drug sumitriptan. This process is being curtailed here, apart from the blocking presumably by Minister Lawrence, by not having been submitted to cabinet as far as I can determine.

The PBAC said that the patches were clearly effective in a significant number of patients, that they were cost effective, that they were safe and that, therefore, they should be listed on the PBS, preferably in a restricted manner to allow one course to be started to initiate patients in this therapy. On that basis, the government's own appointed experts—let us make it very clear—have said, `List these products; it is worth while financially, it is worth while medically.'

So what then is the government's position? A statement has been issued and tabled in the Senate this evening—with no minister taking responsibility, I might add, but presumably with at least the blessing of Minister Lawrence—rejecting the listing on the ground of a $100 million alleged cost and also the claim that this is a state matter. According to the PBAC documents, there is apparently an agreement that these smoking cessation programs are a state matter. What other drugs are state matters? Is there any evidence of the various states purchasing these patches? The answer is a very resounding no, there is no evidence of this at all. This is buck-passing.

The government claim of $100 million is a grossly inflated figure. There are about 3 1/2 million smokers in Australia and it is estimated that about a quarter actively attempt to quit in any one year. Seventy-five per cent of those quitters actually go cold turkey and the remaining 25 per cent seek some support—counselling, hypnosis, medication or other products, such as the patches.

For the government's figure to be even vaguely accurate, every single would-be quitter in every year would have to seek a prescription for the patches. That clearly does not, and clearly never will, happen. Importantly, I point out that the patches have been available to war veterans for some time but the demand for them has been so low that the conditions for their use had to be watered down to encourage the war veterans to use them.

Clearly, the government's estimates are grossly inflated. The industry estimates that the figures would be at a maximum of around 300,000 people per year. Even on this basis, in this extreme case, the actual cost is about a fifth of the government's estimate; that is, $20 million.

Let me look at how this stance, this refusal to help people give up smoking, matches up with the government's past rhetoric on anti-smoking measures. All previous health ministers, as well as the current minister, Dr Lawrence, have spoken often, and rightly, of the evils of smoking and the need in both economic and human terms to encourage people to quit. On 10 August this year Dr Lawrence spoke about figures that showed that teenage smoking was on the rise after 10 years of decline. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: These disturbing statistics pose a serious threat to the hard-won gains in reducing tobacco consumption which have been fought for in this country. I urge all levels of government, the media, the health sector and the community to support the Commonwealth's action to counteract these concerning trends and to preserve the health of our young people.

Talk about hypocrisy! What has changed since August? Why does Minister Lawrence urge everybody else to combat smoking and then sit at best silent, if not responsible for this stupid and callous decision? She has not put her name to this statement, but neither has she spoken out against the decision, if it were made by somebody else and taken out of her hands. Indeed, she has claimed that when she gave up smoking she went cold turkey, implying that if she did it anybody else could. It is a clear case of the Keating government hypocrisy being exposed to all the groups that Dr Lawrence urged to help in the war against smoking, despite some pathetic attempt to hide behind a vague statement with nobody's name attached to it.

PARA.TAB: I remind this chamber how bad the problem is. Smoking kills 20,000 patients every year. It costs $9 billion a year. It causes cancer, heart disease, bronchitis and a whole host of other medical conditions. It shortens the life span of its direct victims and makes their reduced term more difficult to endure with shortness of breath and loss of limbs.

There is a very clear relationship also between smoking and the social situation. The lowest paid and lowest educated groups in the community are the heaviest smokers. These are the people who could benefit from these patches and they are also the people who cannot afford the patches. These are the people who are suffering from this government's decision. The smoking rate in Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders is almost 50 per cent compared with 20-odd per cent among non-Aboriginals.

A million Australians have died this century through smoking related illness. In 1991, Australians smoked 34 billion cigarettes and inhaled 343,000 kilograms of tar. There are 43 known cancer producing chemicals in cigarettes. Passive smoking—just inhaling other people's smoke—kills 10 people a week in New South Wales alone. It causes over a third of cancer deaths and undoubtedly affects the lifespan of people in Australia.

Telecom made a special study of 70,000 staff, and found that smoking cost that organisation alone $16 1/2 million in sick leave. If that were translated to the national work force, the figure would be $1.5 billion. Today's smokers in Australia will lose 125 million years of normal activity because of smoking related illness and premature death.

There can be no doubt about the enormity of this problem and there can be no doubt about the hypocrisy of the government. When it suits it, the government pays lip service to attacking the problem but when it comes to the crunch of being involved in spending a small amount of money, it passes the buck. Sadly, the worst affected are those on low incomes and Aboriginals, those very people that the ALP claims, falsely of course, to represent.

This is short-term cost cutting, but there is a long-term cost. Sadly, the cost is not only financial but is a cost in lives and in suffering. I plead with the government to reverse this decision and, for once, to practise long-term preventive medicine and invest in the long-term health of the people of Australia—to fulfil the responsibility entrusted to it by the people of Australia. To do otherwise is simply gross hypocrisy. To do otherwise is simply to abandon any pretence of caring for the health of Australians. There is no doubt about the size of this problem. There is no doubt that this solution is not the answer to the whole problem, but it is a partial solution that potentially will save thousands of lives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to comment on the terrible drought and, in particular, the contrast between the approach to the drought taken by this federal Labor government and the new initiatives that have just been announced in New South Wales. For four years we have had developing a terrible drought that is devastating rural Australia. Our Prime Minister, Mr Keating, tried to ignore the development of this drought for most of that four years.

PARA.TAB: When I was in northern Queensland in July, Mr Keating was there with me. He visited Cairns and Townsville, and that was fine, but I challenged him to go outback—to go to Roma and Longreach to see the real effects of this drought. This of course he refused to do. Eventually, he went out to Dubbo for a day and he went out to south-west Queensland. He came back and delivered a $165 million package to be spent in the next four years in countering the effects of the drought. I would like to point out to the Senate the gross inadequacy of this package and in particular the fact that in New South Wales—my state—96 per cent of farmers who are affected by this drought get absolutely nothing.

It is interesting to see the reaction of some of the bush members of the ALP. We have members like Eric Fitzgibbon, who has finally blown the whistle on this government and has said what the government is failing to do for the voters in his electorate. Last week the honourable member for Page (Mr Harry Woods) and the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Newell) lamely defended the federal government's policy. They said that if people were not eligible for the drought relief funds—and indeed all farmers on the northern coastal area of New South Wales are in that position—there was already the Farmhand fund. The Farmhand fund raised $12 million and I believed that it finally shamed this government into trying to do something about the drought.

Welcome though that money is, charity is no substitute for proper public policy. It is quite interesting that now Eric Fitzgibbon, the member for Hunter, has blown the whistle on the government on this issue. The front page of this morning's Maitland Mercury states in full what Eric Fitzgibbon had to say yesterday. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: My government is not spending enough on drought relief.
The Government should increase its $164 million drought relief package to include farmers who are not eligible under the exceptional circumstances criteria.
We gave $250 million for the arts over 4 years. I'm all for the arts but where is the greater urgency?
Farmers need to be allowed to live with a degree of dignity.
It's not my natural constituency, but nevertheless the farmers are my constituents and I want to see the government give them more.

Is that not refreshing—an ALP government member who stands up to the government and blows the whistle on the inadequacy of its policy? But where are the voices of Harry Woods in Page and Neville Newell in Richmond? We do not hear them speaking out in a similar forthright manner.

PARA.TAB: As Eric Fitzgibbon points out, it is the federal government's responsibility to help with drought assistance, particularly in this extreme situation when this terrible drought is devastating so many farmers. By relying on the Farmhand appeal money, the government is just substituting charity for proper public policy. When will the government help? We on the north coast are in a terrible situation in an area that is not considered to be experiencing extreme drought.

But the effects of the drought are obvious. The cattle breeding herds of the North Coast near Casino, near Grafton and in the Hunter will soon be wiped out if they do not get any further help to help maintain this very valuable domestic and export beef industry. The New South Wales Department of Agriculture has estimated that 150,000 cattle in the Upper Hunter will have to be sold or shot in the coming months. Stock are now dying from starvation.

This bleak picture of drought also has a very human dimension. How does the minister tell a farmer who has no food and income and who has borrowed tens of thousands of dollars to keep stock alive that 23 months of continuous drought is not enough to qualify for federal help? This has happened in Scone and in Merriwa in the Hunter electorate. One farmer up there thought that he had assistance and was then told that the area was not eligible for this government package. That man was considering suicide because of the despair of having been offered help and then Social Security saying he was not eligible.

On the North Coast the acute drought is having a special effect because this is normally a high rainfall area. The effect on the area is far greater than in the inland, which is used to sparse rainfalls. Minister Collins said he had to draw the line somewhere for the assistance package. The Senate should note tonight that this line is far too inflexible and far too mean, as it leaves out so many farmers deserving of help in this the worst drought this century.

It is refreshing to see the New South Wales coalition government, having promised over $20 million in August, now coming up with an additional package of $65 million that is comprehensive and will aid a wide range of farmers. They will not have to follow these very stringent guidelines that the federal government has laid down.

The Fahey government has appointed a drought relief coordinator to see that the money and services are effectively delivered. The local council rates are to be relieved from farmers and rural businesses in the drought declared areas. A decision has been made that interest subsidies are available to non-farm businesses suffering trading difficulties and there is a budget of $5 million like the Queensland scheme. Today Senator Schacht declined to match such spending. This was pointed out by Senator Macdonald today.

The commitment of the New South Wales government for ongoing assistance when the drought eventually breaks is also there. When Senator Macdonald and I were up north of Kyogle the week before last a number of the farmers said to us, `After the drought ends, that's when a lot of our problems will start because we've got to re-stock and get ready for the next cycle. A lot of the people in the city will forget us because they'll think that the problem will be over.' It is refreshing to see that the New South Wales government has recognised this and is putting funding into post-drought money at this stage.

A further $10 million is being added to the rural adjustment scheme to match the federal money. The private vehicle conveyance of school children subsidies will be doubled at a cost of $7.5 million. More than $1 million has been put aside for the humane treatment of drought affected stock. Other initiatives include bore deepening grants to the north-west of New South Wales, where the aquifer under the cotton growing areas has now been pumped dry. The running of special free fodder and water trains to cart into drought areas has been made available on a similar basis to bring fodder from areas such as Western Australia.

There is the free carriage of charitable goods by rail in New South Wales. The government also proposes an increase in agistment grazing of drought stock on crown land and state recreation areas. There will be relief for drought affected families with school expenses, including $4 million on tripling the number of boarding scholarships at New South Wales agricultural high schools.

That is a very comprehensive program when we consider the difficulties of farming families and the regions of New South Wales farming areas that it covers. It is in stark contrast to the mean-minded approach of the federal government. It is welcomed that some government members are now acknowledging this publicly. Let us hope that they have some influence in their party room in getting the government to change its mean-minded policy.

The coalition government in New South Wales does not have the budget resources of the federal government. Despite this, it is moving to help in a comprehensive way. The federal Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Collins, must rethink his package and his commitment to alleviating suffering in rural Australia. Let us see whether he can do a little better by providing assistance to the 96 per cent of farmers who are getting no help. (Time expired)

The following answers to questions were circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 9 May 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Will the Government be producing a response to the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration entitled Follow the Yellow Brick Road—the Final Report of an Efficiency Audit of the Australian Taxation Office, which was tabled in March 1991.
(2) What measures have been taken, or are planned, to implement recommendation 15 of the report and does the Government plan to introduce legislation in respect of such matters.
(3) Has the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) begun to collect statistics in accordance with recommendation 16 of this report; if so, are those statistics available; if not, why not.
(4) Has the ATO implemented recommendation 17 of the report; if so, are those statistics available from this change of income tax returns; if not, why not.

(5) Does the ATO (Victorian Division) only supply to the public a list of public benevolent institutions; if so, why has this list not been brought into line with all other regional offices of the ATO which also supply details of date of approval, withdrawal, other comments and appropriate statutory reference and are there any plans to bring the list into line with the practice of the rest of the ATO.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) & (2) While a formal Government response has unfortunately not been tabled to date, the ATO has been active in addressing the Committee's recommendations. A formal Government response will be tabled in the 1994 Spring Sittings.

(3) & (4) No. The ATO does collect statistics of the amount of gifts claimed in the income tax return of individual taxpayers. However, the ATO does not collect separate statistics of gifts to particular organisations claimed under section 78 of the Income Tax Assessment Act (ITAA), nor does it collect details of trust distributions to non-taxable entities such as charitable institutions.

Under a system of self-assessment, the ATO relies on statements made by taxpayers in their returns for the purpose of making an assessment. As such, taxation returns seek only limited information about income and deductions, with further details sought if a taxpayer is selected for audit. In relation to deductions claimed for donations to charitable organisations, the tax return seeks only a total figure.

To amend ATO systems to maintain details, for example, of the amounts claimed as deductions each year for donations made to each of the charitable organisations listed in section 78 of the ITAA would be a substantial and expensive exercise for very little benefit. Such a change would have a significant impact on ATO processing with the very likely possibility of increasing turnaround time for assessments, particularly in the case of the many taxpayers who claim donations to a number of charitable organisations each year.

There is also an issue of how donations or contributions are claimed by entities other than individuals. Donations can be claimed either as a gift or as a legitimate business expense. For example, large donations made by the corporate sector can be claimed as a promotional or advertising expense under section 51(1), as opposed to section 78 of the ITAA. To try to record the specifics of these claims would add further complexity and expense. Further, to the extent that information was not provided electronically, there would be a massive workload involved in keying the data.

(5) One of the ATO's Victorian Branch Offices has, in response to a request under the Freedom of Information Act 1982 (FOI Act), provided a list of organisations which have been approved under section 78 of the ITAA in that State.

Each Branch of the ATO does keep a register that lists all organisations that have been granted tax deductible gift status by that Branch for the purposes of the ITAA. The largest category of organisations approved for this purpose is public benevolent institutions.
The ATO has recently taken steps to ensure that future requests for information contained in the Registers will be treated consistently.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Defence Exports Program: Mr L. Fluitman

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 29 August 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the relationship that exists between Indonesian-born Dutch national, Mr Laurens Fluitman, and Australia's Defence Exports Program.
(1) Is Mr Fluitman authorised to act as a spokesman for the department and the Australian Defence Industry.
(2) Is Mr Fluitman's 12-month contract, which expired on 30 June 1994, being renewed; if so, on what terms.
(3) Has Mr Fluitman been provided with a security clearance and access to the defence elements of the Australian Embassy in Indonesia.
(4) Has Mr Fluitman sought, or been provided with, classified defence security material by the Defence Exports Program through defence officials at the Australian Embassy in Jakarta.
(5) Has the department received critical comments about Mr Fluitman from a number of successful Australian and international companies operating in Indonesia.
(6) What role has the Defence Exports Program played in securing residency visas for Australia for Mr Fluitman, enabling him to reside on the Gold Coast.
(7) Does Mr Fluitman regularly travel to and from Indonesia at Australian taxpayers' expense.
(8) Why have officers of the Defence Exports Program sought to secure Australian citizenship for Mr Fluitman.
(9) Why has this month's proposed mission by the Defence Acquisitions and Logistics Organisation to Indonesia been cancelled.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Mr Fluitman has not been authorised to act as a spokesman for the Department of Defence.

(2) Some discussions regarding the future employment of Malindoqueen, of which Mr Fluitman is a director have taken place with officers of the Department of Defence. However, at my direction, the contract will not be renewed. I have also asked the Inspector General in Defence to review the details of the initial contract.

(3) Mr Fluitman does not have an Australian security clearance. When he visits the Australian Embassy in Jakarta, the Embassy staff (including Australian defence representatives) treat him like any other commercial visitor. Mr Fluitman has access to the defence elements of the Embassy on this basis.
(4) To the best knowledge of relevant Defence officials, Mr Fluitman has not sought, or been provided with, any classified Australian defence material.
(5) The Department of Defence has not received any specific criticisms by companies about Mr Fluitman.

(6) Officials of the Department of Defence have explained to representatives of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs the service that Mr Fluitman provided under Malindoqueen's contract with Defence.
(7) Under Malindoqueen's contract with Defence, Mr Fluitman was required to travel to Indonesia. Defence paid for that portion of his travel that was directly attributable to his work for Defence.

(8) Defence officials responsible for the Defence Export Program have supported Mr Fluitman's application for permanent residency in Australia by supplying statements confirming the scope and nature of Mr Fluitman's work for the Department.

(9) I presume the question refers to a proposed presentation to Indonesian officials by representatives of the Defence Acquisition and Logistics Program on how Australia secures significant transfer of technology and local industry involvement in major defence capital equipment projects like the Collins Class submarines. The presentation has been deferred pending clarification of Indonesian interests and settlement of a date suitable to both parties.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 30 August 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What are the details of the discussions at a military level between the Commander of the French forces in New Caledonia, Major-General Rene Delhome, and Australian Chief of General Staff, General John Grey, about the possibility of training and joint exercises with Australia; if these details cannot be provided, why not.
(2) What is the Government's view of participating in such a request for training and joint exercises, bearing in mind that a formal request has not yet been received.

(3) (a) What has been the human rights record of the French on New Caledonia; and (b) how many of the indigenous population have been killed, imprisoned, tortured or deprived of their civil and political rights.
(4) What is the role of the 3500 French counter-insurgency troops on New Caledonia at present.
(5) (a) What is the total number of French troops on New Caledonia; and (b) what is their role.
(6) Please provide details as to French bases in the South Pacific providing details of their names, locations and activities.

(7) What is Australia's current defence relationship with the French in terms of (a) training; (b) military aid; (c) defence co-operation; (d) defence exports; (e) confidence building measures; (f) counter-insurgency; (g) communications; (h) surveillance; (i) joint exercises; and (j) technology transfer.

(8) What is Australia's current defence relationship with New Caledonia in terms of: (a) training; (b) military aid; (c) defence co-operation; (d) defence exports; (e) confidence building measures; (f) counter-insurgency; (g) communications; (h) surveillance; (i) joint exercises; and (j) technology transfer.

(9) With reference to (7)(d) and (8)(d), what were the defence exports to France and New Caledonia for the 1980-81, 1981-82, 1982-83, 1983-84, 1984-85, 1985-86, 1986-87, 1987-88, 1988-89, 1989-90, 1990-91, 1991-92, 1992-93, 1993-94 and 1994-95 financial years.
(10) Will the Minister provide details of the proposed formal request from the French Government as soon as it becomes available; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) During a courtesy call on Lieutenant General Grey on 24 June 1994, Major General Delhome mentioned briefly an interest in possible expansion of combined activities between Australia and France to include headquarters-level exercises at some future stage. General Delhome also invited an Australian delegation to attend celebrations in New Caledonia in May 1995 to mark the end of World War II in the Pacific. He also flagged a proposal for a cultural exchange involving school children of French and Australian military families.

General Delhome has subsequently written to Lieutenant General Grey, with a specific invitation for an Australian Army officer to visit New Caledonia in October 1994 as an observer to the annual French military exercise, and has further raised proposals for cultural exchanges involving Australian and French school children.

(2) We have a longstanding program of contact with French forces in the South Pacific, focusing on bilateral naval passage exercises, fisheries surveillance and disaster relief coordination. There may be some scope for a modest increase in activity, noting the positive development in recent years of French policies on New Caledonia and nuclear testing. I would be happy to consider further expansion in contact with the French, but I would not envisage that we would get involved in cooperation or exercises that related to internal security in New Caledonia.
(3) This is not a matter on which Defence is able to comment. I suggest the honourable senator direct her question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs.
(4) I do not propose to answer this question, which is a matter for the French Government.
(5) I do not propose to answer this question, which is a matter for the French Government.
(6) I do not propose to answer this question, which is a matter for the French Government.

(7) Europe is not an area of priority in Australian defence planning. Nevertheless, our relations with France are important to our defence and broader national and strategic interests, particularly in the South West Pacific.

(a) Training between the ADF and the French military is currently limited to one rotational position being offered to Australia on the senior military staff course in France and one officer from France attending the Joint Services Staff College in Australia every three years. (This officer then becomes the French Defence Attache to Australia located in Canberra.)
(b) Australia provides no military aid to France.

(c) With respect to defence materiel and related issues, Australian and French authorities are negotiating a Cooperative Logistic Support Agreement and French and Australian naval staff are negotiating a technical arrangement on cooperation in the field of naval armaments.
(d) See answer to question 9 below.
(e) Visits to France and Australia by Ministers and senior officials from each country and exchanges between Service personnel provide a forum for raising matters of mutual interest.
(f) Nil

(g) Channels of communication exist for operational-level contact between Australian and French armed forces with respect to naval passage exercises, fisheries surveillance and disaster relief coordination in the South Pacific.

(h) Arrangements were established in May 1993 for coordination of regional fisheries surveillance flights conducted by Australian, New Zealand and French armed forces, in conjunction with the South Pacific Forum Fisheries Agency.
(i) Bilateral passage exercises are periodically conducted between ships of the Royal Australian Navy and the French Navy, in conjunction with ship visits to New Caledonia and Australia.

(j) At the government to government level, the Defence Science Agreement with France, signed in 1990, enables collaboration between French and Australian scientists on a range of technologies, for example the Over-The-Horizon radar technology.

ANSWER.PARA: At the commercial level, French companies competing for Australian defence business may also transfer technology.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 5 September 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What are the details of each overseas trip taken by the Managing Director of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) since 1 July 1994, including the dates of such trips, the cost, the countries visited, the persons or organisations visited and the purpose of each visit.

(2) On any, and which, trips did the Managing Director conduct any, and what, business relating to the ABC's Asian satellite television service, Australia Television International (ATV); if so, what was the nature and extent thereof.
(3) To the extent that any time, resources or proportion of any such visit were related to the business of ATV, were they funded from ATV's budget; if not, why not, and what was the funding source.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) has advised as follows:

(1) The Managing Director has made one overseas visit since 1 July 1994. This trip was to Vietnam and Hong Kong from 26 August to 30 August 1994. The cost of travel for this trip was $882.00. Frequent flyer points were used for the Sydney—Hong Kong—return route. All other direct expenses associated with the visit including accommodation totalled $2495.00.

The ABC regards details of persons met and the nature of discussions undertaken to be commercial in confidence. The disclosure of this information could adversely affect ABC negotiations on a range of matters (ie. program sales, co-production arrangements, orchestral tours and subscription television contacts).

(2) This visit included business relating to Australia Television in both Hong Kong and Vietnam. In Vietnam rebroadcasting arrangements were discussed along with discussion on national and international television developments.
However, on this visit as with others, a wide range of other ABC matters were dealt with by the Managing Director. In Vietnam, these included:
progress of the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB) Indochina Broadcasting project, including setting a workplan for 1995 with both Radio and Television organisations.

discussions with the Vietnamese government on international copyright compliance, streamlining television news material shipment from ABC Hanoi bureau, and plans for the introduction of additional television channels using multi-point distribution services (MDS).
discussions concerning Radio Australia and usage and future usage of short wave radio in Vietnam.
plans for the Director General of Vietnam Radio to visit Australia and the ABC were discussed further.
In Hong Kong matters canvassed included:
international satellite television developments.
future ABC satellite planning and the functioning of the ABC Asian news bureau.
new ABC accommodation in Hong Kong.

(3) No cost was attributed to the Australia Television budget. The Managing Director has budget allocations for both domestic and international travel. It is not the practice to attribute these costs to the operational areas.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 19 September 1994:

PARA.TAB: Has the part of the Department known as the Legal Practice sought authorisation from the Trade Practices Commission for it to enter into contracts, arrangements or understandings with the Department of Defence and a number of other Commonwealth departments or agencies for exclusivity in the provision of legal services to those departments or agencies, or otherwise sought a ruling from the commission in relation to the matter; if so, when were the relevant authorisations or rulings provided; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: In February 1991 the Government decided to introduce a system of user pays for the provision of legal services to departments and Budget-dependent agencies. Briefly; the system approved at that time provided that departments and budget-dependent agencies were required, subject to a review in 1994, to continue to obtain their externally sourced legal services from the Attorney-General's Department until 30 June 1995. After that date a range of those services would be opened up to competition from private sector service providers.

The 1994 review has since been carried out and the Government has decided to maintain the 1991 decision to tie departments and Budget-dependent agencies' legal services to the Attorney-General's Department until 30 June 1995.

In the course of reaching the 1991 decision the Government endorsed certain principles of the user pays system which were set out in the Guidelines for the Provision of Government Legal Services. A copy of the Guidelines is attached.

Amongst those principles was provision for a service agreement to be entered into between the Attorney-General's Department and each department and Budget-dependent agency describing the legal services to be provided and regulating the provision of those services. Paragraphs nine and ten refer.
I am advised that a number of departments and Budget-dependent agencies have concluded service agreements with the Attorney-General's Department.

In respect of the arrangements between the Legal Practice and the Department of Defence and other Commonwealth departments and agencies in relation to the exclusive provision of legal services I am advised that no authorisation has been sought from the Trade Practices Commission because it is considered that the Trade Practices Act 1974 has no application to those arrangements because they are, in effect, internal administrative arrangements for the provision by the Commonwealth of legal services to other emanations of the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 4 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What have been the movements of HMAS Sydney since the beginning of 1994, and what are its future plans.

(2) (a) What Australian warships, submarines and frigates were involved in the Gulf War or carried out duties regarding Iraq after that time; and (b) was HMAS Sydney involved in the Gulf War and/or duties relevant to Iraq after the end of the Gulf War.

(3) (a) Which Australian warships, submarines and frigates are in the Gulf; (b) what are their duties; (c) what is their weaponry; (d) what is their quantity of personnel; and (e) how much does it cost per day and per year to operate each of these warships, submarines or frigates.
(4) How much does it cost per day and per year to operate the HMAS Sydney where it is currently deployed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) From February 1994, HMAS Sydney was conducting helicopter flight trials in the eastern Australian area. In April, HMAS Sydney deployed to the Hawaii area for Exercise Rimpac 94. On its return to Australia in July, HMAS Sydney had a two month maintenance period followed by a period exercising in the eastern Australian area, which included the recent maritime search and rescue effort involving a missing plane off Newcastle, NSW.

HMAS Sydney is now programmed to conduct exercises in Western Australian waters late in October, returning to the east coast in November prior to a leave and maintenance period. In 1995, HMAS Sydney will be exercising in northern Australian waters before deploying to Asia.
(2) (a) HMA Ships Brisbane, Sydney and Westralia were involved in the multinational force during the Gulf War, and HMA Ships Canberra, Darwin and Success also took part in operations against Iraq.
(b) HMAS Sydney participated in the Gulf War and completed two other deployments to the Gulf at the end of 1991 and during 1993.
(3) There are no Australian warships serving in the multinational force supporting the blockade of

ANSWER.PARA: Iraq. The last deployment to the Red Sea by the RAN concluded in December 1993.

PARA.TAB: (4) HMAS Sydney's average operating cost per day at sea, including personnel costs, is $163 824. This equates to an annual figure of $19 495 000.
These costs are determined on programmed activities only. Additional unplanned activity such as HMAS Sydney's recent 4-day maritime search and rescue effort is not included in this costing.
